rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: HFC 245fa (1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane) is a non-flammable cooling agent having a boiling point slightly below room temperature. It has lower toxicity compared to most HCFCâ€™s. It is utilized in Rankine cycle applications for waste heat recovery, centrifugal chilllers for process and comfort cooling, heat transfer applications, including secondary loops in commercial refrigeration, Heat pipes and thermosiphons including electronics cooling and thermal storage applications. HFC 245fa is immiscible with water. Vapor pressure: 1.4 bar at 25 °C Boiling point: 15 °C Liquid Viscosity: 0.402 mPa s at 25 °C Density: 1.339 g/mL at 25 °C

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Butyl alcohol or n-Butyl alcohol is a colourless, highly flammable liquid liquid with a strong, characteristic, mildly alcoholic odour. One of the four organic compounds having the same molecular formula, C4H9OH, but different structures: normal (n-) butyl alcohol, secondary butyl alcohol, isobutyl alcohol, and tertiary butyl alcohol. Slightly soluble in water: 79 g/l (20 °C), neutral pH. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. Flash point: 35 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 343 °C. Specific gravity: 0.810. Viscosity: 2.95 cP at 20 °C. Explosion limits: 1.4 % - 11.2 % Commercial n-butyl alcohol is made by fermentation of corn or molasses or from acetaldehyde by a series of reactions. Use: All have numerous industrial applications. n-Butyl alcohol is a solvent for lacquers, resins, and other coatings and a component of hydraulic brake fluids. Large quantities are converted to esters: the acetate is a lacquer solvent; the phthalate, a plasticizer. Secondary butyl alcohol is used mostly in the manufacture of methyl ethyl ketone, a useful solvent. Isobutyl alcohol is interchangeable in many uses with n-butyl alcohol and has been cheaper since large-scale production began in the early 1950s. Tertiary butyl alcohol is the least important; it is used in making fine chemicals and as a denaturing agent for ethyl alcohol. Any of four isomeric alcohols, C4H9OH, widely used as solvents and in organic synthesis. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Lactic acid : CH3CHOHCO2H, a colourless, odourless syrupy liquid organic acid. It is miscible with water, pH value 2.8 (10 g/l (of 90% solution), H2O, 20 °C), ethanol or glycerin. Specific Gravity: 1.2. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 122 °C. Viscosity: 40 to 100 cP.
Lactic acid is a fermentation product of lactose (milk sugar); it is present in sour milk, yoghourt, and cottage cheese. The protein in milk is coagulated (curdled) by lactic acid. Lactic acid is produced in the muscles during intense activity. Calcium lactate, a soluble lactic acid salt, is used as a source of calcium in the diet. Lactic acid is produced commercially for use in pharmaceuticals and foods, in leather tanning and textile dyeing, and in making plastics, solvents, inks, and lacquers. Other Names: Milk acid

1-Propyl alcohol, also called Propanol is a colourless, highly flammable, fragrant liquids miscible with water in all proportions (pH value almost neutral). Melting point: -127 °C. Boiling point: 97 °C. Specific gravity: 0.80. Viscosity: 2.26 cP at 20 °C and 1.13 cP at 50 °C. Flash point: 15 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 405 °C. Explosion limits: 2.1% - 12%. Vapour/air mixtures are explosive and somewhat toxic.Normal (n-)propyl alcohol (molecular formula CH3CH2CH2OH), or 1-propanol, is a by-product of the synthesis of methyl alcohol from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. It occurs in fusel oil (higher alcohols and their esters). It easily forms esters and ethers, some of commercial importance. Use: 1-Propyl alcohol is used especially in the preparation of lacquers. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Tartaric acid: HO2CCHOHCHOHCO2H, white colourless, odourless, crystalline powder. Very soluble in water: 1390 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.6 (100 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Melting point: 206 °C. Tartaric acid is an organic fruit acid. It occurs in many plants, particularly in the grape and is easily obtained from tartar.This natural acid is chiefly the dextrorotatory D-tartaric acid, called also D-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid or L-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid. This form can be partially converted to the others by heating it with an aqueous alkali, e.g., potassium hydroxide. Tartaric acids can be synthesized from maleic acids or fumaric acids by reaction with aqueous potassium permanganate. The various isomeric forms differ in such physical properties as boiling point. Use: Tartaric acid is used in the form of its salts, e.g., cream of tartar and Rochelle salt. It is also used as synergist for antioxidants, acid, sequestrant and flavouring agent. Widely used in foodstuffs industry such as foaming agent of beer, acidity agent, taste improvement of foodstuffs, cold drink, candy, fruit juice and ferment powder.

Methylethylketone (MEK) or butanone is a flammable organic solvent used in plastic industry for e.g. gums, resins and cellulose acetate. It has a sweet smell and is colorless. It is soluble in water up to 27.5 grams per 100 mL water. It is miscible with alcohols and paraffinic oils. Melting Point: -86 °C Boiling Point: 79.6 °C Flash point: -9 °C Density: 0.805 g/mL at 20 °C Viscosity: 0.43 cP at 20 °C

2-Ethoxyethanol, also known by the trademark Cellosolve or ethyl cellosolve , is a solvent used widely in commercial and Ethylene glycol monoethylether 2-ethoxy-ethanol Formula: HOCH3CH2OCH2CH3 industrial applications. It is a clear, colorless, nearly odorless liquid that is miscible with water, ethanol, diethyl ether, acetone, and ethyl acetate. As with other glycol ethers, 2-ethoxyethanol has the useful property of being able to dissolve chemically diverse compounds. It will dissolve oils, resins, grease, waxes, nitrocellulose, and lacquers. This is an ideal property as a multi-purpose cleaner, and, therefore, 2-ethoxyethanol is used in products, such as varnish removers and degreasing solutions. Boiling point: 135 °C Flash point: 42 °C Viscosity: 2.50 mPs at 20 °C Density: 0.960 g/mL at 20 °C Water miscible. Combustible.

Citric acid: or 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboxylic acid, HO2CCH2C(OH)(CO2H)CH2CO2H, an organic carboxylic acid containing three carboxyl groups; it is a solid at room temperature, melts at 153 °C, and decomposes at higher temperatures. Solubility in water 1630 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is responsible for the tart taste of various fruits in which it occurs, e.g., lemons, limes, oranges, pineapples, and gooseberries. It can be extracted from the juice of citrus fruits by adding calcium oxide (lime) to form calcium citrate, an insoluble precipitate that can be collected by filtration; the citric acid can be recovered from its calcium salt by adding sulfuric acid. It is obtained also by fermentation of glucose with the aid of the mold Aspergillus niger and can be obtained synthetically from acetone or glycerol. Use: Citric acid is used in soft drinks and in laxatives and cathartics. Its salts, the citrates, have many uses, e.g., ferric ammonium citrate is used in making blueprint paper. Sour salt, used in cooking, is citric acid.

Salicylic acid: or 2-hydroxybenzoic acid, C6H4(OH)CO2H, a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 159 °C; it is soluble in ethanol and ether but is only slightly soluble in water. Solubility in water 1.8 g/l (20 °C) pH value 3 (20 °C) (saturated solution).
Salicylic acid and its derivatives are toxic when consumed in large amounts. Sodium salicylate is used to a small extent as a food preservative and as an antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.
The major use of salicylic acid is in the preparation of its ester derivatives; since it contains both a hydroxyl (-OH) and a carboxyl (-CO2H) group, it can react with either an acid or an alcohol.
The hydroxyl group reacts with acetic acid to form the acetate ester, acetylsalicylic acid. Several useful esters are formed by reaction of the carboxyl group with alcohols.
The methyl ester, methyl salicylate (also called oil of wintergreen since it produces the fragrance of wintergreen), is formed with methanol. Methyl salicylate is used in food flavourings and in liniments.
The phenyl ester, phenyl salicylate, or salol, is formed with phenol; it is used in medicine as an antiseptic and antipyretic. This ester does not hydrolyse in the acidic stomach, but in the alkaline intestines, releasing free salicylic acid.
The menthyl ester, menthyl salicylate, which is used in suntan lotions, is formed with menthol.

Lactic acid : CH3CHOHCO2H, a colourless, odourless syrupy liquid organic acid. It is miscible with water, pH value 2.8 (10 g/l (of 90% solution), H2O, 20 °C), ethanol or glycerin. Specific Gravity: 1.2. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 122 °C. Viscosity: 40 to 100 cP.
Lactic acid is a fermentation product of lactose (milk sugar); it is present in sour milk, yoghourt, and cottage cheese. The protein in milk is coagulated (curdled) by lactic acid. Lactic acid is produced in the muscles during intense activity. Calcium lactate, a soluble lactic acid salt, is used as a source of calcium in the diet. Lactic acid is produced commercially for use in pharmaceuticals and foods, in leather tanning and textile dyeing, and in making plastics, solvents, inks, and lacquers. Other Names: Milk acid

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Acetaldehyde or ethanal, a highly flammable colourless liquid aldehyde with a pungent, fruity odour, sometimes simply called aldehyde. Acetaldehyde is soluble in water and ethanol. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Prolonged contact with air may cause formation of peroxides that may explode. It is formed by the partial oxidation of ethanol. Oxidation of acetaldehyde forms acetic acid. Acetaldehyde is made commercially by the oxidation of ethylene with a palladium catalyst. Use: Acetaldehyde is mainly used as an intermediate in the synthesis of other chemicals. Acetaldehyde is formed as a product of incomplete wood combustion in fireplaces and woodstoves, forest and wildfires, pulp and paper production, stationary internal combustion engines and turbines, vehicle exhaust fumes, and wastewater processing. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Calcium acetate: White crystals or powder with slight acetic acid odour. Melting point 230 °C. Decomposes to form acetone, calcium carbonate. Solubility in water 300g/l (0 °C). pH value 7.2 - 8.2 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Used as deicer, in lubricants, as food stabilizer and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Acetic acid, CH3CO2H, colourless liquid that has a characteristic pungent odor, boils at 118 °C, and is miscible with water in all proportions; it is a weak organic carboxylic acid (see carboxyl group). Glacial acetic acid is concentrated, 99.5% pure acetic acid; it solidifies at about 17 °C to a crystalline mass resembling ice. Specific gravity: 1.050. Flash point 39 °C. Auto ignition temperature 463 °C. Melting point: 17 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. pH value: 2.9 (6 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Use: Acetic acid is the major acid in vinegar; as such, it is widely used as a food preservative and condiment. For industrial use concentrated acetic acid is prepared from the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Acetic acid is also a product in the destructive distillation of wood. It reacts with other chemicals to form numerous compounds of commercial importance. These include cellulose acetate, used in making acetate rayon, nonflammable motion-picture film, lacquers, and plastics; various inorganic salts, e.g., lead, potassium, and copper acetates; and amyl, butyl, ethyl, methyl, and propyl acetates, which are used as solvents, mostly in certain quick-drying lacquers and cements. Amyl acetate is sometimes called banana oil because it has a characteristic banana odor.

Acetic anhydride: Colourless liquid with strong acetic acid odor. Slowly soluble in water, forming acetic acid. Specific gravity 1.08. Viscosity: 0.912 cP. Melting point -73 °C. Boiling point 140 °C. Flash point 49 °C (combustible). Auto ignition temperature: 316 °C. Soluble in cold water(>=10mg/ml); Decomposes in hot water. Acetic anhydride belongs to the group of acid anhydrides, which is a chemical compound that reacts with water to form an acid. Anhydrides of inorganic acids are normally oxides of nonmetallic elements. Carbon dioxide, CO2, is the anhydride of carbonic acid, H2CO3. Nitrogen pentoxide, N2O5, is the anhydride of nitric acid, HNO3. Phosphorus pentoxide, P2O5, is the anhydride of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Sulfur dioxide, SO2, is the anhydride of sulfurous acid, H2SO3. Sulfur trioxide, SO3, is the anhydride of sulfuric acid, H2SO4. Anhydrides of organic acids, like the acids themselves, contain the carbonyl group, CO. Organic anhydrides include acetic anhydride or ethanoic anhydride, (CH3CO)2O, and benzoic anhydride, (C6H5CO)2O. Use: Used in manufacture of acetyl compounds and cellulose acetates. Also as solvent in examining wool fat, glycerol, fatty and volatile oils and resins. Widely used in organic syntheses as dehydrating agent in nitrations, sulfonations and other reactions where removal of water is necessary. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Butyl acetate or n-Butyl acetate is a colorless, flammable liquid that has a pleasant, fruity odor (rather like pears), and it is used in the flavoring/fragrance industry as an artificial flavoring. pH value: neutral. Specific gravity: 0.880. Melting point: -77 °C. Boiling point: 127 °C (1013 hPa). Flash point physical: 22 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 420 °C. Viscosity: 0.73 cP at 20 °C. Slightly soluble in water (7 g/l at 20 °C). Use: Butyl acetate is often used in organic chemistry laboratories as a solvent. Industrially, n-butyl acetate is used in the manufacture of lacquers, artificial leather, photographic films, plastics, and safety glass. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Solubility in water 300g/l (0 °C). pH value 7.2 - 8.2 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Used as deicer, in lubricants, as food stabilizer and as a corrosion inhibitor.

The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Ethyl acetate or ethyl ethanoate is used in glues, nail polish removers, decaffeinating tea and coffee, and cigarettes. Its main use is as solvent. Ethyl acetate is colorless and has a sweet smell. It is soluble in water up to 8 grams per 100 mL water. Boiling Point: 77.1 °C Flash Point: -4 °C Viscosity: 0.426 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.897 g/mL at 20 °C

Ethyl acetate or ethyl ethanoate is used in glues, nail polish removers, decaffeinating tea and coffee, and cigarettes. Its main use is as solvent. Ethyl acetate is colorless and has a sweet smell. It is soluble in water up to 8 grams per 100 mL water. Boiling Point: 77.1 °C Flash Point: -4 °C Viscosity: 0.426 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.897 g/mL at 20 °C

Acetone: CH3COCH3, colourless, highly flammable (flash point <. -20 °C) and volatile liquid. Soluble in water. Acetone is the simplest aliphatic ketone. Melting point: -97 °C. Boiling point: 57 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 465 °C. Viscosity: 0.30 cP at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79 at 20 °C. Use: Acetone is widely used in industry as a solvent for numerous organic substances and is a component of most paint and varnish removers. It is used in the manufacture of synthetic resins and fillers, smokeless powders (e.g., cordite), and numerous other organic compounds. Acetone is produced commercially mostly by catalytic dehydrogenation of isopropanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Tetrachloroethane: 1,1,2,2-Tetrachloroethane is a colourless or pale yellow liquid with a suffocating, sweetish odour. Almost insoluble in water.
Melting point: -44 °C, boiling point: 146 °C. Flash point: none. Specific gravity: 1.595. Viscosity: 1.7 cP at 20 °C.
It is used in making other chemicals, insecticides, paints, rust removers and varnishes. Tetrachloroethane is toxic, a powerful narcotic and possibly carcinogenic.

Acid cleaning: Used in cleaning operations to remove encrusted surface matter and mineral scale found on metal equipment such as boilers and steam producing equipment. Orthophosphoric acid is routinely used as a cleaning compound in its dilute form to remove oxidation from non-stainless steel surfaces, staining of stainless steel, lime and scale from heat exchangers and in Clean-in-Place (CIP) cleaning operations especially in dairy processing to remove build up of calcium and phosphate salts from processing equipment. It is also used to brighten metals and remove rust. Additionally, orthophosphoric acid can be mixed with other detergents for process cleaning operations. Phosphoric acid is preferred because it is the lowest in corrosiveness at the low concentrations which are effective and is compatible with many surfactants. Organic acids such as citric, tartaric, acetic and gluconic are effective in some situations, especially removing mineral deposits formed as a result of using alkaline cleaning compounds or other cleaners. They are not as corrosive or irritating to the skin and they are good water softeners and rinse easily. Other strong acid agents used for cleaning operations include hydrochloric (muriatic), hydrofluoric, sulfamic, sulfuric, and nitric acids. Nitric and sulfuric acids are so corrosive that they are not generally used as cleaners. Hydrofluoric acid is very unstable and dangerous to handle and also extremely corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is very effective at descaling metals but produces highly toxic fumes in the form of hydrogen chloride gas. This special cleaner dissolves and removes rust, scale, lime, corrosion, excess concrete, soap scum, mortar, urine build-up and all water minerals. Strong acids are normally inhibited in order to avoid corrosion attack on metals.

Acetic acid, CH3CO2H, colourless liquid that has a characteristic pungent odor, boils at 118 °C, and is miscible with water in all proportions; it is a weak organic carboxylic acid (see carboxyl group). Glacial acetic acid is concentrated, 99.5% pure acetic acid; it solidifies at about 17 °C to a crystalline mass resembling ice. Specific gravity: 1.050. Flash point 39 °C. Auto ignition temperature 463 °C. Melting point: 17 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. pH value: 2.9 (6 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Use: Acetic acid is the major acid in vinegar; as such, it is widely used as a food preservative and condiment. For industrial use concentrated acetic acid is prepared from the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Acetic acid is also a product in the destructive distillation of wood. It reacts with other chemicals to form numerous compounds of commercial importance. These include cellulose acetate, used in making acetate rayon, nonflammable motion-picture film, lacquers, and plastics; various inorganic salts, e.g., lead, potassium, and copper acetates; and amyl, butyl, ethyl, methyl, and propyl acetates, which are used as solvents, mostly in certain quick-drying lacquers and cements. Amyl acetate is sometimes called banana oil because it has a characteristic banana odor.

Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.

Phenol (C6H5OH) is a colorless, combustible, crystalline solid with a characteristic odor. Liquid water and phenol show limited miscibility below 70 °C. It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phenol is a poisonous and hazardous liquid; rapidly absorbed through the skin, causing severe burns. It is an aromatic alcohol that exhibits weak acidic properties and is corrosive and poisonous.
Melting point: about 41 °C. Boiling point: 182 °C (conc.) Flash point: 79 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 715 °C. Explosion limits: 1.5 % - 8.6 % pH of phenol water mixtures are slightly acidic (around 5-6) Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.06 (80%) and 1.07 (conc.) Viscosity at 45 °C: 3.8 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 60 °C: 2.5 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 80 °C: 1.6 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 100 °C: 1.1 cSt. (conc.)
The main use of phenol is as a feedstock for phenolic resins, bisphenol A and caprolactam (an intermediate in the production of nylon-6). It is used in the manufacture of many products including insulation materials, adhesives, lacquers, paint, rubber, ink and dyes. It is found in some commercial disinfectants, antiseptics and lotions.
The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.
Carbonic acid (H2CO3) is formed when CO2, a colourless odourless gas is dissolved in water.

Chromic acid: occurring only as salt (CrO3, dark-red, odourless flakes or powder), or in solution as H2CrO4, a corrosive, oxidizing acid. Solubility in water 63% at 20 °C. pH value 0.2 - 2 depending on concentration. Use: Chromic acid is used in the preparation of wood preservatives, metal plating, magnetic tapes and catalyst production. Chromic acid is used extensively in formulating wood preservatives. The chromate salts act as a fixative, bonding other protective chemicals to the wood.Chromic acid serves as the source of chromium metal for plating chromium on all common metals and plastics. Chromium plating is of two types: decorative plating, normally over deposits of copper and/or nickel, and hard chromium plating, applied directly to cast iron, steel, aluminum and other metals. Decorative plating is used on automobile trim and other consumer products, such as toasters, major appliances, and plumbing fixtures.

Citric acid: or 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboxylic acid, HO2CCH2C(OH)(CO2H)CH2CO2H, an organic carboxylic acid containing three carboxyl groups; it is a solid at room temperature, melts at 153 °C, and decomposes at higher temperatures. Solubility in water 1630 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is responsible for the tart taste of various fruits in which it occurs, e.g., lemons, limes, oranges, pineapples, and gooseberries. It can be extracted from the juice of citrus fruits by adding calcium oxide (lime) to form calcium citrate, an insoluble precipitate that can be collected by filtration; the citric acid can be recovered from its calcium salt by adding sulfuric acid. It is obtained also by fermentation of glucose with the aid of the mold Aspergillus niger and can be obtained synthetically from acetone or glycerol. Use: Citric acid is used in soft drinks and in laxatives and cathartics. Its salts, the citrates, have many uses, e.g., ferric ammonium citrate is used in making blueprint paper. Sour salt, used in cooking, is citric acid.

Formic acid: or methanoic acid, HCO2H, a colourless, corrosive liquid with a sharp odor.; it boils at 101 °C and solidifies at 8 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 2.2 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Note: Often used in an aqueous solution. It has the lowest molecular weight and is the simplest of the carboxylic acids. Functionally, it is both an acid and an aldehyde. Like other acids, it reacts with most alcohols to form esters and decomposes when heated; like other aldehydes, it is easily oxidized. Formic acid occurs in the bodies of red ants and in the stingers of bees. It can be made by the oxidation of formaldehyde; it is prepared commercially by heating carbon monoxide and sodium hydroxide to form sodium formate which, when carefully treated with sulfuric acid, yields formic acid. Use: Formic acid is used industrially in textile dyeing, in leather tanning, and in coagulating latex rubber.

Hydrochloric acid: HCl, a colourless, poisonous gas with an unpleasant, acrid odor. It is very soluble in water and readily soluble in alcohol and ether. It fumes in moist air. It is not flammable, and the liquid is a poor conductor of electricity. Hydrochloric acid is prepared commercially by the reaction of sulfuric acid with sodium chloride (common salt); niter cake, a mixture of sodium bisulfite and sulfuric acid that is a byproduct of nitric acid manufacture, is sometimes used in place of sulfuric acid. Hydrochloric acid is also produced as a byproduct of the manufacture of chlorinated organic chemicals. It can be prepared directly by reaction of hydrogen and chlorine gases; the reaction is very exothermic and takes place readily in sunlight or at elevated temperatures. Although anhydrous (water-free) hydrochloric acid is commercially available as a high-pressure compressed gas in steel cylinders, most of the gas produced is dissolved in water to form hydrochloric acid, a commercially important chemical. Pure grades of hydrochloric acid are colourless, but technical grades, commonly called muriatic acid, are often yellow-coloured because of impurities such as dissolved metals. Most hydrochloric acid produced has a concentration of 30% to 35% hydrogen chloride by weight. Use: The major use of hydrochloric acid is in the manufacture of other chemicals. It is also used in large amounts in pickling (cleaning) metal surfaces, e.g., iron before galvanizing. It reacts with most common metals, releasing hydrogen and forming the metal chloride; with most metal oxides and hydroxides it reacts to form water and the metal chloride. Hydrochloric acid is also used in small amounts in processing glucose and other foods and for various other uses. Concentrated solutions are strong acids and highly corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is not an oxidizing agent but can be oxidized by very strong oxidizing agents, liberating chlorine gas. In dilute solutions of the acid the hydrogen chloride is almost completely dissociated into hydrogen and chloride ions.

Hydrofluoric acid: A colourless, fuming, corrosive, dangerously poisonous aqueous solution of hydrogen fluoride, HF, used to etch or polish glass, pickle certain metals, and clean masonry.
Hydrogen fluoride(HF) a colourless, fuming liquid or colourless gas that boils at 20 °C. Above 19 °C, hydrogen fluoride is a gas.
Hydrofluoric acid is available with concentrations in the range of 30 - 70 % HF w/v.
Hydrofluoric acid containing 35.35% hydrogen fluoride by weight is an azeotrope with a constant boiling point of 120 °C.
Whether gaseous, liquid, or in solution, hydrogen fluoride is a dangerous chemical and must be handled with caution, since it attacks the skin and other tissue. Hydrofluoric acid attacks glass, reacting with the silica, SiO2, to form the gas silicon tetrafluoride, SiF4, and water; this leaves the surface of the glass etched.
Hydrofluoric acid is extremely potent and dangerous, and must be handled with extreme caution. It can penetrate thick, calloused skin and even fingernails, causing extensive skin burns and scarring. A major exposure to concentrated HF can bind the body's calcium stores from the bones, causing seizures, bone destruction and death. Inhaling HF fumes can lead to pneumonia. A splash of HF in the eyes can cause destruction of the eye tissues and blindness.

Lactic acid : CH3CHOHCO2H, a colourless, odourless syrupy liquid organic acid. It is miscible with water, pH value 2.8 (10 g/l (of 90% solution), H2O, 20 °C), ethanol or glycerin. Specific Gravity: 1.2. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 122 °C. Viscosity: 40 to 100 cP.
Lactic acid is a fermentation product of lactose (milk sugar); it is present in sour milk, yoghourt, and cottage cheese. The protein in milk is coagulated (curdled) by lactic acid. Lactic acid is produced in the muscles during intense activity. Calcium lactate, a soluble lactic acid salt, is used as a source of calcium in the diet. Lactic acid is produced commercially for use in pharmaceuticals and foods, in leather tanning and textile dyeing, and in making plastics, solvents, inks, and lacquers. Other Names: Milk acid

Linoleic acid:Colourless liquid with a specific gravity of 0.9 at 22 °C. Melting point -12 °C. Insoluble in water.
Linoleic acid is an unsaturated fatty acid, C17H31COOH, considered essential to the human diet.
Linoleic acid is an important component of drying oils, such as linseed oil.
Linoleic acid is a major constituent of many vegetable oils e.g. cottonseed, soybean, peanut, corn, sunflower seed and linseed. It is used for manufacturing of paints, coatings, emulsifiers, vitamins and as a nutrient.

Maleic acid, or cis-butenedioic acid, is a geometric isomer of fumaric acid. Appearance: White crystals, faint acidulous odor. Specific gravity: 1.59. pH: less than 7 acidic. White crystals, dissolves readily in water and alcohol . Solubility in water 79 g/100g (25 °C). Melting point 139 °C-140 °C. At higher temperatures it forms the anhydride, which, like the acid, is irritating to the skin and toxic.
Maleic acid is a stronger organic acid, also called Cis-butenedioic Acid (HO2CCH=CHCO2H). It is an unsaturated organic dibasic acid, that is used in making polyesters for fibre-reinforced laminated moldings, paint for vehicles, and in the manufacture of fumaric acid and many other chemical products.
Maleic Acid is used in the production of insecticide (e.g. Malathion), medicine, synthetic resin and other chemicals, such as tartaric acid and malic acid. Maleic acid is also used as a mordant in dyeing.Maleic anhydride is interchangeable with the acid in most applications.

Nitric acid: chemical compound, HNO3, colourless, highly corrosive, poisonous liquid that gives off choking fumes in moist air. It is miscible with water in all proportions. It forms an azeotrope (constant-boiling mixture) that has the composition 68% nitric acid and 32% water and that boils at 121 °C. The nitric acid of commerce is typically a solution of 52% to 68% nitric acid in water. More concentrated solutions are available. Solutions containing over 86% nitric acid are commonly called fuming nitric acid; they often have a reddish-brown colour from dissolved nitrogen oxides. It is produced mostly by oxidation of ammonia (the Ostwald process). Small amounts are produced by the treatment of sodium nitrate with sulfuric acid. Nitric acid was known to the alchemists as aqua fortis; the name is used in commerce for impure grades of it. Aqua regia is a mixture of nitric and hydrochloric acids. Nitric acid is a strong oxidizing agent. It ionizes readily in solution, forming a good conductor of electricity. It reacts with metals, oxides, and hydroxides, forming nitrate salts. Use: Main uses of nitric acid are in the preparation of fertilizers, e.g., ammonium nitrate, and explosives (e.g. nitroglycerin). It is also used in the manufacture of chemicals, e.g., in making dyes.

Linoleic acid:Colourless liquid with a specific gravity of 0.9 at 22 °C. Melting point -12 °C. Insoluble in water.
Linoleic acid is an unsaturated fatty acid, C17H31COOH, considered essential to the human diet.
Linoleic acid is an important component of drying oils, such as linseed oil.
Linoleic acid is a major constituent of many vegetable oils e.g. cottonseed, soybean, peanut, corn, sunflower seed and linseed. It is used for manufacturing of paints, coatings, emulsifiers, vitamins and as a nutrient.

Oxalic acid or ethanedioic acid, HO2CCO2H, is a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 102 °C with sublimation. Solubility in water 102 g/l (20 °C) pH value 0.7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Oxalic acid and oxalate salts are poisonous. Oxalic acid is found in many plants, e.g., sorrel and rhubarb, normally as its calcium or potassium salts.
Oxalic acid is the only possible compound in which two carboxyl groups are joined directly; for this reason oxalic acid is one of the strongest organic acids. Unlike other carboxylic acids (except formic acid), it is readily oxidized. This makes it useful as a reducing agent for photography, bleaching, and ink removal.

Palmitic acid: Appearance: white chips, crystals or powder. Odor: Slight characteristic odor. Insoluble in water. Melting point: 61 °C - 64 °C Boiling point: 352 °C. Specific gravity: 0.840. Viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.
Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and a major component of solid fats. It is found in palm oil and many animal fats (milk or butterfat is 21 percent palmitic acid). Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. As an additive, palmitic acid is used in the manufacture of soap and to enhance the flavor of butter and cheese spreads.
rdf:Description.viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Phenol (C6H5OH) is a colorless, combustible, crystalline solid with a characteristic odor. Liquid water and phenol show limited miscibility below 70 °C. It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phenol is a poisonous and hazardous liquid; rapidly absorbed through the skin, causing severe burns. It is an aromatic alcohol that exhibits weak acidic properties and is corrosive and poisonous.
Melting point: about 41 °C. Boiling point: 182 °C (conc.) Flash point: 79 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 715 °C. Explosion limits: 1.5 % - 8.6 % pH of phenol water mixtures are slightly acidic (around 5-6) Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.06 (80%) and 1.07 (conc.) Viscosity at 45 °C: 3.8 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 60 °C: 2.5 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 80 °C: 1.6 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 100 °C: 1.1 cSt. (conc.)
The main use of phenol is as a feedstock for phenolic resins, bisphenol A and caprolactam (an intermediate in the production of nylon-6). It is used in the manufacture of many products including insulation materials, adhesives, lacquers, paint, rubber, ink and dyes. It is found in some commercial disinfectants, antiseptics and lotions.
The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Phosphoric acid: H3PO4, a common acid of phosphorus that is the source of industrially important compounds called phosphates. At room temperature, phosphoric acid is a crystalline material with a specific gravity of 1.83. The solid melts at 42 °C. Soluble in water, pH value below 0.5 (100 g/l (of 85% solution), H2O, 20 °C). Phosphoric acid is normally stored and sold as a solution. Phosphoric acid is made by treating calcium phosphate rock with sulphuric acid, followed by filtration of the resultant liquid to remove calcium sulfate. It can be prepared also by burning phosphorus vapour and treating the resulting oxide with steam. Use: The acid is useful in the laboratory because of its resistance to oxidation, to reduction, and to evaporation. Phosphoric acid has found many uses e.g. as an ingredient in soft drinks and dental cements, as a catalyst, in pickling and rustproofing metals, and in making phosphates, which are used in water softeners, fertilisers, and detergents.

Salicylic acid: or 2-hydroxybenzoic acid, C6H4(OH)CO2H, a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 159 °C; it is soluble in ethanol and ether but is only slightly soluble in water. Solubility in water 1.8 g/l (20 °C) pH value 3 (20 °C) (saturated solution).
Salicylic acid and its derivatives are toxic when consumed in large amounts. Sodium salicylate is used to a small extent as a food preservative and as an antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.
The major use of salicylic acid is in the preparation of its ester derivatives; since it contains both a hydroxyl (-OH) and a carboxyl (-CO2H) group, it can react with either an acid or an alcohol.
The hydroxyl group reacts with acetic acid to form the acetate ester, acetylsalicylic acid. Several useful esters are formed by reaction of the carboxyl group with alcohols.
The methyl ester, methyl salicylate (also called oil of wintergreen since it produces the fragrance of wintergreen), is formed with methanol. Methyl salicylate is used in food flavourings and in liniments.
The phenyl ester, phenyl salicylate, or salol, is formed with phenol; it is used in medicine as an antiseptic and antipyretic. This ester does not hydrolyse in the acidic stomach, but in the alkaline intestines, releasing free salicylic acid.
The menthyl ester, menthyl salicylate, which is used in suntan lotions, is formed with menthol.

Stearic acid: A colourless, odorless, waxlike saturated fatty acid, CH3(CH2)16COOH, almost insoluble in water (less than 0.1%).
Melting point: 69 °C. Boiling point: 383 °C. Flash point: 196 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 395 °C. Specific gravity 0.87
Stearic acid is also called octedacanoic acid, and it is one of the most common long-chain fatty acids, found in combined form in natural animal and vegetable fats. Commercial "stearic acid" is a mixture of approximately equal amounts of stearic and palmitic acids and small amounts of oleic acid. It is employed in the manufacture of candles, cosmetics, shaving soaps, lubricants, and pharmaceuticals.
In nature stearic acid occurs primarily as a mixed triglyceride, or fat, with other long-chain acids and as an ester of a fatty alcohol. It is much more abundant in animal fat than in vegetable fat; lard and tallow often contain up to 30 percent stearic acid.
Alkaline hydrolysis, or saponification, of fats yields soaps, which are the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Pure stearic acid is obtained with difficulty from such a mixture by crystallization, vacuum distillation, or chromatography of the acids or suitable derivatives. The pure acid undergoes chemical reactions typical of carboxylic acids.

Sulfamic acid: A very corrosive acid. For that reason an inhibited solution of sulfamic acid is often used for descaling. Melting point 205 °C. The substance decomposes on heating or on burning producing toxic and corrosive fumes including nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. It reacts slowly with water to form ammonium bisulfate. Sulfamic acid is a dry, non-volatile, non-hygroscopic, odorless, white crystalline, stable solid acid. It is moderately soluble in water and forms a strongly acidic and corrosive aqueous solution (pH value 1.18 (1 g/100ml, H2O, 25 °C)) that is comparable in acidity to the common strong mineral acids but may be easily handled and stored in the dry form. Its solution is less corrosive towards metals than other mineral acids. Salts of sulfamic acid are very soluble in water. Use: Acid Cleaning and pH adjustment. Descaling agent of cooling towers (air conditioners), marine equipment (sea water evaporators), water wells, dairy equipment (pipeline milkers, milk evaporators), brewery equipment, sugar evaporators, pulp and paper equipment, desalination equipment, general industrial equipment (boilers, condensers, heat exchangers, evaporators, etc.) and household equipment. Bleaching for Pulp. Dyes and Pigments. Electroplating.

Sulfuric acid: H2SO4, corrosive, oily, colourless liquid, with a specific gravity of 1.85. Melting point: 10 °C. Boiling point 340 °C. (pH value 1 at 25%, 20 °C) Sulfuric acid is soluble in all proportions in water. When sulfuric acid is mixed with water, considerable heat is released. Unless the mixture is well stirred, the added water may be heated beyond its boiling point and the sudden formation of steam may blow the acid out of its container. Properties: Sulfuric acid is a strong acid, that in aqueous solution is largely changed to hydrogen ions (H+) and sulfate ions (SO4--). Each molecule gives two H+ ions, thus sulfuric acid is dibasic. Dilute solutions of sulfuric acid show all the behavior characteristics of acids. They taste sour, conduct electricity, neutralize alkalies, and corrode active metals with formation of hydrogen gas. Concentrated sulfuric acid, formerly called oil of vitriol, is a valuable desiccating agent. It acts so vigorously in this respect that it removes water from (and therefore chars) wood, cotton, sugar, and paper. It is used in the manufacture of ether, nitroglycerin, and dyes for its property as a desiccant. When concentrated sulfuric acid is heated, it behaves also as an oxidizing agent, capable, for example, of dissolving such relatively unreactive metals as copper, mercury, and lead to produce metal sulfate, sulfur dioxide, and water. Use: The uses of sulfuric acid are so varied that the volume of its production provides an approximate index of general industrial activity. American production of sulfuric acid exceeded 29 million tons annually in the early 1970s, a figure corresponding to a daily production of 1/3 kg (3/4 lb) per person throughout the year. The largest single use of sulfuric acid is for making fertilizers, both superphosphate and ammonium sulfate. It is also used in making organic products, refining petroleum, making paints and pigments, processing metals, and making rayon. One of the few consumer products containing sulfuric acid as such is the lead storage battery, or car energizer.

Sulfurous acid: A solution of about 6% SO2 in water. When sulfur dioxide (SO2) is dissolved in water, an acidic solution results. This has long been loosely called a sulfurous acid, H2SO3, solution. Sulfurous acid solutions can be oxidised by strong oxidising agents, and oxygen from the atmospheric air slowly oxidises the solution to the more stable sulfuric acid. Sulfurous Acid will react with a base to form sulfite salts. Use: Sulphurous acid is a strong reducing agent. The solution has bleaching properties. Moistened wool, straw for hats, and other materials normally injured by chlorine are bleached on exposure to sulphur dioxide.

Tannic acid: tannin or gallotannic acid, astringent vegetable product found in a wide variety of plants. Tannic acid is a colourless to pale yellow solid.
Decomposes at 210 °C - 215 °C. Solubility in water 250 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Tannic acid of commerce use normally contains about 10% of water.
Tannin varies somewhat in composition, having the approximate empirical formula C76H52O46. It is believed to be a glucoside in which each of the five hydroxyl groups of the glucose molecule is esterified with a molecule of digallic acid.
Sources include the bark of oak, hemlock, chestnut, and mangrove; the leaves of certain sumacs, and plant galls. Tannic acid is also present in tea, coffee, and walnuts. A solution of tannic acid is obtained from one of these natural sources by extraction with hot water. Tannic acid is in particular obtained from plant gall.
Tannic acid is used in tanning animal skins to make leather, it transforms certain proteins of animal tissue into compounds that resist decomposition. It is also used in manufacturing inks, as a mordant in dyeing, and in medicine as an astringent and for treatment of burns.

Tartaric acid: HO2CCHOHCHOHCO2H, white colourless, odourless, crystalline powder. Very soluble in water: 1390 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.6 (100 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Melting point: 206 °C. Tartaric acid is an organic fruit acid. It occurs in many plants, particularly in the grape and is easily obtained from tartar.This natural acid is chiefly the dextrorotatory D-tartaric acid, called also D-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid or L-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid. This form can be partially converted to the others by heating it with an aqueous alkali, e.g., potassium hydroxide. Tartaric acids can be synthesized from maleic acids or fumaric acids by reaction with aqueous potassium permanganate. The various isomeric forms differ in such physical properties as boiling point. Use: Tartaric acid is used in the form of its salts, e.g., cream of tartar and Rochelle salt. It is also used as synergist for antioxidants, acid, sequestrant and flavouring agent. Widely used in foodstuffs industry such as foaming agent of beer, acidity agent, taste improvement of foodstuffs, cold drink, candy, fruit juice and ferment powder.

Alkaline cleaning: A hot alkali solution is used to remove organic contaminants from the metal surface, including dirt, paint markings, grease, oil, etc.
Typical ingredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants. Alkaline cleaning agents have different functions and would not be considered alternatives to acids, but would be used as a separate step in a thorough cleaning program.
rdf:Description.typicalIngredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Ammonia: Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) exists naturally in a gaseous state under atmospheric pressure and temperature. Under moderate pressure it changes easily to a liquid, becoming a gas again when the pressure is reduced.
Boiling point -33 °C at atm. pressure. Extremely soluble in water e.g. 529g/l at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.638 (at 0 °C, atm. pressure). Vapour pressure is 9 bar at 20 °C and about 20 bar at 50 °C. Viscosity: 0.3 cP at -33 °C.
Industries take advantage of this characteristic by shipping and storing liquefied ammonia in pressurized railway cars, tank trucks and cylinders of various sizes.
It is primarily used as fertilizer. It is also widely used as a refrigerant and in manufacturing nitric acid, explosives, plastics and as a solvent in the chemical laboratory.
Anhydrous ammonia is one of the most water-soluble of all gases, but it should not be confused with aqueous ammonia, which is a 15 to 30 per cent solution of ammonia in water. Generally, ammonia has good warning properties because of its characteristic pungent and irritating odour.
With rising temperature ammonia expands rapidly, increasing the internal pressure in vessels and pipes, etc. This must be considered in the design and operation of ammonia systems.

Ammonium hydroxide: A saturated aqueous (water) solution of ammonia (colourless, pungent gas, NH3) contains 45 percent ammonia by weight at 0 °C and 30 percent at ordinary room temperatures. On solution in water, ammonia becomes ammonium hydroxide, NH4OH, which is strongly basic and similar in chemical behavior to the hydroxides of the alkali metals. Use: As a household cleanser and in the manufacture of a wide variety of products, including textiles, rayon, rubber, fertilizer, and plastic. Copper and copper alloys have only limited resistance to ammonium hydroxide.

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Alkaline cleaning: A hot alkali solution is used to remove organic contaminants from the metal surface, including dirt, paint markings, grease, oil, etc.
Typical ingredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants. Alkaline cleaning agents have different functions and would not be considered alternatives to acids, but would be used as a separate step in a thorough cleaning program.
rdf:Description.typicalIngredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Potassium hydroxide: Chemical compound with the formula KOH. Pure potassium hydroxide forms white, deliquescent crystals. Solubility in water 1100 g/l (20 °C). pH value >13.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). pH value 12 (0.05% aqueous solution) and 14 (5% solution). Specific gravity 1.2 (20% aqueous solution) and 1500 kg/m3 (50% aqueous solution).
For commercial and laboratory use it is normally in the form of white pellets. A strong base, it dissolves readily in water, giving off much heat and forming a strongly alkaline caustic solution. It is commonly called caustic potash. It closely resembles sodium hydroxide in its chemical properties and has similar uses, e.g., in making soap, in bleaching, and in manufacturing chemicals, but is less widely used because of its higher cost. It is prepared chiefly by electrolysis of potassium chloride. Commercial grades of potassium hydroxide sometimes contain the chloride as well as other impurities.

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

Aluminium sulfate: A white crystalline compound, Al2(SO4)3, also called ALUM. It reacts acidic with water. Melting point: 92 °C. Solubility in water about 600 g/l (20 °C). pH value about 2.5 - 4.0 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Aluminium sulfate is used in the paper industry to clarify and control the pH of process waters, process, waste and potable water treatment, as mordant for textile fabric, the manufacture of chemicals, catalysts, greases, soaps, leather tanning chemicals, fire extinguishing chemicals, in foods and for modifying concrete.

Aluminium chloride: Yellow to grey crystals with odour of hydrochloric acid. Available in different forms. In anhydrous (AlCl3) form it combines with water with explosive violence and liberation of much heat. Soluble in water (450g/l at 20 °C) and in many organic solvents. pH value 2.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting point: about 190 °C Use: The hexahydrate form AlCl3,6H2O is used in preserving wood, disinfecting stables, slaughterhouses etc.; in deodorants and antiperspirants preparations and in refining crude oil. Poly Aluminium Chlorides (PAC, A1n(OH)mC13n-m)x) are highly efficient flocculants, capable of removing every kind of particle from aqueous suspensions. Polymeric aluminium chlorides are used for treatment and cleaning of industrial water, drinking water, waste water and swimming pool water. Furthermore they are used in paper industry as an auxiliary, where excellent results are achieved The chemical composition of polymeric aluminium chloride is optimised for each application.

Aluminium sulfate: A white crystalline compound, Al2(SO4)3, also called ALUM. It reacts acidic with water. Melting point: 92 °C. Solubility in water about 600 g/l (20 °C). pH value about 2.5 - 4.0 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Aluminium sulfate is used in the paper industry to clarify and control the pH of process waters, process, waste and potable water treatment, as mordant for textile fabric, the manufacture of chemicals, catalysts, greases, soaps, leather tanning chemicals, fire extinguishing chemicals, in foods and for modifying concrete.

Aluminium chloride: Yellow to grey crystals with odour of hydrochloric acid. Available in different forms. In anhydrous (AlCl3) form it combines with water with explosive violence and liberation of much heat. Soluble in water (450g/l at 20 °C) and in many organic solvents. pH value 2.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting point: about 190 °C Use: The hexahydrate form AlCl3,6H2O is used in preserving wood, disinfecting stables, slaughterhouses etc.; in deodorants and antiperspirants preparations and in refining crude oil. Polymeric aluminium chlorides are used for treatment and cleaning of industrial water, drinking water, waste water and swimming pool water. Furthermore they are used in paper industry as an auxiliary, where excellent results are achieved The chemical composition of polymeric aluminium chloride is optimised for each application.

Aluminium sulfate: A white crystalline compound, Al2(SO4)3, also called ALUM. It reacts acidic with water. Melting point: 92 °C. Solubility in water about 600 g/l (20 °C). pH value about 2.5 - 4.0 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Aluminium sulfate is used in the paper industry to clarify and control the pH of process waters, process, waste and potable water treatment, as mordant for textile fabric, the manufacture of chemicals, catalysts, greases, soaps, leather tanning chemicals, fire extinguishing chemicals, in foods and for modifying concrete.

Sulfamic acid: A very corrosive acid. For that reason an inhibited solution of sulfamic acid is often used for descaling. Melting point 205 °C. The substance decomposes on heating or on burning producing toxic and corrosive fumes including nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. It reacts slowly with water to form ammonium bisulfate. Sulfamic acid is a dry, non-volatile, non-hygroscopic, odorless, white crystalline, stable solid acid. It is moderately soluble in water and forms a strongly acidic and corrosive aqueous solution (pH value 1.18 (1 g/100ml, H2O, 25 °C)) that is comparable in acidity to the common strong mineral acids but may be easily handled and stored in the dry form. Its solution is less corrosive towards metals than other mineral acids. Salts of sulfamic acid are very soluble in water. Use: Acid Cleaning and pH adjustment. Descaling agent of cooling towers (air conditioners), marine equipment (sea water evaporators), water wells, dairy equipment (pipeline milkers, milk evaporators), brewery equipment, sugar evaporators, pulp and paper equipment, desalination equipment, general industrial equipment (boilers, condensers, heat exchangers, evaporators, etc.) and household equipment. Bleaching for Pulp. Dyes and Pigments. Electroplating.

Sulfamic acid: A very corrosive acid. For that reason an inhibited solution of sulfamic acid is often used for descaling. Melting point 205 °C. The substance decomposes on heating or on burning producing toxic and corrosive fumes including nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. It reacts slowly with water to form ammonium bisulfate. Sulfamic acid is a dry, non-volatile, non-hygroscopic, odorless, white crystalline, stable solid acid. It is moderately soluble in water and forms a strongly acidic and corrosive aqueous solution (pH value 1.18 (1 g/100ml, H2O, 25 °C)) that is comparable in acidity to the common strong mineral acids but may be easily handled and stored in the dry form. Its solution is less corrosive towards metals than other mineral acids. Salts of sulfamic acid are very soluble in water. Use: Acid Cleaning and pH adjustment. Descaling agent of cooling towers (air conditioners), marine equipment (sea water evaporators), water wells, dairy equipment (pipeline milkers, milk evaporators), brewery equipment, sugar evaporators, pulp and paper equipment, desalination equipment, general industrial equipment (boilers, condensers, heat exchangers, evaporators, etc.) and household equipment. Bleaching for Pulp. Dyes and Pigments. Electroplating.

Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Appearance: colourless liquid with an odour of ammonia. Melting point: 10 °C - 12 °C. Boiling point: 170 °C. Specific gravity: 1.01. Viscosity (100% conc.): 24.1 cP at 20 °C and 16.2 cP at 30 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 85 C (closed cup). Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Water solubility: 100% Ethanolamine is harmful by ingestion, inhalation or if absorbed through skin. Ethanolamine may cause severe eye, skin and respiratory irritation. Use: Ethanolamnine is used as a non-ionic detergent in dry cleaning, as cleaning agent in the electronic industry, emulsion paints, polishes and agricultural sprays and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Ammonia: Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) exists naturally in a gaseous state under atmospheric pressure and temperature. Under moderate pressure it changes easily to a liquid, becoming a gas again when the pressure is reduced.
Boiling point -33 °C at atm. pressure. Extremely soluble in water e.g. 529g/l at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.638 (at 0 °C, atm. pressure). Vapour pressure is 9 bar at 20 °C and about 20 bar at 50 °C. Viscosity: 0.3 cP at -33 °C.
Industries take advantage of this characteristic by shipping and storing liquefied ammonia in pressurized railway cars, tank trucks and cylinders of various sizes.
It is primarily used as fertilizer. It is also widely used as a refrigerant and in manufacturing nitric acid, explosives, plastics and as a solvent in the chemical laboratory.
Anhydrous ammonia is one of the most water-soluble of all gases, but it should not be confused with aqueous ammonia, which is a 15 to 30 per cent solution of ammonia in water. Generally, ammonia has good warning properties because of its characteristic pungent and irritating odour.
With rising temperature ammonia expands rapidly, increasing the internal pressure in vessels and pipes, etc. This must be considered in the design and operation of ammonia systems.

Ammonium hydroxide: A saturated aqueous (water) solution of ammonia (colourless, pungent gas, NH3) contains 45 percent ammonia by weight at 0 °C and 30 percent at ordinary room temperatures. On solution in water, ammonia becomes ammonium hydroxide, NH4OH, which is strongly basic and similar in chemical behavior to the hydroxides of the alkali metals. Use: As a household cleanser and in the manufacture of a wide variety of products, including textiles, rayon, rubber, fertilizer, and plastic. Copper and copper alloys have only limited resistance to ammonium hydroxide.

Ammonium bicarbonate: A colourless to white crystalline salt with an faint ammonia odour. Releases CO2 when heated and decomposes at about 60 °C. Solubility in water 220g/l at 20 °C (decomposes in hot water). pH value about 8 (50 g/l, H2O at 20 °C). Use: Ammonium bicarbonate is used as a food additive and in baking powder. Utilized as a source of ammonia in the production of ammonium salts pharmaceuticals, pigments and dyes. Used in fire-extinguishing compounds.

Ammonium bicarbonate: A colourless to white crystalline salt with an faint ammonia odour. Releases CO2 when heated and decomposes at about 60 °C. Solubility in water 220g/l at 20 °C (decomposes in hot water). pH value about 8 (50 g/l, H2O at 20 °C). Use: Ammonium bicarbonate is used as a food additive and in baking powder. Utilized as a source of ammonia in the production of ammonium salts pharmaceuticals, pigments and dyes. Used in fire-extinguishing compounds.

Ammonium hydroxide: A saturated aqueous (water) solution of ammonia (colourless, pungent gas, NH3) contains 45 percent ammonia by weight at 0 °C and 30 percent at ordinary room temperatures. On solution in water, ammonia becomes ammonium hydroxide, NH4OH, which is strongly basic and similar in chemical behavior to the hydroxides of the alkali metals. Use: As a household cleanser and in the manufacture of a wide variety of products, including textiles, rayon, rubber, fertilizer, and plastic. Copper and copper alloys have only limited resistance to ammonium hydroxide.

Ammonium nitrate: Chemical compound, NH4NO3, that exists as colorless, rhombic crystals at room temperature but changes to monoclinic crystals when heated above 32 °C. It is a strong oxidizer and is extremely soluble in water and soluble in alcohol and liquid ammonia. Melting point: 170 °C. Specific gravity: 1.725 at 25 °C. Solubility in water 1920g/l (20 °C). pH value about 5.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is prepared commercially by reaction of nitric acid and ammonia. Use: Major uses are in fertilizers and explosives. For fertilizers it is in the form of small clay-coated pellets. For explosives it is sometimes mixed with other substances, e.g., TNT, so that it is more easily detonated. It is also used in solid-fuel rocket propellants, in pyrotechnics, and in the production of nitrous oxide.

Ammonium sulfate: Chemical compound, (NH4)2SO4, a colorless-to-gray, crystalline substance that occurs in nature as the mineral mascagnite. It is soluble in water and insoluble in alcohol or liquid ammonia. Melting point: 280 °C, decomposes. Solubility in water: 754g/l (20 °C). pH value: 5 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity: (40%, 20 °C): 1.23. Viscosity (40%, 20 °C): 2.06 cSt. Use: Ammonium sulfate is used as a fertilizer, in galvanizing, in preparing other ammonium compounds and for fireproofing.

Boiling point -33 °C at atm. pressure. Extremely soluble in water e.g. 529g/l at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.638 (at 0 °C, atm. pressure). Vapour pressure is 9 bar at 20 °C and about 20 bar at 50 °C. Viscosity: 0.3 cP at -33 °C.
Industries take advantage of this characteristic by shipping and storing liquefied ammonia in pressurized railway cars, tank trucks and cylinders of various sizes.
It is primarily used as fertilizer. It is also widely used as a refrigerant and in manufacturing nitric acid, explosives, plastics and as a solvent in the chemical laboratory.
Anhydrous ammonia is one of the most water-soluble of all gases, but it should not be confused with aqueous ammonia, which is a 15 to 30 per cent solution of ammonia in water. Generally, ammonia has good warning properties because of its characteristic pungent and irritating odour.
With rising temperature ammonia expands rapidly, increasing the internal pressure in vessels and pipes, etc. This must be considered in the design and operation of ammonia systems.

Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa).
