Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium acetate: Solubility in water 2530 g/l (20 °C) pH value 7.5 - 8.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Potassium acetate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols).Potassium acetate is highly effective as antifreeze. It exerts much lower BOD-effects (Biological Oxygen Demand), and it offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
Antifrogen SOL is based on propylene glycol and higher boiling glycols plus anticorrosion additives. Typical applications: Solar heating systems.

Jet fuel: A kerosene-based product used in jet engines. Flammable liquid, flash point from 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: from 300 °C to 400 °C. Jet Fuel This category comprises both gasoline and kerosene type jet fuels meeting specifications for use in aviation turbine power units. Gasoline type jet fuel This includes all light hydrocarbon oils for use in aviation turbine power units. They distill between 100 °C and 250 °C. It is obtained by blending kerosenes and gasoline or naphthas in such a way that the aromatic content does not exceed 25 per cent in volume, and the vapour pressure is between 13.7 kPa and 20.6 kPa. Additives can be included to improve fuel stability and combustibility. Kerosene type jet fuel This is medium distillate used for aviation turbine power units. It has the same distillation characteristics and flash point as kerosene (between 150 °C and 300 °C C but not generally above 250 °C. In addition, it has particular specifications (such as freezing point) which are established by the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Jet fuel: A kerosene-based product used in jet engines. Flammable liquid, flash point from 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: from 300 °C to 400 °C. Jet Fuel This category comprises both gasoline and kerosene type jet fuels meeting specifications for use in aviation turbine power units. Gasoline type jet fuel This includes all light hydrocarbon oils for use in aviation turbine power units. They distill between 100 °C and 250 °C. It is obtained by blending kerosenes and gasoline or naphthas in such a way that the aromatic content does not exceed 25 per cent in volume, and the vapour pressure is between 13.7 kPa and 20.6 kPa. Additives can be included to improve fuel stability and combustibility. Kerosene type jet fuel This is medium distillate used for aviation turbine power units. It has the same distillation characteristics and flash point as kerosene (between 150 °C and 300 °C C but not generally above 250 °C. In addition, it has particular specifications (such as freezing point) which are established by the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Pyridine or azine C5H5N is a colorless, highly flammable, toxic liquid with a very unpleasant fish-like odour. It is miscible with water and with most organic solvents. Its aqueous solution is slightly alkaline. Melting point: -42 °C. Boiling point: 116 °C. Flash point: 19 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 480 °C. Explosion limits: 1.8 % - 12.4 % Specific gravity: 0.98 kg/m3. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 20 °C. Chemically, it is a heterocyclic aromatic tertiary amine. Its molecule resembles that of benzene, one carbon-hydrogen unit in the benzene ring being replaced with a nitrogen molecule. Pyridine is obtained from bone oil or from coal tar by destructive distillation, which decomposes alkaloids that contain it. Alkaloids that contain pyridine include coniine, piperine (the alkaloid in pepper), and nicotine (present in tobacco); free pyridine is present in tobacco smoke. Use: Pyridine is used as a solvent, as a denaturant for alcohol, in paints, medicine, textile dying and as a starting material in the synthesis of other compounds. Compounds that can be derived from pyridine include antihistamines and vitamins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Pyridine or azine C5H5N is a colorless, highly flammable, toxic liquid with a very unpleasant fish-like odour. It is miscible with water and with most organic solvents. Its aqueous solution is slightly alkaline. Melting point: -42 °C. Boiling point: 116 °C. Flash point: 19 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 480 °C. Explosion limits: 1.8 % - 12.4 % Specific gravity: 0.98 kg/m3. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 20 °C. Chemically, it is a heterocyclic aromatic tertiary amine. Its molecule resembles that of benzene, one carbon-hydrogen unit in the benzene ring being replaced with a nitrogen molecule. Pyridine is obtained from bone oil or from coal tar by destructive distillation, which decomposes alkaloids that contain it. Alkaloids that contain pyridine include coniine, piperine (the alkaloid in pepper), and nicotine (present in tobacco); free pyridine is present in tobacco smoke. Use: Pyridine is used as a solvent, as a denaturant for alcohol, in paints, medicine, textile dying and as a starting material in the synthesis of other compounds. Compounds that can be derived from pyridine include antihistamines and vitamins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Sodium bicarbonate: or sodium hydrogen carbonate, chemical compound, NaHCO3, a white crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as bicarbonate of soda or baking soda. It is soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 95.5 g/l (20 °C). pH value 8.35 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). NaHCO3 evolves carbon dioxide gas when heated above about 50 °C, a property made use of in baking powder, of which it is a component. It is also decomposed by most acids; the acid is neutralised and carbon dioxide is given off. Use: The major use of sodium bicarbonate is in foods, e.g., baked goods. It is used in effervescent "salts" and is sometimes used medically to correct excess stomach acidity. It is also used in several kinds of fire extinguishers.

Sulfuric acid: H2SO4, corrosive, oily, colourless liquid, with a specific gravity of 1.85. Melting point: 10 °C. Boiling point 340 °C. (pH value 1 at 25%, 20 °C) Sulfuric acid is soluble in all proportions in water. When sulfuric acid is mixed with water, considerable heat is released. Unless the mixture is well stirred, the added water may be heated beyond its boiling point and the sudden formation of steam may blow the acid out of its container. Properties: Sulfuric acid is a strong acid, that in aqueous solution is largely changed to hydrogen ions (H+) and sulfate ions (SO4--). Each molecule gives two H+ ions, thus sulfuric acid is dibasic. Dilute solutions of sulfuric acid show all the behavior characteristics of acids. They taste sour, conduct electricity, neutralize alkalies, and corrode active metals with formation of hydrogen gas. Concentrated sulfuric acid, formerly called oil of vitriol, is a valuable desiccating agent. It acts so vigorously in this respect that it removes water from (and therefore chars) wood, cotton, sugar, and paper. It is used in the manufacture of ether, nitroglycerin, and dyes for its property as a desiccant. When concentrated sulfuric acid is heated, it behaves also as an oxidizing agent, capable, for example, of dissolving such relatively unreactive metals as copper, mercury, and lead to produce metal sulfate, sulfur dioxide, and water. Use: The uses of sulfuric acid are so varied that the volume of its production provides an approximate index of general industrial activity. American production of sulfuric acid exceeded 29 million tons annually in the early 1970s, a figure corresponding to a daily production of 1/3 kg (3/4 lb) per person throughout the year. The largest single use of sulfuric acid is for making fertilizers, both superphosphate and ammonium sulfate. It is also used in making organic products, refining petroleum, making paints and pigments, processing metals, and making rayon. One of the few consumer products containing sulfuric acid as such is the lead storage battery, or car energizer.
rdf:Description.prefLabel: Battery acid, Oil of vitriol (Sulfuric acid)

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sugar syrup: Other Names: Liquid sugar, sugar, beet sugar, cane sugar, sucrose. Formula: C12H22O11 Specific gravity: 1.1 to 1.5. Viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature. E.g 50 Brix* syrup has a viscosity of about 15 cP (21 °C). 68 Brix syrup (21 °C) has a viscosity of about 240 cP, while 76 Brix sugar (21 °C) has a viscosity of 1300 cP. Remarks: The term sugar syrup or syrup is a very broad one and is applied very generally to a number of sweet tasting carbohydrates. Use: Sugar syrups are used in food, for sweetening, in candy, preserves and jams, in making soap, pharmaceuticals, caramel, as a chemical intermediate for detergents, as an emulsifying agent in such things as plasticisers, resins, explosives, glues and insecticides. * BRIX is the measurement in percentage by weight of sucrose in pure water solution. This designation of BRIX degrees is only valid for pure sucrose solutions. Pure sucrose is extract from sugar-cane or sugar-beet.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Benzene: Clear, colourless, highly flammable, toxic liquid with a pleasant aromatic odor. Specific gravity: 0.870 . Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 74,6 mm. Melting point: 6 °C. Flash point: -11 °C. Boiling point: 80 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 561 °C. Viscosity: 0.65 cP at 20 °C. Benzene is miscible with alcohol, acetone, carbon tetrachloride; slightly soluble in water. Benzene is extremely flammable; the vapor is harmful; the liquid is poisonous and a known carcinogen. Among the important derivatives of benzene are phenol, aniline, and picric acid. Benzene and the other aromatic hydrocarbons are obtained for industrial purposes from the distillation of coal tar, a byproduct in the manufacture of coke, and from petroleum by special reforming methods. Use: Benzene is used in making styrene, synthetic detergents, insecticides, fumigants, drugs, dyes and solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.

Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.

Benzene: Clear, colourless, highly flammable, toxic liquid with a pleasant aromatic odor. Specific gravity: 0.870 . Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 74,6 mm. Melting point: 6 °C. Flash point: -11 °C. Boiling point: 80 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 561 °C. Viscosity: 0.65 cP at 20 °C. Benzene is miscible with alcohol, acetone, carbon tetrachloride; slightly soluble in water. Benzene is extremely flammable; the vapor is harmful; the liquid is poisonous and a known carcinogen. Among the important derivatives of benzene are phenol, aniline, and picric acid. Benzene and the other aromatic hydrocarbons are obtained for industrial purposes from the distillation of coal tar, a byproduct in the manufacture of coke, and from petroleum by special reforming methods. Use: Benzene is used in making styrene, synthetic detergents, insecticides, fumigants, drugs, dyes and solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Melting point: 250 °C. Solubility in water 710g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 6.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (26%, 20 °C): 1.2. Viscosity (26%, 20 °C): 2.4 cSt. It was first prepared from the waters of mineral springs at Epsom, England; it also occurs as the mineral epsomite. Use: Magnesium sulfate is used medicinally as a purgative, it is also used in leather tanning, mordant dyeing, fertilizers, explosives and as a filler in cotton goods and paper.

Sodium hypochlorite: NaClO is a pale greenish liquid with chlorine odour. Also known as soda bleach or liquid bleach. Household bleaches normally contain about 5% sodium hypochlorite (about pH11), and more concentrated bleaches contain 10-15% sodium hypochlorite (about pH13).Commercial sodium hypochlorites are normally stabilised with sodium hydroxide. Sodium hypochlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as chlorine (a toxic gas) will be liberated. Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 40 °C (decomposes). Specific gravity: 1.21. pH value: 6 to 9. Use: sodium hypochlorite is used for a wide range of applications where its powerful disinfection and oxidation properties are utilised. The main application areas include: Bleaching; Formulated Disinfectants; Potable and Waste Water Treatment; Swimming Pool Water Treatment; Process and Cooling Water Treatment; Odour Control; Chemical Intermediates; etc. Sodium hypochlorite is aggressive to many metals and elastomers. Javelle water: aqueous solution of sodium or potassium hypochlorite. It was originally made near the French town of Javelle (now part of Paris) and was the first chemical bleach, a use first demonstrated by C. L. Berthollet in 1785. It was produced by passing chlorine gas through a water solution of potash (potassium carbonate). After the invention of bleaching powder Javelle water was sometimes produced by reacting the bleaching powder with potash or soda ash (sodium carbonate).

Appearance: blue to blue-green crystals. Nickel sulfate is odorless.
Nickel sulfate is very soluble in water (about 75%). It forms a solution with a pH about 4.5
Nickel sulfate is used in electroplating, organic chemical synthesis, metal colouring, dye mordant, manufacturing other nickel salts, Ni-Cd battery.

Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Boiler water: "Boiler water" is the term used to specifically refer to the water which is heated inside the boiler. It is that water which is provided by the boiler feedwater and withdrawn from the boiler as either heated water or steam. Aside from the BFW treatment, corrosion of boiler water systems is further controlled by proper boiler operation and in some cases by "internal" treatments with chemical additives which adjust pH and control solids precipitation and sludge formation. The chemicals are fed either to the boiler feedwater or to the boiler drum.
Boiler feedwater ("BFW") may either be the same as the makeup water, or may consist of returned steam condensate, or (as in most cases) will be a mixture of both. The relative amounts of makeup and condensate may vary. A typical figure is 5% makeup with 95% condensate, but this depends on how the steam plant is operated and how much of the steam is condensed and recovered for recirculation. In order to be non-scaling, the BFW must be a softened or demineralised water. In order to be non-corrosive to the carbon-steel or low-alloy steel components from which boilers are normally constructed, the water must be thoroughly deaerated. This is partially achieved by thermomechanical means (use of deaeration heating tanks), while the last traces of dissolved oxygen are removed by chemical agents ("oxygen scavengers").

Brackish water: Water containing too much salt (chloride) to be useful to people but less salt than ocean water. Generally, water containing dissolved minerals in amounts that exceed normally acceptable standards for municipal, domestic, and irrigation uses. Considerably less saline than sea water. Water containing between 1,000-4,000 parts per million (PPM) Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). Notes: Due to the high chloride content brackish water is corrosive.

Brackish water: Water containing too much salt (chloride) to be useful to people but less salt than ocean water. Generally, water containing dissolved minerals in amounts that exceed normally acceptable standards for municipal, domestic, and irrigation uses. Considerably less saline than sea water. Water containing between 1,000-4,000 parts per million (PPM) Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). Notes: Due to the high chloride content brackish water is corrosive.

Brackish water: Water containing too much salt (chloride) to be useful to people but less salt than ocean water. Generally, water containing dissolved minerals in amounts that exceed normally acceptable standards for municipal, domestic, and irrigation uses. Considerably less saline than sea water. Water containing between 1,000-4,000 parts per million (PPM) Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). Notes: Due to the high chloride content brackish water is corrosive.

Calcium chloride: CaCl2, chemical compound that is crystalline, lumpy, or flaky, is normally white, and is very soluble in water (400 g/l (20 °C). The water solution is normally neutral or slightly on the alkaline side. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.3. Viscosity: Water-thin The anhydrous compound is hygroscopic; it rapidly absorbs water and is used to dry gases by passing them through it. Use: to melt ice on roads, to control dust, in brines for refrigeration, and as a preservative in foods. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.

Potassium acetate: Solubility in water 2530 g/l (20 °C) pH value 7.5 - 8.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Potassium acetate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols).Potassium acetate is highly effective as antifreeze. It exerts much lower BOD-effects (Biological Oxygen Demand), and it offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Seawater: Most of the elements that can be found on earth are present in seawater, at least in trace amounts. However, eleven of the constituents alone account for 99.95% of the total solutes, chloride ions being by far the largest constituent. The concentration of dissolved materials in the sea varies greatly with location and time because seawater is diluted by rivers, rain, or melting ice, or is concentrated by evaporation. Salinity of Ocean/Sea waters The Practical Salinity Scale defines salinity in terms of the conductivity ratio of a sample to that of a solution of 32.4356 g of KCl at 15 °C in a 1 kg solution. A sample of seawater at 15 °C with a conductivity equal to this KCl solution has a salinity of exactly 35 practical salinity units (psu). Baltic Sea: about 5 to 15 psu. Black Sea: less than 20 psu. Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean: from 33 to 37 psu. Mediterranean: about 40 psu. Dead Sea: about 300-400 psu. Conversion of salinity to chloride: Chloride (ppm) = (Salinity x 1000) / 1.8 Use: Seawater systems are used by many industries such as shipping, offshore oil and gas production, power plants and coastal industrial plants. The main use of seawater is for cooling purposes but it is also used for fire fighting, oil field water injection and for desalination plants.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: LPG is a colourless, odourless gas. Normally LPG is odorised by adding an odorant prior to supply to the user, to aid the detection of any leaks). LPG is Flammable. LPG is heavier than air and has approximately half the weight of water. LPG is non-toxic but can cause suffocation. LPG expands upon release and 1 litre of liquid will form approximately 250 litres of vapour. LPG consists of propane (C3H8), butane (C4H10), or propane-butane mixtures derived from crude oil refining or natural gas fractionation. For convenience of transportation, these gases are liquefied through pressurization. Propane vaporises, changing from a liquid to a vapour when released to the atmosphere at a temperature above -42 °C and butane at 0 °C. Propane: Boiling point: -42 °C Flash point: -100 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 8.5 bar. Butane Boiling point: -1 °C. Flash point: -60 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 2.8 bar. Use: LPG is used as a fuel for domestic, industrial, agricultural, cooking, heating and drying processes. LPG can be used as an automotive fuel or as a propellant for aerosols, in addition to other specialist applications. Hazards in using liquefied petroleum gas? LPG is a flammable gas, which has the potential to create a hazard. Therefore it is important that the properties and safe handling of LPG are understood and applied in the domestic and commercial/industrial situations. Liquefied petroleum gas is stored under pressure. The gas will leak from any joint or connection, which is not sealed properly. Liquefied petroleum gas is heavier than air. Any significant leak will move downwards and stay on the ground. LPG will accumulate in any low-lying area such as depressions in the ground, drains or pits. Since LPG is stored in two phases, liquid and gaseous, there is potential for either a liquid leak or a gas leak. If the Liquefied petroleum gas leak is a gas leak it may not be seen (because LPG is colourless), except where the leak is of sufficient size to be seen shimmering in the air. When a liquid Liquefied petroleum gas leak occurs, the gas release will be seen as a patch of ice around the area of the leak, or as a jet of white liquid. This white appearance is due to the cooling effect created by the rapid expansion of the LPG liquid into a gas. The condensing atmospheric moisture makes the leak visible. In concentrated amounts and in uncontrolled conditions, liquefied petroleum gas has the potential to create a fire or an explosion.

Zinc chloride: White, odourless granules. Very soluble in water. Melting Point: 293 °C. Specific Gravity: 2.9. Solubility in water 3680 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Galvanizing fluxes; soldering fluxes; electroplating; batteries uses; wood preservative; dehydrating and condensing agent in organic synthesis; burnishing and polishing compounds for steels; antiseptic and deodorant preparations; textiles; adhesives; dental cements; glass etching; petroleum refining; parchment; dentifrices; embalming and taxidermists fluids; medicine; dyestuff; pigments; antistatic.

Butyl acetate or n-Butyl acetate is a colorless, flammable liquid that has a pleasant, fruity odor (rather like pears), and it is used in the flavoring/fragrance industry as an artificial flavoring. pH value: neutral. Specific gravity: 0.880. Melting point: -77 °C. Boiling point: 127 °C (1013 hPa). Flash point physical: 22 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 420 °C. Viscosity: 0.73 cP at 20 °C. Slightly soluble in water (7 g/l at 20 °C). Use: Butyl acetate is often used in organic chemistry laboratories as a solvent. Industrially, n-butyl acetate is used in the manufacture of lacquers, artificial leather, photographic films, plastics, and safety glass. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Butyl alcohol or n-Butyl alcohol is a colourless, highly flammable liquid liquid with a strong, characteristic, mildly alcoholic odour. One of the four organic compounds having the same molecular formula, C4H9OH, but different structures: normal (n-) butyl alcohol, secondary butyl alcohol, isobutyl alcohol, and tertiary butyl alcohol. Slightly soluble in water: 79 g/l (20 °C), neutral pH. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. Flash point: 35 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 343 °C. Specific gravity: 0.810. Viscosity: 2.95 cP at 20 °C. Explosion limits: 1.4 % - 11.2 % Commercial n-butyl alcohol is made by fermentation of corn or molasses or from acetaldehyde by a series of reactions. Use: All have numerous industrial applications. n-Butyl alcohol is a solvent for lacquers, resins, and other coatings and a component of hydraulic brake fluids. Large quantities are converted to esters: the acetate is a lacquer solvent; the phthalate, a plasticizer. Secondary butyl alcohol is used mostly in the manufacture of methyl ethyl ketone, a useful solvent. Isobutyl alcohol is interchangeable in many uses with n-butyl alcohol and has been cheaper since large-scale production began in the early 1950s. Tertiary butyl alcohol is the least important; it is used in making fine chemicals and as a denaturing agent for ethyl alcohol. Any of four isomeric alcohols, C4H9OH, widely used as solvents and in organic synthesis. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Calcium hypochlorite: White powder with a chlorine-like odour. Normally a mixture of calcium chloride hypochlorite, CaCl(OCl); calcium hypochlorite, Ca(OCl)2; and calcium chloride, CaCl2. Calcium hypochlorite is a strong oxidiser. Solubility (wt.% in water): 217 g/l at 27 °C. Specific gravity 2.350. Sometimes called chloride of lime, it can be prepared by reacting calcium hydroxide or slaked lime, Ca(OH)2, with chlorine gas, Cl2. It is used as a strong bleaching agent, as a general disinfectant to destroy bacteria, algae, slime, fungi and other microorganisms and in making Javelle water (see Sodium hypochlorite). Use: Calcium hypochlorite is used primarily to chlorinate swimming pools, and to disinfect drinking water supplies and sewage systems. It is also used as a sanitizer in a number of food processings, commercial, institutional, and domestic applications. Bleaching powder was first produced in 1799 by Charles Tennant in Glasgow, Scotland.

Calcium acetate: White crystals or powder with slight acetic acid odour. Melting point 230 °C. Decomposes to form acetone, calcium carbonate. Solubility in water 300g/l (0 °C). pH value 7.2 - 8.2 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Used as deicer, in lubricants, as food stabilizer and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Calcium chloride: CaCl2, chemical compound that is crystalline, lumpy, or flaky, is normally white, and is very soluble in water (400 g/l (20 °C). The water solution is normally neutral or slightly on the alkaline side. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.3. Viscosity: Water-thin The anhydrous compound is hygroscopic; it rapidly absorbs water and is used to dry gases by passing them through it. Use: to melt ice on roads, to control dust, in brines for refrigeration, and as a preservative in foods. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.

Calcium chloride: CaCl2, chemical compound that is crystalline, lumpy, or flaky, is normally white, and is very soluble in water (400 g/l (20 °C). The water solution is normally neutral or slightly on the alkaline side. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.3. Viscosity: Water-thin The anhydrous compound is hygroscopic; it rapidly absorbs water and is used to dry gases by passing them through it. Use: to melt ice on roads, to control dust, in brines for refrigeration, and as a preservative in foods. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Calcium hypochlorite: White powder with a chlorine-like odour. Normally a mixture of calcium chloride hypochlorite, CaCl(OCl); calcium hypochlorite, Ca(OCl)2; and calcium chloride, CaCl2. Calcium hypochlorite is a strong oxidiser. Solubility (wt.% in water): 217 g/l at 27 °C. Specific gravity 2.350. Sometimes called chloride of lime, it can be prepared by reacting calcium hydroxide or slaked lime, Ca(OH)2, with chlorine gas, Cl2. It is used as a strong bleaching agent, as a general disinfectant to destroy bacteria, algae, slime, fungi and other microorganisms and in making Javelle water (see Sodium hypochlorite). Use: Calcium hypochlorite is used primarily to chlorinate swimming pools, and to disinfect drinking water supplies and sewage systems. It is also used as a sanitizer in a number of food processings, commercial, institutional, and domestic applications. Bleaching powder was first produced in 1799 by Charles Tennant in Glasgow, Scotland.

Sugar syrup: Other Names: Liquid sugar, sugar, beet sugar, cane sugar, sucrose. Formula: C12H22O11 Specific gravity: 1.1 to 1.5. Viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature. E.g 50 Brix* syrup has a viscosity of about 15 cP (21 °C). 68 Brix syrup (21 °C) has a viscosity of about 240 cP, while 76 Brix sugar (21 °C) has a viscosity of 1300 cP. Remarks: The term sugar syrup or syrup is a very broad one and is applied very generally to a number of sweet tasting carbohydrates. Use: Sugar syrups are used in food, for sweetening, in candy, preserves and jams, in making soap, pharmaceuticals, caramel, as a chemical intermediate for detergents, as an emulsifying agent in such things as plasticisers, resins, explosives, glues and insecticides. * BRIX is the measurement in percentage by weight of sucrose in pure water solution. This designation of BRIX degrees is only valid for pure sucrose solutions. Pure sucrose is extract from sugar-cane or sugar-beet.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Appearance: white crystalline with a slight ammonia-like odor. Melting point: decomposes at 133 °C. Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.03 (15 %w/w), 1.15 (50% w/w). Viscosity at 20 °C: 1.6 cSt (50% w/w). Water solubility: 1080g/l at 20 °C. pH: 7.2 (10% solution). Use: Urea is widely used in the agricultural industry as an animal feed additive and fertilizer.

Phenol (C6H5OH) is a colorless, combustible, crystalline solid with a characteristic odor. Liquid water and phenol show limited miscibility below 70 °C. It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phenol is a poisonous and hazardous liquid; rapidly absorbed through the skin, causing severe burns. It is an aromatic alcohol that exhibits weak acidic properties and is corrosive and poisonous.
Melting point: about 41 °C. Boiling point: 182 °C (conc.) Flash point: 79 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 715 °C. Explosion limits: 1.5 % - 8.6 % pH of phenol water mixtures are slightly acidic (around 5-6) Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.06 (80%) and 1.07 (conc.) Viscosity at 45 °C: 3.8 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 60 °C: 2.5 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 80 °C: 1.6 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 100 °C: 1.1 cSt. (conc.)
The main use of phenol is as a feedstock for phenolic resins, bisphenol A and caprolactam (an intermediate in the production of nylon-6). It is used in the manufacture of many products including insulation materials, adhesives, lacquers, paint, rubber, ink and dyes. It is found in some commercial disinfectants, antiseptics and lotions.
The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.
Carbonic acid (H2CO3) is formed when CO2, a colourless odourless gas is dissolved in water.

Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.

Appearance: pale yellow viscous liquid.
Melting point: -10 °C. Boiling point: 313 °C. Flash point: about 235 °C. Specific gravity: 0.96. Viscosity: 44 cPs. to 660 cPs. Auto ignition temperature: about 450 °C. Water solubility: negligible.
Castor Oil is a triglyceride (ester) of fatty acid extracted from plants. It has the advantage over other mineral oils that it is a renewable resource. Castor oil is bio-degradable and eco-friendly. Many derivatives can be produced which have a similar chemical composition to petroleum based oils.
There are many uses for castor oil and its derivatives. Some of these include: lubricants, greases and hydraulic fluids, plastics, textiles and textile finishing materials, paints and varnishes, cosmetics and hair oils, inks, adhesives, synthetic resins, fibres, plasticizers, fungi static (fungus-growth-inhibiting) compounds and soaps.

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Potassium hydroxide: Chemical compound with the formula KOH. Pure potassium hydroxide forms white, deliquescent crystals. Solubility in water 1100 g/l (20 °C). pH value >13.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). pH value 12 (0.05% aqueous solution) and 14 (5% solution). Specific gravity 1.2 (20% aqueous solution) and 1500 kg/m3 (50% aqueous solution).
For commercial and laboratory use it is normally in the form of white pellets. A strong base, it dissolves readily in water, giving off much heat and forming a strongly alkaline caustic solution. It is commonly called caustic potash. It closely resembles sodium hydroxide in its chemical properties and has similar uses, e.g., in making soap, in bleaching, and in manufacturing chemicals, but is less widely used because of its higher cost. It is prepared chiefly by electrolysis of potassium chloride. Commercial grades of potassium hydroxide sometimes contain the chloride as well as other impurities.

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

2-Ethoxyethanol, also known by the trademark Cellosolve or ethyl cellosolve , is a solvent used widely in commercial and Ethylene glycol monoethylether 2-ethoxy-ethanol Formula: HOCH3CH2OCH2CH3 industrial applications. It is a clear, colorless, nearly odorless liquid that is miscible with water, ethanol, diethyl ether, acetone, and ethyl acetate. As with other glycol ethers, 2-ethoxyethanol has the useful property of being able to dissolve chemically diverse compounds. It will dissolve oils, resins, grease, waxes, nitrocellulose, and lacquers. This is an ideal property as a multi-purpose cleaner, and, therefore, 2-ethoxyethanol is used in products, such as varnish removers and degreasing solutions. Boiling point: 135 °C Flash point: 42 °C Viscosity: 2.50 mPs at 20 °C Density: 0.960 g/mL at 20 °C Water miscible. Combustible.

Stearic acid: A colourless, odorless, waxlike saturated fatty acid, CH3(CH2)16COOH, almost insoluble in water (less than 0.1%).
Melting point: 69 °C. Boiling point: 383 °C. Flash point: 196 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 395 °C. Specific gravity 0.87
Stearic acid is also called octedacanoic acid, and it is one of the most common long-chain fatty acids, found in combined form in natural animal and vegetable fats. Commercial "stearic acid" is a mixture of approximately equal amounts of stearic and palmitic acids and small amounts of oleic acid. It is employed in the manufacture of candles, cosmetics, shaving soaps, lubricants, and pharmaceuticals.
In nature stearic acid occurs primarily as a mixed triglyceride, or fat, with other long-chain acids and as an ester of a fatty alcohol. It is much more abundant in animal fat than in vegetable fat; lard and tallow often contain up to 30 percent stearic acid.
Alkaline hydrolysis, or saponification, of fats yields soaps, which are the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Pure stearic acid is obtained with difficulty from such a mixture by crystallization, vacuum distillation, or chromatography of the acids or suitable derivatives. The pure acid undergoes chemical reactions typical of carboxylic acids.

Palmitic acid: Appearance: white chips, crystals or powder. Odor: Slight characteristic odor. Insoluble in water. Melting point: 61 °C - 64 °C Boiling point: 352 °C. Specific gravity: 0.840. Viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.
Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and a major component of solid fats. It is found in palm oil and many animal fats (milk or butterfat is 21 percent palmitic acid). Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. As an additive, palmitic acid is used in the manufacture of soap and to enhance the flavor of butter and cheese spreads.
rdf:Description.viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium nitrate: chemical compound, NaNO3, a colourless, odorless crystalline compound that closely resembles potassium nitrate (saltpeter or niter) in appearance and chemical properties. It is soluble in water, alcohol, and liquid ammonia. Solubility in water 880 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 7.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrate is also called soda niter or Chile saltpeter. It is found naturally in large deposits in arid regions of Chile, Peru, Argentina, and Bolivia as caliche, a crude, impure nitrate rock or gravel. Use: sodium nitrate is used in making potassium nitrate, fertilizers, and explosives. It was formerly an important raw material for the production of nitric acid.

Chlorine is a disinfectant added to water to reduce or eliminate microorganisms, such as bacteria and viruses, which can be present in water. The different forms of chlorine used for water treatment are gaseous chlorine, sodium hypochlorite solution and calcium hypochlorite. When chlorine is introduced into water, it dissociates into two parts, - Hypochlorous Acid (HOCl), which is the strong, fast, oxidizing disinfectant, and the Hypochlorite Ion (OCl-), which is a very slow, weak disinfectant. The ratio of HOCL to OCl- is determined by the pH value of the water (Cl2 will only be present in the water at very low pH). HOCl is 100 times more powerful an oxidant/disinfectant than is the hypochlorite ion. Consequently, disinfection is most effective at pH 5 to 7 where HOCl is the predominant form. Free Chlorine Free chlorine is defined as the concentration of residual chlorine in water present as dissolved gas (Cl2), hypochlorous acid (HOCl), and/or hypochlorite ion (OCl-). The three forms of free chlorine exist together in equilibrium. Combined Chlorine Combined chlorine is defined as the residual chlorine existing in water in chemical combination with ammonia or organic amines which can be found in natural or polluted bwaters. Total Chlorine Total chlorine is the sum of free and combined chlorine. Typical values: Bottled water, drinking water, swimming pool, spa-water purification: higher than 0.1-0.2 ppm and lower than 2-3 ppm.Sanitation (CIP): 20-300 ppm. Use: Process water disinfection for the food industry, potable water disinfection, CIP sanitization, pasteuriser sanitization, vegetable washing, odour control scrubbers, sulfide oxidation, manganese and iron oxidation.

Chlorine dioxide, ClO2 is a gas at ordinary temperatures. However ClO22 is soluble in an aqueous solution (solubility about 4 g/l). Typical values: drinking water: less than 1 ppm Sanitation (CIP) : 1-10 ppm. Chlorine dioxide's oxidizing and disinfecting properties remain constant over the wide pH range of 4 to 10. This is different than the active forms of chlorine, which is strongly affected by the pH. Another advantage of using chlorine dioxide is that it does not directly form halogenated byproducts when used, as is the case with the use of chlorine. Because of its unstable nature, chlorine dioxide is always generated at the point of use. The average concentration of chlorine dioxide in these generators is about 1000-3000 mg/L. Chlorine dioxide is used extensively as a bleaching agent in the pulp and paper industry. In fact, in order to minimize the environmental effects of the bleaching process, ClO2 is rapidly becoming the chemical of choice. Chlorine dioxide is also being used as a disinfectant agent in the food industry for fruit and vegetable washing, flume water disinfection, meat and poultry disinfection, food process equipment sanitizing water and for odor control. In industrial processes, ClO2 is used in industrial water treatment (cooling systems/towers), ammonia plants, pulp mills (slime control, paper machines), oil fields, scrubbing systems/odor control, textile bleaching and the electronic industry. Chlorine dioxide is also being applied to medical wastes.

Chlorine dioxide, ClO2 is a gas at ordinary temperatures. However ClO22 is soluble in an aqueous solution (solubility about 4 g/l). Typical values: drinking water: less than 1 ppm Sanitation (CIP) : 1-10 ppm. Chlorine dioxide's oxidizing and disinfecting properties remain constant over the wide pH range of 4 to 10. This is different than the active forms of chlorine, which is strongly affected by the pH. Another advantage of using chlorine dioxide is that it does not directly form halogenated byproducts when used, as is the case with the use of chlorine. Because of its unstable nature, chlorine dioxide is always generated at the point of use. The average concentration of chlorine dioxide in these generators is about 1000-3000 mg/L. Chlorine dioxide is used extensively as a bleaching agent in the pulp and paper industry. In fact, in order to minimize the environmental effects of the bleaching process, ClO2 is rapidly becoming the chemical of choice. Chlorine dioxide is also being used as a disinfectant agent in the food industry for fruit and vegetable washing, flume water disinfection, meat and poultry disinfection, food process equipment sanitizing water and for odor control. In industrial processes, ClO2 is used in industrial water treatment (cooling systems/towers), ammonia plants, pulp mills (slime control, paper machines), oil fields, scrubbing systems/odor control, textile bleaching and the electronic industry. Chlorine dioxide is also being applied to medical wastes.
