Typical values: drinking water: less than 1 ppm Sanitation (CIP) : 1-10 ppm. Chlorine dioxide's oxidizing and disinfecting properties remain constant over the wide pH range of 4 to 10. This is different than the active forms of chlorine, which is strongly affected by the pH. Another advantage of using chlorine dioxide is that it does not directly form halogenated byproducts when used, as is the case with the use of chlorine. Because of its unstable nature, chlorine dioxide is always generated at the point of use. The average concentration of chlorine dioxide in these generators is about 1000-3000 mg/L. Chlorine dioxide is used extensively as a bleaching agent in the pulp and paper industry. In fact, in order to minimize the environmental effects of the bleaching process, ClO2 is rapidly becoming the chemical of choice. Chlorine dioxide is also being used as a disinfectant agent in the food industry for fruit and vegetable washing, flume water disinfection, meat and poultry disinfection, food process equipment sanitizing water and for odor control. In industrial processes, ClO2 is used in industrial water treatment (cooling systems/towers), ammonia plants, pulp mills (slime control, paper machines), oil fields, scrubbing systems/odor control, textile bleaching and the electronic industry. Chlorine dioxide is also being applied to medical wastes.

Chloroform: or trichloromethane, CHCl3, is a volatile, colourless, nonflammable liquid that has a sweetish taste and a somewhat pungent odor.
Melting point: -63 °C. Boiling point: 61 °C. Vapour pressure: 159 mm Hg at 20 °C. Flash point: none. Specific gravity: 1.48. Viscosity 0.38 cSt at 20 °C and 0.35 cSt. at 60 °C.
It dissolves freely in ethanol and ether but is almost insoluble in water. It was once used as a general anesthetic in surgery but has been replaced by less toxic, safer anesthetics, such as ether. Chemically, it is employed as a solvent for fats, alkaloids, iodine, and other substances.
When exposed to sunlight and air it reacts to form phosgene, a poisonous gas.

Hydrochloric acid: HCl, a colourless, poisonous gas with an unpleasant, acrid odor. It is very soluble in water and readily soluble in alcohol and ether. It fumes in moist air. It is not flammable, and the liquid is a poor conductor of electricity. Hydrochloric acid is prepared commercially by the reaction of sulfuric acid with sodium chloride (common salt); niter cake, a mixture of sodium bisulfite and sulfuric acid that is a byproduct of nitric acid manufacture, is sometimes used in place of sulfuric acid. Hydrochloric acid is also produced as a byproduct of the manufacture of chlorinated organic chemicals. It can be prepared directly by reaction of hydrogen and chlorine gases; the reaction is very exothermic and takes place readily in sunlight or at elevated temperatures. Although anhydrous (water-free) hydrochloric acid is commercially available as a high-pressure compressed gas in steel cylinders, most of the gas produced is dissolved in water to form hydrochloric acid, a commercially important chemical. Pure grades of hydrochloric acid are colourless, but technical grades, commonly called muriatic acid, are often yellow-coloured because of impurities such as dissolved metals. Most hydrochloric acid produced has a concentration of 30% to 35% hydrogen chloride by weight. Use: The major use of hydrochloric acid is in the manufacture of other chemicals. It is also used in large amounts in pickling (cleaning) metal surfaces, e.g., iron before galvanizing. It reacts with most common metals, releasing hydrogen and forming the metal chloride; with most metal oxides and hydroxides it reacts to form water and the metal chloride. Hydrochloric acid is also used in small amounts in processing glucose and other foods and for various other uses. Concentrated solutions are strong acids and highly corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is not an oxidizing agent but can be oxidized by very strong oxidizing agents, liberating chlorine gas. In dilute solutions of the acid the hydrogen chloride is almost completely dissociated into hydrogen and chloride ions.

Chromic acid: occurring only as salt (CrO3, dark-red, odourless flakes or powder), or in solution as H2CrO4, a corrosive, oxidizing acid. Solubility in water 63% at 20 °C. pH value 0.2 - 2 depending on concentration. Use: Chromic acid is used in the preparation of wood preservatives, metal plating, magnetic tapes and catalyst production. Chromic acid is used extensively in formulating wood preservatives. The chromate salts act as a fixative, bonding other protective chemicals to the wood.Chromic acid serves as the source of chromium metal for plating chromium on all common metals and plastics. Chromium plating is of two types: decorative plating, normally over deposits of copper and/or nickel, and hard chromium plating, applied directly to cast iron, steel, aluminum and other metals. Decorative plating is used on automobile trim and other consumer products, such as toasters, major appliances, and plumbing fixtures.

Chromic acid: occurring only as salt (CrO3, dark-red, odourless flakes or powder), or in solution as H2CrO4, a corrosive, oxidizing acid. Solubility in water 63% at 20 °C. pH value 0.2 - 2 depending on concentration. Use: Chromic acid is used in the preparation of wood preservatives, metal plating, magnetic tapes and catalyst production. Chromic acid is used extensively in formulating wood preservatives. The chromate salts act as a fixative, bonding other protective chemicals to the wood.Chromic acid serves as the source of chromium metal for plating chromium on all common metals and plastics. Chromium plating is of two types: decorative plating, normally over deposits of copper and/or nickel, and hard chromium plating, applied directly to cast iron, steel, aluminum and other metals. Decorative plating is used on automobile trim and other consumer products, such as toasters, major appliances, and plumbing fixtures.

Chromic acid: occurring only as salt (CrO3, dark-red, odourless flakes or powder), or in solution as H2CrO4, a corrosive, oxidizing acid. Solubility in water 63% at 20 °C. pH value 0.2 - 2 depending on concentration. Use: Chromic acid is used in the preparation of wood preservatives, metal plating, magnetic tapes and catalyst production. Chromic acid is used extensively in formulating wood preservatives. The chromate salts act as a fixative, bonding other protective chemicals to the wood.Chromic acid serves as the source of chromium metal for plating chromium on all common metals and plastics. Chromium plating is of two types: decorative plating, normally over deposits of copper and/or nickel, and hard chromium plating, applied directly to cast iron, steel, aluminum and other metals. Decorative plating is used on automobile trim and other consumer products, such as toasters, major appliances, and plumbing fixtures.

Cider: in Europe, fermented juice of apples; in the United States, unfermented apple juice, unless allowed to ferment, in which case it is known as hard cider. Selected apples are grated in a mill, and the juice is expressed and, for hard cider, fermented and filtered. The commercial product is normally pasteurized or treated with preservatives and is frequently blended to balance the main constituents, sugar, malic acid, and tannin.
The pH of apple cider is typically between 3.6 and 4.0.
In France cider is made principally in Normandy and Brittany. It is at its best after a year or two in cask. English cider from the southern and western counties is noted and rivals beer as a popular alcoholic beverage. Cider is popular also in Germany, Spain, and Switzerland. Perry is a similar beverage made from pears.

CIP cleaning: Clean in Place is the process used to ensure that process lines, vessels and reactors are free of inorganic and organic contaminants. Clean in Place technology involves the use of chemicals, high pressure pumps, spray nozzles and spray balls and aseptic design principles to ensure that large scale processes are appropriately free of dirt, organic contaminants and microorganisms.
Automation is another essential element of the modern CIP process. There are a number of steps involved in a full cleaning and sterilizing CIP process: Draining, rinsing, cleaning, sanitizing wash, final rinse.
In the first stage it is important that the process equipment must as much as possible be drained of fluids and solids.
In the next stage, water is used as a primary wash to clean away the more easily removed particles.
Following this is the cleaning stage. Most cleaning agents are based around a sodium hydroxide/surfactant mixture. The mixture is dissolved in water to prepare typically a 1-3% w/v solution and heated to 50 °C-80 °C. The solution is circulated through the system for approximately 15-20 minutes. The caustic solution is then drained from the system. Contrary to popular belief, the caustic wash is not a sterilizing process. Spores and hardy microorganisms are able to survive the caustic wash.
Disinfection/sterilization requires the use of a sanitizing wash. Before the sanitizing wash can proceed, it is necessary to remove most of the alkalinity from the system. This is because many sanitizing solutions do not function well under alkaline conditions. Washing with water alone is inefficient and can lead to significant wastage. Dilute solutions of citric acid or nitric acid can be used to assist in removing the alkalinity. These solutions will also assist in removing inorganic scale from the system.
A variety of chemicals are available for the sanitizing wash. These include chlorine compounds, quaternary amines, hydrogen peroxide based formulations. The use of chlorine based compounds such as chlorine dioxide and chlorine is limited by their corrosiveness to stainless steels. If not removed properly from the system they can cause the formation of organochlorides. Quaternary amines can be used. The wastewater from quaternary amine washes are however difficult to treat by biological methods. Hydrogen peroxide formulations have considerable potential as a general use sanitizing agent.
The sanitizing wash is followed by a final step in the CIP process which is a sterile water wash. The water should be deionized so as to prevent the formation of inorganic scale on the walls.

Maleic acid, or cis-butenedioic acid, is a geometric isomer of fumaric acid. Appearance: White crystals, faint acidulous odor. Specific gravity: 1.59. pH: less than 7 acidic. White crystals, dissolves readily in water and alcohol . Solubility in water 79 g/100g (25 °C). Melting point 139 °C-140 °C. At higher temperatures it forms the anhydride, which, like the acid, is irritating to the skin and toxic.
Maleic acid is a stronger organic acid, also called Cis-butenedioic Acid (HO2CCH=CHCO2H). It is an unsaturated organic dibasic acid, that is used in making polyesters for fibre-reinforced laminated moldings, paint for vehicles, and in the manufacture of fumaric acid and many other chemical products.
Maleic Acid is used in the production of insecticide (e.g. Malathion), medicine, synthetic resin and other chemicals, such as tartaric acid and malic acid. Maleic acid is also used as a mordant in dyeing.Maleic anhydride is interchangeable with the acid in most applications.

Citric acid: or 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboxylic acid, HO2CCH2C(OH)(CO2H)CH2CO2H, an organic carboxylic acid containing three carboxyl groups; it is a solid at room temperature, melts at 153 °C, and decomposes at higher temperatures. Solubility in water 1630 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is responsible for the tart taste of various fruits in which it occurs, e.g., lemons, limes, oranges, pineapples, and gooseberries. It can be extracted from the juice of citrus fruits by adding calcium oxide (lime) to form calcium citrate, an insoluble precipitate that can be collected by filtration; the citric acid can be recovered from its calcium salt by adding sulfuric acid. It is obtained also by fermentation of glucose with the aid of the mold Aspergillus niger and can be obtained synthetically from acetone or glycerol. Use: Citric acid is used in soft drinks and in laxatives and cathartics. Its salts, the citrates, have many uses, e.g., ferric ammonium citrate is used in making blueprint paper. Sour salt, used in cooking, is citric acid.

Acid cleaning: Used in cleaning operations to remove encrusted surface matter and mineral scale found on metal equipment such as boilers and steam producing equipment. Orthophosphoric acid is routinely used as a cleaning compound in its dilute form to remove oxidation from non-stainless steel surfaces, staining of stainless steel, lime and scale from heat exchangers and in Clean-in-Place (CIP) cleaning operations especially in dairy processing to remove build up of calcium and phosphate salts from processing equipment. It is also used to brighten metals and remove rust. Additionally, orthophosphoric acid can be mixed with other detergents for process cleaning operations. Phosphoric acid is preferred because it is the lowest in corrosiveness at the low concentrations which are effective and is compatible with many surfactants. Organic acids such as citric, tartaric, acetic and gluconic are effective in some situations, especially removing mineral deposits formed as a result of using alkaline cleaning compounds or other cleaners. They are not as corrosive or irritating to the skin and they are good water softeners and rinse easily. Other strong acid agents used for cleaning operations include hydrochloric (muriatic), hydrofluoric, sulfamic, sulfuric, and nitric acids. Nitric and sulfuric acids are so corrosive that they are not generally used as cleaners. Hydrofluoric acid is very unstable and dangerous to handle and also extremely corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is very effective at descaling metals but produces highly toxic fumes in the form of hydrogen chloride gas. This special cleaner dissolves and removes rust, scale, lime, corrosion, excess concrete, soap scum, mortar, urine build-up and all water minerals. Strong acids are normally inhibited in order to avoid corrosion attack on metals.

Alkaline cleaning: A hot alkali solution is used to remove organic contaminants from the metal surface, including dirt, paint markings, grease, oil, etc.
Typical ingredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants. Alkaline cleaning agents have different functions and would not be considered alternatives to acids, but would be used as a separate step in a thorough cleaning program.
rdf:Description.typicalIngredients: Caustic (e.g. sodium hydroxide, sodium metasilicate) with detergent and wetting agents, builders, additives and surfactants.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
CIP cleaning: Clean in Place is the process used to ensure that process lines, vessels and reactors are free of inorganic and organic contaminants. Clean in Place technology involves the use of chemicals, high pressure pumps, spray nozzles and spray balls and aseptic design principles to ensure that large scale processes are appropriately free of dirt, organic contaminants and microorganisms.
Automation is another essential element of the modern CIP process. There are a number of steps involved in a full cleaning and sterilizing CIP process: Draining, rinsing, cleaning, sanitizing wash, final rinse.
In the first stage it is important that the process equipment must as much as possible be drained of fluids and solids.
In the next stage, water is used as a primary wash to clean away the more easily removed particles.
Following this is the cleaning stage. Most cleaning agents are based around a sodium hydroxide/surfactant mixture. The mixture is dissolved in water to prepare typically a 1-3% w/v solution and heated to 50 °C-80 °C. The solution is circulated through the system for approximately 15-20 minutes. The caustic solution is then drained from the system. Contrary to popular belief, the caustic wash is not a sterilizing process. Spores and hardy microorganisms are able to survive the caustic wash.
Disinfection/sterilization requires the use of a sanitizing wash. Before the sanitizing wash can proceed, it is necessary to remove most of the alkalinity from the system. This is because many sanitizing solutions do not function well under alkaline conditions. Washing with water alone is inefficient and can lead to significant wastage. Dilute solutions of citric acid or nitric acid can be used to assist in removing the alkalinity. These solutions will also assist in removing inorganic scale from the system.
A variety of chemicals are available for the sanitizing wash. These include chlorine compounds, quaternary amines, hydrogen peroxide based formulations. The use of chlorine based compounds such as chlorine dioxide and chlorine is limited by their corrosiveness to stainless steels. If not removed properly from the system they can cause the formation of organochlorides. Quaternary amines can be used. The wastewater from quaternary amine washes are however difficult to treat by biological methods. Hydrogen peroxide formulations have considerable potential as a general use sanitizing agent.
The sanitizing wash is followed by a final step in the CIP process which is a sterile water wash. The water should be deionized so as to prevent the formation of inorganic scale on the walls.

Soap cleaning: Soaps are water-soluble sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Soaps are made from fats and oils, or their fatty acids, by treating them chemically with a strong alkali. Although soap is a good cleaning agent, its effectiveness is reduced when used in hard water.
Hardness in water is caused by the presence of mineral salts - mostly those of calcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg), but sometimes also iron (Fe) and manganese (Mn). The mineral salts react with soap to form an insoluble precipitate known as soap film or scum.

Condensate: or "(boiler) return condensate" is condensed steam which is returned to the boiler. Condensing steam or steam condensate is in principle relatively pure water (at least, in the absence of water treatment chemicals). The condensate water differs from distilled water in level of contamination.
Although the steam condensate of a properly controlled boiler should be pure and non-corrosive, in most practical systems it contains a number of impurities (e.g., dissolved iron, oxygen, carbon dioxide and/or entrained caustic, sodium carbonates, chlorides, silica).
Therefore, steam condensates can be fairly aggressive to a number of metals due to a high content of carbon dioxide or oxygen or both. This oxygen may result from the partial decomposition of superheated steam. The impurities and their concentrations may differ from those present in the makeup water. The presence of iron is normally due to corrosion. Oxygen may arise directly from ingress in the condensate return system or may originate from improper deaeration of the boiler feed water. Carbon dioxide can result from a makeup with high bicarbonate content. Silica is quite volatile and may be carried over in the steam cycle (especially in high-pressure steam systems).
Boiler return condensate may also be treated ("polished") by filtration and ion exchange to prevent accumulation of iron or other salts in the system. Good quality return condensate should have a conductivity of at most 50 microSiemens. If necessary, corrosion in steam-condensate systems is normally controlled through additions of neutralizing or filming amines (e.g., morpholine, octadecylamine).

Cooling/cutting lubricant: The use of coolant-induced cutting tools to improve cutter performance has long been known in the art of material removal. In the 17th century, pioneers used coolant fed boring bars to bore cannon barrels. U.S. Patent archives show records of coolant induced drills dated as far back as the 1890's.
More recently, industry has begun to realize the substantial advantage coolant fed tooling has to offer. Cutting fluids can improve the performance of cutting tools by cooling the cutting tool and the workpiece, by lubricating the cutting surfaces of the tool, by inhibiting seizure between the chip and the tool, and by flushing the chips from the work area.
The results from the use of cutting fluids can be lowered cutting force, improved tool life, higher cutting speeds, heavier chip loads, improved surface finish, better control of workpiece accuracy, and improved chip control.
There are four basic types of cutting fluids: 1) Water-based soluble or emulsifying oils 2) Oil-based cutting fluids 3) Chemical or synthetic fluids 4) Gaseous fluids.
The most common type used in industry is water-based soluble oils, sometimes called coolant. The need to lubricate the cutting tool is just as important as cooling it. The coolants normally contain additives e.g. corrosion inhibitors and bactericides.

Ammonia: Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) exists naturally in a gaseous state under atmospheric pressure and temperature. Under moderate pressure it changes easily to a liquid, becoming a gas again when the pressure is reduced.
Boiling point -33 °C at atm. pressure. Extremely soluble in water e.g. 529g/l at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.638 (at 0 °C, atm. pressure). Vapour pressure is 9 bar at 20 °C and about 20 bar at 50 °C. Viscosity: 0.3 cP at -33 °C.
Industries take advantage of this characteristic by shipping and storing liquefied ammonia in pressurized railway cars, tank trucks and cylinders of various sizes.
It is primarily used as fertilizer. It is also widely used as a refrigerant and in manufacturing nitric acid, explosives, plastics and as a solvent in the chemical laboratory.
Anhydrous ammonia is one of the most water-soluble of all gases, but it should not be confused with aqueous ammonia, which is a 15 to 30 per cent solution of ammonia in water. Generally, ammonia has good warning properties because of its characteristic pungent and irritating odour.
With rising temperature ammonia expands rapidly, increasing the internal pressure in vessels and pipes, etc. This must be considered in the design and operation of ammonia systems.

Calcium chloride: CaCl2, chemical compound that is crystalline, lumpy, or flaky, is normally white, and is very soluble in water (400 g/l (20 °C). The water solution is normally neutral or slightly on the alkaline side. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.3. Viscosity: Water-thin The anhydrous compound is hygroscopic; it rapidly absorbs water and is used to dry gases by passing them through it. Use: to melt ice on roads, to control dust, in brines for refrigeration, and as a preservative in foods. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.

Cooling/cutting lubricant: The use of coolant-induced cutting tools to improve cutter performance has long been known in the art of material removal. In the 17th century, pioneers used coolant fed boring bars to bore cannon barrels. U.S. Patent archives show records of coolant induced drills dated as far back as the 1890's.
More recently, industry has begun to realize the substantial advantage coolant fed tooling has to offer. Cutting fluids can improve the performance of cutting tools by cooling the cutting tool and the workpiece, by lubricating the cutting surfaces of the tool, by inhibiting seizure between the chip and the tool, and by flushing the chips from the work area.
The results from the use of cutting fluids can be lowered cutting force, improved tool life, higher cutting speeds, heavier chip loads, improved surface finish, better control of workpiece accuracy, and improved chip control.
There are four basic types of cutting fluids: 1) Water-based soluble or emulsifying oils 2) Oil-based cutting fluids 3) Chemical or synthetic fluids 4) Gaseous fluids.
The most common type used in industry is water-based soluble oils, sometimes called coolant. The need to lubricate the cutting tool is just as important as cooling it. The coolants normally contain additives e.g. corrosion inhibitors and bactericides.

DOWTHERM J heat transfer fluid is a mixture of isomers of an alkylated aromatic specially engineered for demanding low-temperature applications in liquid phase pressurized systems.
Flash point (closed cup): 57 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 420 °C. Specific gravity: 0.98 at 25 °C. Recommended use temperature range: -80 °C to 315 °C.

DOWTHERM Q heat transfer fluid contains a mixture of diphenylethane and alkylated aromatics.
Flash Point (closed cup): 120 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 412 °C. Specific gravity: 0.98 at 0 °C. Recommended use temperature range: -35 °C to 330 °C.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Ethyl alcohol as antifreeze: Ethyl alcohol/water is an aqueous solution of denatured grain alcohol. Its main advantage is that it is nontoxic. Therefore, it is used as antifreeze in applications in breweries, chemical plants, food freezing plants and ground source heat pumps. Boiling point: 78 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 422 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. As a flammable liquid, it requires certain handling and storage precautions. In order to prevent corrosion inhibitors are added. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Ethyl alcohol as antifreeze: Ethyl alcohol/water is an aqueous solution of denatured grain alcohol. Its main advantage is that it is nontoxic. Therefore, it is used as antifreeze in applications in breweries, chemical plants, food freezing plants and ground source heat pumps. Boiling point: 78 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 422 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. As a flammable liquid, it requires certain handling and storage precautions. In order to prevent corrosion inhibitors are added. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Glycerol: C3H5(OH)3, clear, colourless, odorless, syrupy liquid; hygroscopic. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 290 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) and alcohol, insoluble in ether. Flash point 177 °C. Specific gravity: 1.3. Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. Use: as a component of antifreeze mixtures, as a sweetener, in alkyd resins, cellophane, explosives, ester gums, pharmaceuticals, perfumery, cosmetics, foodstuffs, as a solvent, in printer's ink rolls, as an emulsifying agent, in anti-freeze, for paper coatings and finishes, for special soaps, lubricants and softeners and as a hydraulic fluid. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration.

Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Hydrocarbon based refrigerants: Although not well known to the general public, hydrocarbons (HC) are well established as refrigerants and were, like ammonia, used extensively in domestic and small commercial applications in the past. They have excellent refrigerant properties with thermodynamic efficiencies equal to or above chlorofluorocarbons (CFC). Operating temperatures are also comparable.HC's, in particular propane, were introduced as refrigerant in the twenties of this century and its use is being now revitalized, due to concerns of ozone depletion by the CFC's. But the flammability of the HC's is of concern too. In fact the use of HC's in small-scale applications ceased in the 1930s as a result of concerns about flammability and the invention of CFCs. Examples of commercial products are: Duracool, Enviro-Safe, HC-12a (the most common one is a mix of 79% propane and 21% isobutene) and Gilotherm D12. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Methyl alcohol as antifreeze: Methyl alcohol/water is an antifreeze solution used in refrigeration services and ground source heat pumps. Similar to glycols, this solution can be inhibited to stop corrosion. It can be used at temperatures as low as -40 °C owing to its relatively high heat transfer rate in this temperature range. Its main disadvantages as a heat transfer fluid are its toxicological considerations. It is considered more harmful than ethylene glycol and consequently is used only for process applications located outdoors. Methyl alcohol also is flammable and, as such, introduces a potential fire hazard where it is stored, handled or used. Auto ignition temperature: 464 °C. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Methyl alcohol as antifreeze: Methyl alcohol/water is an antifreeze solution used in refrigeration services and ground source heat pumps. Similar to glycols, this solution can be inhibited to stop corrosion. It can be used at temperatures as low as -40 °C owing to its relatively high heat transfer rate in this temperature range. Its main disadvantages as a heat transfer fluid are its toxicological considerations. It is considered more harmful than ethylene glycol and consequently is used only for process applications located outdoors. Methyl alcohol also is flammable and, as such, introduces a potential fire hazard where it is stored, handled or used. Auto ignition temperature: 464 °C. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Potassium acetate: Solubility in water 2530 g/l (20 °C) pH value 7.5 - 8.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Potassium acetate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols).Potassium acetate is highly effective as antifreeze. It exerts much lower BOD-effects (Biological Oxygen Demand), and it offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Glycerol: C3H5(OH)3, clear, colourless, odorless, syrupy liquid; hygroscopic. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 290 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) and alcohol, insoluble in ether. Flash point 177 °C. Specific gravity: 1.3. Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. Use: as a component of antifreeze mixtures, as a sweetener, in alkyd resins, cellophane, explosives, ester gums, pharmaceuticals, perfumery, cosmetics, foodstuffs, as a solvent, in printer's ink rolls, as an emulsifying agent, in anti-freeze, for paper coatings and finishes, for special soaps, lubricants and softeners and as a hydraulic fluid. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: SYLTHERM XLT is a silicone oil based heat transfer fluid (Dimethyl Polysiloxane) designed for use as a low temperature liquid phase heat transfer medium. Flash Point (closed Cup): 47 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 350 °C. Specific gravity at 25 °C: 0.852. Recommended use temperature range: -100 °C to 260 °C.

Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Corn oil: Melting point -20 °C. Specific gravity 0.910. Viscosity about 32 cSt. at 54 °C.
A pale yellow liquid obtained from the embryos of corn grains, used especially as a cooking and salad oil and in the manufacture of margarine.

Creosote is a colorless or yellow, oily liquid. Boiling point: typically 200 °C to 220 °C. Flash point: about 75 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 335 °C. Specific gravity: typically 1.1. Viscosty: about 20-60 cSt. at 20 °C. Water solubility: low. Creosote is a mixture of chemicals prepared by the distillation of coal tar. Its constituents are liquid and solid aromatic hydrocarbons, tar acids, and tar bases. Use: Creosotes are very widely used for impregnating wood. Another common use is to pyrolyse them to carbon black. A minor proportion is used for admixture to pitch and asphalt, to give them the right consistency for use, e.g. as road surfacing. Creosote contains chemicals which are probable carcinogens.

Creosote contains chemicals which are probable carcinogens.

Creosote contains chemicals which are probable carcinogens.

Cresol is a brownish liquid with a phenol-like odour. Melting point: 11 °C to 35 °C. Boiling point: about 20 °C. Flash point (closed cup): 86 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 550 °C - 600 °C. CSpecific gravity: 1.04 Viscosity: about 10-20 cSt. Water solubility: moderate Cresol is a mixture of the three isomeric cresols (ortho-, meta-, para-cresol). It is obtained from coal tar. Use: Mixed cresols are used as disinfectants, preservatives and wood preservatives.

Cresol is a brownish liquid with a phenol-like odour. Melting point: 11 °C to 35 °C. Boiling point: about 20 °C. Flash point (closed cup): 86 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 550 °C - 600 °C. CSpecific gravity: 1.04 Viscosity: about 10-20 cSt. Water solubility: moderate Cresol is a mixture of the three isomeric cresols (ortho-, meta-, para-cresol). It is obtained from coal tar. Use: Mixed cresols are used as disinfectants, preservatives and wood preservatives.

Chromic acid: occurring only as salt (CrO3, dark-red, odourless flakes or powder), or in solution as H2CrO4, a corrosive, oxidizing acid. Solubility in water 63% at 20 °C. pH value 0.2 - 2 depending on concentration. Use: Chromic acid is used in the preparation of wood preservatives, metal plating, magnetic tapes and catalyst production. Chromic acid is used extensively in formulating wood preservatives. The chromate salts act as a fixative, bonding other protective chemicals to the wood.Chromic acid serves as the source of chromium metal for plating chromium on all common metals and plastics. Chromium plating is of two types: decorative plating, normally over deposits of copper and/or nickel, and hard chromium plating, applied directly to cast iron, steel, aluminum and other metals. Decorative plating is used on automobile trim and other consumer products, such as toasters, major appliances, and plumbing fixtures.

Crude oil: Flammable liquid varying in colour from yellow to dark reddish-brown, has a peculiar heavy odor. Specific gravity ranges from 0.78 to 0.97. Viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP. Some crudes have to be heated before they can be easily handle. Crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons that exists as a liquid in natural underground reservoirs and remains liquid at atmospheric pressure after passing through surface separating facilities. It consists predominately of paraffins, cyclo-paraffins, cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons having carbon numbers greater than C1. Crude oil may also contain small amounts of benzene, hydrocarbons, oxygenated compounds, sulfur, naphthenic acid and numerous chemicals introduced during the production of the crude. Crude oil is the raw material which is refined into gasoline, heating oil, jet fuel, propane, petrochemicals and other products. Sour crude oil: Crude oil with a high sulphur content. Sweet crude oil: Crude oil with a low sulphur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Appearance: solid or viscous liquid with an amine odour. Melting point: 28 °C. Boiling point: about 268 °C decomposes). Flash point (100% conc.): 137 °C (closed cup). Auto ignition temperature(100% conc.): 662 °C. Specific gravity: 1.09. Viscosity (100% conc.): 380 cP at 30 °C. Viscosity (85% conc.): 60 cP at 20 °C. pH (80 % soln.): 11.95. Diethanolamine is very soluble in water. Diethanolamine causes skin irritation and may be harmful if absorbed through skin. It causes severe eye irritation and may be harmful if inhaled. Use: Diethanolamine is widely used in the preparation of diethanolamides and diethanolamine salts of long-chain fatty acids that are formulated into soaps and surfactants used in liquid laundry and dishwashing detergents, cosmetics, shampoos, and hair conditioners. Diethanolamine is also used in textile processing, in industrial gas purification to remove acid gases, as an anticorrosion agent in metalworking fluids, and in preparations of agricultural chemicals.

Demineralized water (deionized (DI) water) - water from which both anions (e.g. chloride, sulfate, nitrate, phosphate, bicarbonate) and cations (e.g. calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium) have been removed by an ion exchange process. Only those substances, which ionize in water, are removed by deionization. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Today, deionized water has become an essential ingredient in hundreds of applications including: medical, laboratory, pharmaceutical, cosmetics, electronics manufacturing, food processing, plating, countless industrial processes, and even the final rinse at the local car wash. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Water quality from deionizers varies with the type of resins used, feed water quality, flow, efficiency of regeneration, remaining capacity, etc. because of these variables, it is critical in many DI water applications to know the precise quality. Resistivity/conductivity is the most convenient method for testing DI water quality. DI high purity water is a poor electrical conductor, having a resistivity of 18.2 million ohm-cm (18.2 megaohm) and conductivity of 0.055 micro Siemens/cm. It is the amount of ionized substances (or salts) dissolved in the water which determines water's ability to conduct electricity. Therefore, resistivity and its inverse, conductivity, are good general purpose quality parameters. Notes: Deionised water is corrosive to copper and cast iron because the water is "soft" and may contain traces of dissolved oxygen or CO2. It is corrosive to cement and concrete because it is "hungry" for calcium. Various thermoplastic and thermosetting resin formulations, as well as stainless steels and aluminium, can be used. Ultra pure water - water with a specific resistance higher than 1 megaohm-cm (less than 1 micro Siemens/cm). In the laboratory, it normally refers to ASTM D1193 Type 1 reagent grade water. Anything in laboratory water that is not H2O is an impurity. Although chemically pure water is not attainable, ultrapure water systems are now capable of reducing impurities down to the limits of detection. Distilled water - water that has been purified by passing through an evaporation-condensation cycle. It contains small quantities of dissolved solids. Multiple distilling will further lower the percentage of dissolved liquids. Softened water - water that was originally hard, but from which calcium and magnesium ions have been removed.

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Heat Transfer Liquids Mineral or synthetic hydrocarbon based heat transfer liquids (thermal stable liquids) containing effective oxidation and corrosion inhibitors. Heat transfer liquid is also known by a variety of trade names. Other Names: Heat transmission oil, thermal oil, HTO.
Specific gravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature. Viscosity: About 1-5 cSt at service temperatures. At 20 °C the viscosity typically is about 20-100 cSt.
Remarks: Heat transfer liquids are used instead of steam for transferring heat from a source to a point of use such as dies, presses, cooking vessels, processing equipment, etc. Many of them can operate at temperatures up to 315 °C. FKM elastomers are normally recommended but PTFE, FXM or FFKM may also be needed.
rdf:Description.specificGravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Methylene chloride is a colourless, volatile, practically nonflammable liquid belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Methylene chloride has a chloroform-like odor and is highly toxic and a suspected carcinogen. Its toxic effects can be exerted through inhalation, ingestion, and skin/tissue absorption. Melting point -97 °C. Boiling point 40 °C at atmospheric pressure. Flash point: none. Auto ignition temperature: 605 °C. It is denser than water and very slightly soluble in it (1.32 g/100g at 25 °C). Specific gravity: 1.32. Viscosity: 0.45 cP. at 15 °C. Dichloromethane is commercially produced along with methyl chloride, chloroform, and carbon tetrachloride by the chlorination of methane. It is an effective solvent for fats, oils, greases, and many polymeric substances; its use is favoured by low toxicity, low flammability, high stability, and ease of recovery for reuse. Use: It is extensively used as a solvent, especially in paint-stripping formulations.

Diesel fuel: Diesel fuel is principally a blend of petroleum-derived compounds called middle distillates (heavier than gasoline but lighter than lubricating oil) and may or may not contain additional additives. Molecular formula: Depends upon formulation, typically composed of a hydrocarbon mix (mostly ranging from C10 to C22). Flash point of 48 °C to 72 °C. Auto ignition temperature: about 200 °C. During the operation of a diesel engine, diesel fuel is injected into the compressed, high-temperature air in the combustion chamber where it ignites spontaneously. The important properties of diesel fuels are volatility, heating value, ignition quality, viscosity, low-temperature flow, storage stability, component compatibility, and sulfur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Appearance: solid or viscous liquid with an amine odour. Melting point: 28 °C. Boiling point: about 268 °C decomposes). Flash point (100% conc.): 137 °C (closed cup). Auto ignition temperature(100% conc.): 662 °C. Specific gravity: 1.09. Viscosity (100% conc.): 380 cP at 30 °C. Viscosity (85% conc.): 60 cP at 20 °C. pH (80 % soln.): 11.95. Diethanolamine is very soluble in water. Diethanolamine causes skin irritation and may be harmful if absorbed through skin. It causes severe eye irritation and may be harmful if inhaled. Use: Diethanolamine is widely used in the preparation of diethanolamides and diethanolamine salts of long-chain fatty acids that are formulated into soaps and surfactants used in liquid laundry and dishwashing detergents, cosmetics, shampoos, and hair conditioners. Diethanolamine is also used in textile processing, in industrial gas purification to remove acid gases, as an anticorrosion agent in metalworking fluids, and in preparations of agricultural chemicals.

Morpholine, a strong base is a colourless, oily, hygroscopic, volatile liquid with a characteristic amine odour. Morpholine is distributed as an anhydrous liquid and as 40% and 88% solutions with water. Melting point: -5 °C. Boiling point: 129 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 39 °C (Closed cup). Auto ignition temperature (100% conc.): 310 °C. Specific gravity: 1.0. Viscosity (100%): 2.23 cP at 20 °C. Water solubility: 100% Use: Morpholine is used as a chemical intermediate in the rubber industry, as a corrosion inhibitor (especially in boiler systems), in the synthesis of optical brighteners, pharmaceutical products, in waxes, polishes and in dyes. Morpholine causes burn to any area of contact. Harmful if swallowed, inhaled or absorbed through skin.

Tartaric acid: HO2CCHOHCHOHCO2H, white colourless, odourless, crystalline powder. Very soluble in water: 1390 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.6 (100 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Melting point: 206 °C. Tartaric acid is an organic fruit acid. It occurs in many plants, particularly in the grape and is easily obtained from tartar.This natural acid is chiefly the dextrorotatory D-tartaric acid, called also D-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid or L-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid. This form can be partially converted to the others by heating it with an aqueous alkali, e.g., potassium hydroxide. Tartaric acids can be synthesized from maleic acids or fumaric acids by reaction with aqueous potassium permanganate. The various isomeric forms differ in such physical properties as boiling point. Use: Tartaric acid is used in the form of its salts, e.g., cream of tartar and Rochelle salt. It is also used as synergist for antioxidants, acid, sequestrant and flavouring agent. Widely used in foodstuffs industry such as foaming agent of beer, acidity agent, taste improvement of foodstuffs, cold drink, candy, fruit juice and ferment powder.

Xylene, C6H4(CH3)2, is a highly flammable, colorless, oily, liquid aromatic hydrocarbon obtained from coal tar, wood tar, and sometimes from petroleum. Insoluble in water. It is a mixture of three isomers that differ structurally from one another in the location of the two methyl groups that have replaced hydrogen atoms in the benzene molecule. Melting point: -48 °C to -13 °C. Boiling point: 138 °C to 144 °C. Flash point: 27 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 528 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87 kg/m3. Viscosity: from 0.6-0.8 cP at 20 °C. The separation of these three isomers from one another by fractional distillation is difficult because their boiling points are so close together. The xylenes are often used in the synthesis of other compounds, e.g., the xylidenes that are amino derivatives used in the synthesis of azo dyes (e.g. methyl orange) and other compounds. Use: Xylene is used extensively as a solvent. Notes: Harmful if swallowed or inhaled. Eye, skin and respiratory irritant. May act as a narcotic. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Acetone: CH3COCH3, colourless, highly flammable (flash point <. -20 °C) and volatile liquid. Soluble in water. Acetone is the simplest aliphatic ketone. Melting point: -97 °C. Boiling point: 57 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 465 °C. Viscosity: 0.30 cP at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79 at 20 °C. Use: Acetone is widely used in industry as a solvent for numerous organic substances and is a component of most paint and varnish removers. It is used in the manufacture of synthetic resins and fillers, smokeless powders (e.g., cordite), and numerous other organic compounds. Acetone is produced commercially mostly by catalytic dehydrogenation of isopropanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Specific gravity about 1.0. Commercially available in a range of viscosities from 1 cSt. to several thousand cSt.
Silicones are polymers in which organics groups, such as methyl and phenyl groups are bonded to the silicone atoms in chains of inorganic siloxanes (-Si-O-Si-).
Silicone oils have low surface tension, defoaming properties, excellent gloss and film properties, thermal and oxidative stability, and exhibit excellent viscosity stability over a wide temperature range. Silicone oils are also chemically inert to most common materials of construction and have low flammability.

Sodium phosphate (dibasic): Colorless or white, odourless granular salt. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Solubility in water 93 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9.1 - 9.4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Because phosphoric acid is tribasic (having three replaceable hydrogen atoms), it forms monophosphate, diphosphate, and triphosphate salts in which one, two, or three of the hydrogens of the acid are replaced, respectively. Use: Disodium phosphate is used in boiler compounds, detergents and to some extent in medicine and in preparing baking powders.

District heating: The provision of a public heating supply, delivered form the power plant by means of hot water in a closed circuit. After supplying heat to a building's own space heating and domestic hot water heating system, the cooled district heating water is pumped back for reheating. The district heating water is often treated. The strategy is to maintain high quality water in the system through continual filtering, deaeration and demineralisation (or softening) and to maintain the pH between 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide. The procedure requires careful monitoring of the chemistry of the system water. Demineralisation is preferable to softening because it reduces the total ionic concentration. Example of water treatment method filter demineralise or soften deaerate raise pH to 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide (NaOH)

DOWTHERM J heat transfer fluid is a mixture of isomers of an alkylated aromatic specially engineered for demanding low-temperature applications in liquid phase pressurized systems.
Flash point (closed cup): 57 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 420 °C. Specific gravity: 0.98 at 25 °C. Recommended use temperature range: -80 °C to 315 °C.

DOWTHERM Q heat transfer fluid contains a mixture of diphenylethane and alkylated aromatics.
Flash Point (closed cup): 120 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 412 °C. Specific gravity: 0.98 at 0 °C. Recommended use temperature range: -35 °C to 330 °C.

Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.
No Info

Water from precipitation e.g. a stormwater event, which is not seeped into the ground and which is discharged to the drain or sewer system directly form the ground or from exterior building surfaces.
Surface water may cause problems due to the volume of water, the intensity of the runoff and the potential contaminants that the water is carrying, i.e. water pollution. When runoff flows towards the sewer system, it picks up different contaminants such as petroleum/fuels, oils/grease, metal species, pesticides or fertilizers from the ground and surfaces that it runs on. Furthermore the water also carries abrasive particles such as sand, grit etc. which is dragged into the sewer system.
No Info

Water: H2O, also further identified by such terms as soft, tap, hard, distilled, fresh, etc. Specific. Gravity.: 1.0. Viscosity: 1 cP at 20 °C. Water is the most readily available liquid and one of the most difficult to handle, primarily because of its lack of lubrication, corrosive and erosive nature. Water in nature is rarely pure in the "distilled water" sense; it contains dissolved salts, buffers, nutrients, etc., with exact concentrations dependent on local conditions. Use: Enormous quantities are required for cooling of products and equipment, for process needs, for boiler feed and for sanitary and potable water. It was estimated, in 1980, that the water requirements for industry in the USA approximated 525 billion liters per day. A substantial quantity of this water was reused. The intake of "new" water was estimated to be about 140 billion liters daily. If this water was pure and contained no contaminants, there would be little need for water conditioning or water treatment. Water possesses several unique properties, one being its ability to dissolve to some degree every substance occurring on the earth's crust and in the atmosphere. Because of this solvent property, water typically contains a variety of impurities. These impurities are a source of potential trouble through deposition of the impurities in water lines, boiler tubes and on products which are contacted by it. Notes: Water becomes corrosive in the presence of dissolved oxygen. The degree of corrosivity depends on pH, temperature and salt content. For many purposes (e.g. industrial and drinking water applications) water undergoes a further treatment (e.g. disinfection, softening etc.) which may affect the corrosivity of the water.

Effluent is the outflow of water from a natural body of water or from a man-made structure.
Effluent in the man-made sense is generally considered to be pollution. This could entail outflow from a sewage treatment facility, the wastewater discharge from industrial facilities or water from a detention or process tank. The water can be of varying quality - ranging from heavily polluted to completely clean.

Melting point: 250 °C. Solubility in water 710g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 6.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (26%, 20 °C): 1.2. Viscosity (26%, 20 °C): 2.4 cSt. It was first prepared from the waters of mineral springs at Epsom, England; it also occurs as the mineral epsomite. Use: Magnesium sulfate is used medicinally as a purgative, it is also used in leather tanning, mordant dyeing, fertilizers, explosives and as a filler in cotton goods and paper.

Acetaldehyde or ethanal, a highly flammable colourless liquid aldehyde with a pungent, fruity odour, sometimes simply called aldehyde. Acetaldehyde is soluble in water and ethanol. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Prolonged contact with air may cause formation of peroxides that may explode. It is formed by the partial oxidation of ethanol. Oxidation of acetaldehyde forms acetic acid. Acetaldehyde is made commercially by the oxidation of ethylene with a palladium catalyst. Use: Acetaldehyde is mainly used as an intermediate in the synthesis of other chemicals. Acetaldehyde is formed as a product of incomplete wood combustion in fireplaces and woodstoves, forest and wildfires, pulp and paper production, stationary internal combustion engines and turbines, vehicle exhaust fumes, and wastewater processing. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Acetaldehyde or ethanal, a highly flammable colourless liquid aldehyde with a pungent, fruity odour, sometimes simply called aldehyde. Acetaldehyde is soluble in water and ethanol. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Prolonged contact with air may cause formation of peroxides that may explode. It is formed by the partial oxidation of ethanol. Oxidation of acetaldehyde forms acetic acid. Acetaldehyde is made commercially by the oxidation of ethylene with a palladium catalyst. Use: Acetaldehyde is mainly used as an intermediate in the synthesis of other chemicals. Acetaldehyde is formed as a product of incomplete wood combustion in fireplaces and woodstoves, forest and wildfires, pulp and paper production, stationary internal combustion engines and turbines, vehicle exhaust fumes, and wastewater processing. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Oxalic acid or ethanedioic acid, HO2CCO2H, is a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 102 °C with sublimation. Solubility in water 102 g/l (20 °C) pH value 0.7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Oxalic acid and oxalate salts are poisonous. Oxalic acid is found in many plants, e.g., sorrel and rhubarb, normally as its calcium or potassium salts.
Oxalic acid is the only possible compound in which two carboxyl groups are joined directly; for this reason oxalic acid is one of the strongest organic acids. Unlike other carboxylic acids (except formic acid), it is readily oxidized. This makes it useful as a reducing agent for photography, bleaching, and ink removal.

Oxalic acid or ethanedioic acid, HO2CCO2H, is a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 102 °C with sublimation. Solubility in water 102 g/l (20 °C) pH value 0.7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Oxalic acid and oxalate salts are poisonous. Oxalic acid is found in many plants, e.g., sorrel and rhubarb, normally as its calcium or potassium salts.
Oxalic acid is the only possible compound in which two carboxyl groups are joined directly; for this reason oxalic acid is one of the strongest organic acids. Unlike other carboxylic acids (except formic acid), it is readily oxidized. This makes it useful as a reducing agent for photography, bleaching, and ink removal.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Acetic acid, CH3CO2H, colourless liquid that has a characteristic pungent odor, boils at 118 °C, and is miscible with water in all proportions; it is a weak organic carboxylic acid (see carboxyl group). Glacial acetic acid is concentrated, 99.5% pure acetic acid; it solidifies at about 17 °C to a crystalline mass resembling ice. Specific gravity: 1.050. Flash point 39 °C. Auto ignition temperature 463 °C. Melting point: 17 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. pH value: 2.9 (6 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Use: Acetic acid is the major acid in vinegar; as such, it is widely used as a food preservative and condiment. For industrial use concentrated acetic acid is prepared from the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Acetic acid is also a product in the destructive distillation of wood. It reacts with other chemicals to form numerous compounds of commercial importance. These include cellulose acetate, used in making acetate rayon, nonflammable motion-picture film, lacquers, and plastics; various inorganic salts, e.g., lead, potassium, and copper acetates; and amyl, butyl, ethyl, methyl, and propyl acetates, which are used as solvents, mostly in certain quick-drying lacquers and cements. Amyl acetate is sometimes called banana oil because it has a characteristic banana odor.

Acetic anhydride: Colourless liquid with strong acetic acid odor. Slowly soluble in water, forming acetic acid. Specific gravity 1.08. Viscosity: 0.912 cP. Melting point -73 °C. Boiling point 140 °C. Flash point 49 °C (combustible). Auto ignition temperature: 316 °C. Soluble in cold water(>=10mg/ml); Decomposes in hot water. Acetic anhydride belongs to the group of acid anhydrides, which is a chemical compound that reacts with water to form an acid. Anhydrides of inorganic acids are normally oxides of nonmetallic elements. Carbon dioxide, CO2, is the anhydride of carbonic acid, H2CO3. Nitrogen pentoxide, N2O5, is the anhydride of nitric acid, HNO3. Phosphorus pentoxide, P2O5, is the anhydride of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Sulfur dioxide, SO2, is the anhydride of sulfurous acid, H2SO3. Sulfur trioxide, SO3, is the anhydride of sulfuric acid, H2SO4. Anhydrides of organic acids, like the acids themselves, contain the carbonyl group, CO. Organic anhydrides include acetic anhydride or ethanoic anhydride, (CH3CO)2O, and benzoic anhydride, (C6H5CO)2O. Use: Used in manufacture of acetyl compounds and cellulose acetates. Also as solvent in examining wool fat, glycerol, fatty and volatile oils and resins. Widely used in organic syntheses as dehydrating agent in nitrations, sulfonations and other reactions where removal of water is necessary. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Ethyl alcohol (Ethanol): CH3CH2OH, a colourless liquid highly flammable liquid with characteristic odor and taste; commonly called alcohol. Boiling point: 78 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 422 °C. Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.789. Properties: Ethanol is a primary alcohol. It melts at -117 °C and boils at 78.5 °C. It is miscible (i.e., mixes without separation) with water in all proportions (pH value 7.0 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). and is separated from water only with difficulty; ethanol that is completely free of water is called absolute ethanol. Ethanol burns in air with a blue flame, forming carbon dioxide and water. It reacts with active metals to form the metal ethoxide and hydrogen, e.g., with sodium it forms sodium ethoxide. It reacts with certain acids to form esters, e.g., with acetic acid it forms ethyl acetate. It can be oxidized to form acetic acid and acetaldehyde. It can be dehydrated to form diethyl ether or, at higher temperatures, ethylene. Use: Ethanol is used extensively as a solvent in the manufacture of varnishes and perfumes; as a preservative for biological specimens; in the preparation of essences and flavorings; in many medicines and drugs; as a disinfectant and in tinctures (e.g., tincture of iodine); and as a fuel and gasoline additive. Denatured, or industrial, alcohol is ethanol to which poisonous or nauseating substances have been added to prevent its use as a beverage. Medically, ethanol is a soporific, i.e., sleep-producing; although it is less toxic than the other alcohols, death normally occurs if the concentration of ethanol in the bloodstream exceeds about 5 per thousand. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Appearance: colourless liquid with an odour of ammonia. Melting point: 10 °C - 12 °C. Boiling point: 170 °C. Specific gravity: 1.01. Viscosity (100% conc.): 24.1 cP at 20 °C and 16.2 cP at 30 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 85 C (closed cup). Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Water solubility: 100% Ethanolamine is harmful by ingestion, inhalation or if absorbed through skin. Ethanolamine may cause severe eye, skin and respiratory irritation. Use: Ethanolamnine is used as a non-ionic detergent in dry cleaning, as cleaning agent in the electronic industry, emulsion paints, polishes and agricultural sprays and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Ethyl alcohol as antifreeze: Ethyl alcohol/water is an aqueous solution of denatured grain alcohol. Its main advantage is that it is nontoxic. Therefore, it is used as antifreeze in applications in breweries, chemical plants, food freezing plants and ground source heat pumps. Boiling point: 78 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 422 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. As a flammable liquid, it requires certain handling and storage precautions. In order to prevent corrosion inhibitors are added. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Ethyl acetate or ethyl ethanoate is used in glues, nail polish removers, decaffeinating tea and coffee, and cigarettes. Its main use is as solvent. Ethyl acetate is colorless and has a sweet smell. It is soluble in water up to 8 grams per 100 mL water. Boiling Point: 77.1 °C Flash Point: -4 °C Viscosity: 0.426 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.897 g/mL at 20 °C

The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

2-Ethoxyethanol, also known by the trademark Cellosolve or ethyl cellosolve , is a solvent used widely in commercial and Ethylene glycol monoethylether 2-ethoxy-ethanol Formula: HOCH3CH2OCH2CH3 industrial applications. It is a clear, colorless, nearly odorless liquid that is miscible with water, ethanol, diethyl ether, acetone, and ethyl acetate. As with other glycol ethers, 2-ethoxyethanol has the useful property of being able to dissolve chemically diverse compounds. It will dissolve oils, resins, grease, waxes, nitrocellulose, and lacquers. This is an ideal property as a multi-purpose cleaner, and, therefore, 2-ethoxyethanol is used in products, such as varnish removers and degreasing solutions. Boiling point: 135 °C Flash point: 42 °C Viscosity: 2.50 mPs at 20 °C Density: 0.960 g/mL at 20 °C Water miscible. Combustible.

Ethyl acetate or ethyl ethanoate is used in glues, nail polish removers, decaffeinating tea and coffee, and cigarettes. Its main use is as solvent. Ethyl acetate is colorless and has a sweet smell. It is soluble in water up to 8 grams per 100 mL water. Boiling Point: 77.1 °C Flash Point: -4 °C Viscosity: 0.426 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.897 g/mL at 20 °C

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Acetaldehyde or ethanal, a highly flammable colourless liquid aldehyde with a pungent, fruity odour, sometimes simply called aldehyde. Acetaldehyde is soluble in water and ethanol. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Prolonged contact with air may cause formation of peroxides that may explode. It is formed by the partial oxidation of ethanol. Oxidation of acetaldehyde forms acetic acid. Acetaldehyde is made commercially by the oxidation of ethylene with a palladium catalyst. Use: Acetaldehyde is mainly used as an intermediate in the synthesis of other chemicals. Acetaldehyde is formed as a product of incomplete wood combustion in fireplaces and woodstoves, forest and wildfires, pulp and paper production, stationary internal combustion engines and turbines, vehicle exhaust fumes, and wastewater processing. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Acetaldehyde or ethanal, a highly flammable colourless liquid aldehyde with a pungent, fruity odour, sometimes simply called aldehyde. Acetaldehyde is soluble in water and ethanol. Melting point: -123 °C. Boiling point: 21 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 185 °C. Specific gravity: 0.78. Viscosity: 0.22 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -39 °C. Explosion limits: 4% - 57%. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
