Boiling point: 135 °C Flash point: 42 °C Viscosity: 2.50 mPs at 20 °C Density: 0.960 g/mL at 20 °C Water miscible. Combustible.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Tetrachloroethylene: Also called Perchloroethylene, a colourless, dense, nonflammable, highly stable liquid with ether-like odour belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Tetrachloroethylene is denser than water and practically insoluble in it. Boiling point: 121 °C. Specific gravity: 1.62. Viscosity: 0.89 cP at 25 °C Tetrachloroethylene was first prepared in 1821 by the English physicist Michael Faraday; it has been commercially manufactured since about 1910, mostly from trichloroethylene. Use: Tetrachloroethylene is a powerful solvent for many organic substances. By the mid-20th century it had become the most widely used solvent in dry cleaning (displacing carbon tetrachloride and trichloroethylene) and was also commonly used for cleaning metal objects in vapour-degreasing apparatuses. Its broad acceptance has been based upon its nonflammability and low toxicity. Small quantities are also employed as a vermifuge, particularly against hookworm. However tetrachloroethylene is harmful if inhaled, ingested or in contact with skin.

Trichloroethylene: CHClCCl2, is a stable, low-boiling, colourless, heavy, mobile, nonflammable, nonexplosive, noncombustible, toxic liquid. Specific Gravity: 1.46. Viscosity: 0.57 cP at 25 °C. Melting point: -73 °C. Boiling point: 87 °C. Flash point: (open cup) none up to boiling point. Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Vapor is harmful. Miscible with common organic solvents, insoluble in water. Use: Used in metal degreasing, solvent for oils, fats and waxes, dry cleaning, as a refrigerant, heat exchange liquid, as a fumigant, and for cleaning and drying small intricate parts.

Lactic acid : CH3CHOHCO2H, a colourless, odourless syrupy liquid organic acid. It is miscible with water, pH value 2.8 (10 g/l (of 90% solution), H2O, 20 °C), ethanol or glycerin. Specific Gravity: 1.2. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 122 °C. Viscosity: 40 to 100 cP.
Lactic acid is a fermentation product of lactose (milk sugar); it is present in sour milk, yoghourt, and cottage cheese. The protein in milk is coagulated (curdled) by lactic acid. Lactic acid is produced in the muscles during intense activity. Calcium lactate, a soluble lactic acid salt, is used as a source of calcium in the diet. Lactic acid is produced commercially for use in pharmaceuticals and foods, in leather tanning and textile dyeing, and in making plastics, solvents, inks, and lacquers. Other Names: Milk acid

Ferric chloride: Dark brown liquid. Liquid solution with 35 to 40% ferric chloride in water has a specific gravity - 1.45 at 30 °C. Solubility in water 920g/l (20 °C) pH value about 1.8 (10 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Use: Ferric chloride is used principally as a flocculating agent for water treatment. It is also used in metal surface treatment as etching agent for engraving, photography and printed circuitry. Ferric chloride is sometimes used as a disinfectant. It deodourizes sewage and industrial wastes with partial reduction to ferrous chloride (FeCl2). Ferric chloride is aggressive to most metals. Pronounced tendency to crystallisation.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C) , pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C), pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Melting point: 64 °C. Solubility in water 665 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3-4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used in the manufacture of inks, in wool dyeing as a mordant, and in sewage and water treatment as a substitute for aluminum sulfate. Used as a pigment, fertilizer, and feed additive, and as a medicine in the treatment of iron deficiency.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Formalin is a colourless combustible liquid. It is a 40% by volume solution of formaldehyde (HCHO) in water, normally with a small amount of methanol (methyl alcohol) added to prevent polymerization. pH value 5.1-5.7. Flash point 60 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 430 °C. Specific gravity: 1.111 to 1.119 at 25 °C. Formalin causes burns and is very toxic by inhalation, ingestion and through skin absorption. It is readily absorbed through skin. Possible cancer hazard. Use: It is used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, and preservative for biological materials. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Formalin is a colourless combustible liquid. It is a 40% by volume solution of formaldehyde (HCHO) in water, normally with a small amount of methanol (methyl alcohol) added to prevent polymerization. pH value 5.1-5.7. Flash point 60 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 430 °C. Specific gravity: 1.111 to 1.119 at 25 °C. Formalin causes burns and is very toxic by inhalation, ingestion and through skin absorption. It is readily absorbed through skin. Possible cancer hazard. Use: It is used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, and preservative for biological materials. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Formic acid: or methanoic acid, HCO2H, a colourless, corrosive liquid with a sharp odor.; it boils at 101 °C and solidifies at 8 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 2.2 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Note: Often used in an aqueous solution. It has the lowest molecular weight and is the simplest of the carboxylic acids. Functionally, it is both an acid and an aldehyde. Like other acids, it reacts with most alcohols to form esters and decomposes when heated; like other aldehydes, it is easily oxidized. Formic acid occurs in the bodies of red ants and in the stingers of bees. It can be made by the oxidation of formaldehyde; it is prepared commercially by heating carbon monoxide and sodium hydroxide to form sodium formate which, when carefully treated with sulfuric acid, yields formic acid. Use: Formic acid is used industrially in textile dyeing, in leather tanning, and in coagulating latex rubber.

Formalin is a colourless combustible liquid. It is a 40% by volume solution of formaldehyde (HCHO) in water, normally with a small amount of methanol (methyl alcohol) added to prevent polymerization. pH value 5.1-5.7. Flash point 60 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 430 °C. Specific gravity: 1.111 to 1.119 at 25 °C. Formalin causes burns and is very toxic by inhalation, ingestion and through skin absorption. It is readily absorbed through skin. Possible cancer hazard. Use: It is used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, and preservative for biological materials. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Formic acid: or methanoic acid, HCO2H, a colourless, corrosive liquid with a sharp odor.; it boils at 101 °C and solidifies at 8 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 2.2 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Note: Often used in an aqueous solution. It has the lowest molecular weight and is the simplest of the carboxylic acids. Functionally, it is both an acid and an aldehyde. Like other acids, it reacts with most alcohols to form esters and decomposes when heated; like other aldehydes, it is easily oxidized. Formic acid occurs in the bodies of red ants and in the stingers of bees. It can be made by the oxidation of formaldehyde; it is prepared commercially by heating carbon monoxide and sodium hydroxide to form sodium formate which, when carefully treated with sulfuric acid, yields formic acid. Use: Formic acid is used industrially in textile dyeing, in leather tanning, and in coagulating latex rubber.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Fruit juice: Processing fruit juices presents some special problems because the acids contained in fruits are corrosive to many metals. There also can be corrosive action from some of the preservatives used.
Viscosity: Varies from thin to thick, depending on the stage in the process and the pulp content. pH varies from about 2 for lime juice to about 7 for melon juice.
Processing of fruit juices may involve sanitary requirements, possible flushing cycles and handling of many additives and preservatives, as well as the fruit juices. Some viscosity may be involved, depending on the extent to which the juices have been concentrated.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from thin to thick, depending on the stage in the process and the pulp content.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Diesel fuel: Diesel fuel is principally a blend of petroleum-derived compounds called middle distillates (heavier than gasoline but lighter than lubricating oil) and may or may not contain additional additives. Molecular formula: Depends upon formulation, typically composed of a hydrocarbon mix (mostly ranging from C10 to C22). Flash point of 48 °C to 72 °C. Auto ignition temperature: about 200 °C. During the operation of a diesel engine, diesel fuel is injected into the compressed, high-temperature air in the combustion chamber where it ignites spontaneously. The important properties of diesel fuels are volatility, heating value, ignition quality, viscosity, low-temperature flow, storage stability, component compatibility, and sulfur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Jet fuel: A kerosene-based product used in jet engines. Flammable liquid, flash point from 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: from 300 °C to 400 °C. Jet Fuel This category comprises both gasoline and kerosene type jet fuels meeting specifications for use in aviation turbine power units. Gasoline type jet fuel This includes all light hydrocarbon oils for use in aviation turbine power units. They distill between 100 °C and 250 °C. It is obtained by blending kerosenes and gasoline or naphthas in such a way that the aromatic content does not exceed 25 per cent in volume, and the vapour pressure is between 13.7 kPa and 20.6 kPa. Additives can be included to improve fuel stability and combustibility. Kerosene type jet fuel This is medium distillate used for aviation turbine power units. It has the same distillation characteristics and flash point as kerosene (between 150 °C and 300 °C C but not generally above 250 °C. In addition, it has particular specifications (such as freezing point) which are established by the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Kerosene: A colourless, low-sulfur petroleum product that burns without producing much smoke. A complex combination of hydrocarbons including naphthenes, paraffins, and aromatics. Kerosene consists mostly of C9 through C17 hydrocarbons. Kerosene is a colourless to yellowish oily liquid with a strong characteristic odour. Flammable liquid. Flash point 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 225 °C. Specific gravity is between 0.75 - 0.85 kg/m3. Use: At one time kerosene was the most important refinery product because of its use in lamps. Now it is most noted for its use as the primary ingredient in most jet fuels and as a carrier in insecticide sprays. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Naphtha is an low boiling fraction of petroleum i.e. intermediate product between gasoline and kerosene. Naphtha is a clear colourless, highly flammable, volatile liquid with a characteristic odor. The vapors mixed with air will explode if ignited. Naphtha is insoluble in water. Specific gravity about 0.86 to 0.89. Boiling point between 150 °C-220 °C. Flash point -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 277 °C. Use: Naphtha is used as a solvent, cleaner, and gasoline component.

Tannic acid: tannin or gallotannic acid, astringent vegetable product found in a wide variety of plants. Tannic acid is a colourless to pale yellow solid.
Decomposes at 210 °C - 215 °C. Solubility in water 250 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Tannic acid of commerce use normally contains about 10% of water.
Tannin varies somewhat in composition, having the approximate empirical formula C76H52O46. It is believed to be a glucoside in which each of the five hydroxyl groups of the glucose molecule is esterified with a molecule of digallic acid.
Sources include the bark of oak, hemlock, chestnut, and mangrove; the leaves of certain sumacs, and plant galls. Tannic acid is also present in tea, coffee, and walnuts. A solution of tannic acid is obtained from one of these natural sources by extraction with hot water. Tannic acid is in particular obtained from plant gall.
Tannic acid is used in tanning animal skins to make leather, it transforms certain proteins of animal tissue into compounds that resist decomposition. It is also used in manufacturing inks, as a mordant in dyeing, and in medicine as an astringent and for treatment of burns.

Petrol (gasoline): A refined petroleum product used as fuel for reciprocating engines, primarily automobiles. Formula varies between C6H14 and C10H22. Specific Gravity: 0.75. Viscosity: Thin. Highly flammable liquid, flash point: -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 260 °C to 460 °C. Petrol is a mixture of volatile hydrocarbons suitable for operation of internal combustion engines. Petrol intended for use in engines is rated by octane number, an index of quality that reflects the ability of the fuel to resist detonation and burn evenly when subjected to high pressures and temperatures inside an engine. Petrol is also used as a solvent. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

HFC 245fa (1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane) is a non-flammable cooling agent having a boiling point slightly below room temperature. It has lower toxicity compared to most HCFCâ€™s. It is utilized in Rankine cycle applications for waste heat recovery, centrifugal chilllers for process and comfort cooling, heat transfer applications, including secondary loops in commercial refrigeration, Heat pipes and thermosiphons including electronics cooling and thermal storage applications. HFC 245fa is immiscible with water. Vapor pressure: 1.4 bar at 25 °C Boiling point: 15 °C Liquid Viscosity: 0.402 mPa s at 25 °C Density: 1.339 g/mL at 25 °C

Glycerol: C3H5(OH)3, clear, colourless, odorless, syrupy liquid; hygroscopic. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 290 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) and alcohol, insoluble in ether. Flash point 177 °C. Specific gravity: 1.3. Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. Use: as a component of antifreeze mixtures, as a sweetener, in alkyd resins, cellophane, explosives, ester gums, pharmaceuticals, perfumery, cosmetics, foodstuffs, as a solvent, in printer's ink rolls, as an emulsifying agent, in anti-freeze, for paper coatings and finishes, for special soaps, lubricants and softeners and as a hydraulic fluid. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration.

Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Water: H2O, also further identified by such terms as soft, tap, hard, distilled, fresh, etc. Specific. Gravity.: 1.0. Viscosity: 1 cP at 20 °C. Water is the most readily available liquid and one of the most difficult to handle, primarily because of its lack of lubrication, corrosive and erosive nature. Water in nature is rarely pure in the "distilled water" sense; it contains dissolved salts, buffers, nutrients, etc., with exact concentrations dependent on local conditions. Use: Enormous quantities are required for cooling of products and equipment, for process needs, for boiler feed and for sanitary and potable water. It was estimated, in 1980, that the water requirements for industry in the USA approximated 525 billion liters per day. A substantial quantity of this water was reused. The intake of "new" water was estimated to be about 140 billion liters daily. If this water was pure and contained no contaminants, there would be little need for water conditioning or water treatment. Water possesses several unique properties, one being its ability to dissolve to some degree every substance occurring on the earth's crust and in the atmosphere. Because of this solvent property, water typically contains a variety of impurities. These impurities are a source of potential trouble through deposition of the impurities in water lines, boiler tubes and on products which are contacted by it. Notes: Water becomes corrosive in the presence of dissolved oxygen. The degree of corrosivity depends on pH, temperature and salt content. For many purposes (e.g. industrial and drinking water applications) water undergoes a further treatment (e.g. disinfection, softening etc.) which may affect the corrosivity of the water.

Water: H2O, also further identified by such terms as soft, tap, hard, distilled, fresh, etc. Specific. Gravity.: 1.0. Viscosity: 1 cP at 20 °C. Water is the most readily available liquid and one of the most difficult to handle, primarily because of its lack of lubrication, corrosive and erosive nature. Water in nature is rarely pure in the "distilled water" sense; it contains dissolved salts, buffers, nutrients, etc., with exact concentrations dependent on local conditions. Use: Enormous quantities are required for cooling of products and equipment, for process needs, for boiler feed and for sanitary and potable water. Because of this solvent property, water typically contains a variety of impurities. These impurities are a source of potential trouble through deposition of the impurities in water lines, boiler tubes and on products which are contacted by it. For many purposes (e.g. industrial and drinking water applications) water undergoes a further treatment (e.g. disinfection, softening etc.) which may affect the corrosivity of the water.

Turpentine (oil) is distilled pine oil consisting of an essential oil (oil of turpentine) and a type of resin called rosin. Commercial turpentine is oil of turpentine with the rosin removed. When pure, it is a colorless, transparent, oily liquid with a penetrating odor and characteristic taste. It is a flammable liquid. Melting point: -60 °C to -50 °C. Boiling point: 150 °C 180 °C. Flash point: 35 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 253 °C. Specific gravity: 0.86. Viscosity: 1.49 cP at 20 °C. Use: Turpentine (oil) is used as a cleaner, and as a solvent or thinner for oil-based and alkyd coatings.

Water: H2O, also further identified by such terms as soft, tap, hard, distilled, fresh, etc. Specific. Gravity.: 1.0. Viscosity: 1 cP at 20 °C. Water is the most readily available liquid and one of the most difficult to handle, primarily because of its lack of lubrication, corrosive and erosive nature. Water in nature is rarely pure in the "distilled water" sense; it contains dissolved salts, buffers, nutrients, etc., with exact concentrations dependent on local conditions. Use: Enormous quantities are required for cooling of products and equipment, for process needs, for boiler feed and for sanitary and potable water. It was estimated, in 1980, that the water requirements for industry in the USA approximated 525 billion liters per day. A substantial quantity of this water was reused. The intake of "new" water was estimated to be about 140 billion liters daily. If this water was pure and contained no contaminants, there would be little need for water conditioning or water treatment. Water possesses several unique properties, one being its ability to dissolve to some degree every substance occurring on the earth's crust and in the atmosphere. Because of this solvent property, water typically contains a variety of impurities. These impurities are a source of potential trouble through deposition of the impurities in water lines, boiler tubes and on products which are contacted by it. Notes: Water becomes corrosive in the presence of dissolved oxygen. The degree of corrosivity depends on pH, temperature and salt content. For many purposes (e.g. industrial and drinking water applications) water undergoes a further treatment (e.g. disinfection, softening etc.) which may affect the corrosivity of the water.

Paraffin: white, more-or-less translucent, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid. It melts between 47 °C and 65 °C and is insoluble in water but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Specific gravity 0.83. Viscosity 24 cSt. at 55 °C and 20 cSt. at 70 °C.
Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but burns readily in air. Paraffin is obtained from petroleum during refining, it is used in candles, for coating paper, and for various other purposes.
Chemically, paraffin is a mixture of high-molecular-weight alkanes, i.e., saturated hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is an integer between 22 and 27.

Ammonium bicarbonate: A colourless to white crystalline salt with an faint ammonia odour. Releases CO2 when heated and decomposes at about 60 °C. Solubility in water 220g/l at 20 °C (decomposes in hot water). pH value about 8 (50 g/l, H2O at 20 °C). Use: Ammonium bicarbonate is used as a food additive and in baking powder. Utilized as a source of ammonia in the production of ammonium salts pharmaceuticals, pigments and dyes. Used in fire-extinguishing compounds.

Heat Transfer Liquids Mineral or synthetic hydrocarbon based heat transfer liquids (thermal stable liquids) containing effective oxidation and corrosion inhibitors. Heat transfer liquid is also known by a variety of trade names. Other Names: Heat transmission oil, thermal oil, HTO.
Specific gravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature. Viscosity: About 1-5 cSt at service temperatures. At 20 °C the viscosity typically is about 20-100 cSt.
Remarks: Heat transfer liquids are used instead of steam for transferring heat from a source to a point of use such as dies, presses, cooking vessels, processing equipment, etc. Many of them can operate at temperatures up to 315 °C. FKM elastomers are normally recommended but PTFE, FXM or FFKM may also be needed.
rdf:Description.specificGravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Heat Transfer Liquids Mineral or synthetic hydrocarbon based heat transfer liquids (thermal stable liquids) containing effective oxidation and corrosion inhibitors. Heat transfer liquid is also known by a variety of trade names. Other Names: Heat transmission oil, thermal oil, HTO.
Specific gravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature. Viscosity: About 1-5 cSt at service temperatures. At 20 °C the viscosity typically is about 20-100 cSt.
Remarks: Heat transfer liquids are used instead of steam for transferring heat from a source to a point of use such as dies, presses, cooking vessels, processing equipment, etc. Many of them can operate at temperatures up to 315 °C. FKM elastomers are normally recommended but PTFE, FXM or FFKM may also be needed.
rdf:Description.specificGravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: District heating: The provision of a public heating supply, delivered form the power plant by means of hot water in a closed circuit. After supplying heat to a building's own space heating and domestic hot water heating system, the cooled district heating water is pumped back for reheating. The district heating water is often treated. The strategy is to maintain high quality water in the system through continual filtering, deaeration and demineralisation (or softening) and to maintain the pH between 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide. The procedure requires careful monitoring of the chemistry of the system water. Demineralisation is preferable to softening because it reduces the total ionic concentration. Example of water treatment method filter demineralise or soften deaerate raise pH to 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide (NaOH)

Heavy fuel oil (HFO) is a low-grade fuel primarily used in industrial boilers and other direct source heating applications (i.e., blast furnaces). It is also used as a principal fuel in marine applications in large diesel engines.
The viscosity of heavy fuel oil is above 25 cSt at 40 °C. The flashpoint is always above 50 °C and their density is higher than 0.90.
Given its high boiling point and tar-like consistency, HFO typically requires heating before it can be moved through pipes or dispensed into a boiler or other heating vessel to be burned.
HFO is the least expensive of the refined oil fuels and can only be used by facilities that have preheating capabilities.
HFO is typically high in sulphur and other impurities that are released into the air when the fuel is burned.

Heavy fuel oil (HFO) is a low-grade fuel primarily used in industrial boilers and other direct source heating applications (i.e., blast furnaces). It is also used as a principal fuel in marine applications in large diesel engines.
The viscosity of heavy fuel oil is above 25 cSt at 40 °C. The flashpoint is always above 50 °C and their density is higher than 0.90.
Given its high boiling point and tar-like consistency, HFO typically requires heating before it can be moved through pipes or dispensed into a boiler or other heating vessel to be burned.
HFO is the least expensive of the refined oil fuels and can only be used by facilities that have preheating capabilities.
HFO is typically high in sulphur and other impurities that are released into the air when the fuel is burned.

Palmitic acid: Appearance: white chips, crystals or powder. Odor: Slight characteristic odor. Insoluble in water. Melting point: 61 °C - 64 °C Boiling point: 352 °C. Specific gravity: 0.840. Viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.
Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and a major component of solid fats. It is found in palm oil and many animal fats (milk or butterfat is 21 percent palmitic acid). Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. As an additive, palmitic acid is used in the manufacture of soap and to enhance the flavor of butter and cheese spreads.
rdf:Description.viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.

Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and a major component of solid fats. rdf:Description.viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Appearance: blue to blue-green crystals. Nickel sulfate is odorless.
Nickel sulfate is very soluble in water (about 75%). It forms a solution with a pH about 4.5
Nickel sulfate is used in electroplating, organic chemical synthesis, metal colouring, dye mordant, manufacturing other nickel salts, Ni-Cd battery.

Hexane is a colourless, highly flammable, volatile liquid. It is soluble in alcohol, acetone and ether but insoluble in water. Melting point: -95 °C. Boiling point: 69 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 234 °C. Specific gravity: 0.659. Viscosity: 0.33 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: -22 °C. Explosion limits: 1.2% - 7.7%. Use: Hexane is used as a solvent, especially as an extraction solvent for vegetable oils, also as a paint diluent and as an alcohol denaturant. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

HFC 245fa (1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane) is a non-flammable cooling agent having a boiling point slightly below room temperature. It has lower toxicity compared to most HCFCâ€™s. It is utilized in Rankine cycle applications for waste heat recovery, centrifugal chilllers for process and comfort cooling, heat transfer applications, including secondary loops in commercial refrigeration, Heat pipes and thermosiphons including electronics cooling and thermal storage applications. HFC 245fa is immiscible with water. Vapor pressure: 1.4 bar at 25 °C Boiling point: 15 °C Liquid Viscosity: 0.402 mPa s at 25 °C Density: 1.339 g/mL at 25 °C

Sodium hypochlorite: NaClO is a pale greenish liquid with chlorine odour. Also known as soda bleach or liquid bleach. Household bleaches normally contain about 5% sodium hypochlorite (about pH11), and more concentrated bleaches contain 10-15% sodium hypochlorite (about pH13).Commercial sodium hypochlorites are normally stabilised with sodium hydroxide. Sodium hypochlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as chlorine (a toxic gas) will be liberated. Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 40 °C (decomposes). Specific gravity: 1.21. pH value: 6 to 9. Use: sodium hypochlorite is used for a wide range of applications where its powerful disinfection and oxidation properties are utilised. The main application areas include: Bleaching; Formulated Disinfectants; Potable and Waste Water Treatment; Swimming Pool Water Treatment; Process and Cooling Water Treatment; Odour Control; Chemical Intermediates; etc. Sodium hypochlorite is aggressive to many metals and elastomers. Javelle water: aqueous solution of sodium or potassium hypochlorite. It was originally made near the French town of Javelle (now part of Paris) and was the first chemical bleach, a use first demonstrated by C. L. Berthollet in 1785. It was produced by passing chlorine gas through a water solution of potash (potassium carbonate). After the invention of bleaching powder Javelle water was sometimes produced by reacting the bleaching powder with potash or soda ash (sodium carbonate).

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Hydrocarbon based refrigerants: Although not well known to the general public, hydrocarbons (HC) are well established as refrigerants and were, like ammonia, used extensively in domestic and small commercial applications in the past. They have excellent refrigerant properties with thermodynamic efficiencies equal to or above chlorofluorocarbons (CFC). Operating temperatures are also comparable.HC's, in particular propane, were introduced as refrigerant in the twenties of this century and its use is being now revitalized, due to concerns of ozone depletion by the CFC's. But the flammability of the HC's is of concern too. In fact the use of HC's in small-scale applications ceased in the 1930s as a result of concerns about flammability and the invention of CFCs. Examples of commercial products are: Duracool, Enviro-Safe, HC-12a (the most common one is a mix of 79% propane and 21% isobutene) and Gilotherm D12. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Hydrochloric acid: HCl, a colourless, poisonous gas with an unpleasant, acrid odor. It is very soluble in water and readily soluble in alcohol and ether. It fumes in moist air. It is not flammable, and the liquid is a poor conductor of electricity. Hydrochloric acid is prepared commercially by the reaction of sulfuric acid with sodium chloride (common salt); niter cake, a mixture of sodium bisulfite and sulfuric acid that is a byproduct of nitric acid manufacture, is sometimes used in place of sulfuric acid. Hydrochloric acid is also produced as a byproduct of the manufacture of chlorinated organic chemicals. It can be prepared directly by reaction of hydrogen and chlorine gases; the reaction is very exothermic and takes place readily in sunlight or at elevated temperatures. Although anhydrous (water-free) hydrochloric acid is commercially available as a high-pressure compressed gas in steel cylinders, most of the gas produced is dissolved in water to form hydrochloric acid, a commercially important chemical. Pure grades of hydrochloric acid are colourless, but technical grades, commonly called muriatic acid, are often yellow-coloured because of impurities such as dissolved metals. Most hydrochloric acid produced has a concentration of 30% to 35% hydrogen chloride by weight. Use: The major use of hydrochloric acid is in the manufacture of other chemicals. It is also used in large amounts in pickling (cleaning) metal surfaces, e.g., iron before galvanizing. It reacts with most common metals, releasing hydrogen and forming the metal chloride; with most metal oxides and hydroxides it reacts to form water and the metal chloride. Hydrochloric acid is also used in small amounts in processing glucose and other foods and for various other uses. Concentrated solutions are strong acids and highly corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is not an oxidizing agent but can be oxidized by very strong oxidizing agents, liberating chlorine gas. In dilute solutions of the acid the hydrogen chloride is almost completely dissociated into hydrogen and chloride ions.

Hydrofluoric acid: A colourless, fuming, corrosive, dangerously poisonous aqueous solution of hydrogen fluoride, HF, used to etch or polish glass, pickle certain metals, and clean masonry.
Hydrogen fluoride(HF) a colourless, fuming liquid or colourless gas that boils at 20 °C. Above 19 °C, hydrogen fluoride is a gas.
Hydrofluoric acid is available with concentrations in the range of 30 - 70 % HF w/v.
Hydrofluoric acid containing 35.35% hydrogen fluoride by weight is an azeotrope with a constant boiling point of 120 °C.
Whether gaseous, liquid, or in solution, hydrogen fluoride is a dangerous chemical and must be handled with caution, since it attacks the skin and other tissue. Hydrofluoric acid attacks glass, reacting with the silica, SiO2, to form the gas silicon tetrafluoride, SiF4, and water; this leaves the surface of the glass etched.
Hydrofluoric acid is extremely potent and dangerous, and must be handled with extreme caution. It can penetrate thick, calloused skin and even fingernails, causing extensive skin burns and scarring. A major exposure to concentrated HF can bind the body's calcium stores from the bones, causing seizures, bone destruction and death. Inhaling HF fumes can lead to pneumonia. A splash of HF in the eyes can cause destruction of the eye tissues and blindness.

Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Formic acid: or methanoic acid, HCO2H, a colourless, corrosive liquid with a sharp odor.; it boils at 101 °C and solidifies at 8 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 2.2 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Note: Often used in an aqueous solution. It has the lowest molecular weight and is the simplest of the carboxylic acids. Functionally, it is both an acid and an aldehyde. Like other acids, it reacts with most alcohols to form esters and decomposes when heated; like other aldehydes, it is easily oxidized. Formic acid occurs in the bodies of red ants and in the stingers of bees. It can be made by the oxidation of formaldehyde; it is prepared commercially by heating carbon monoxide and sodium hydroxide to form sodium formate which, when carefully treated with sulfuric acid, yields formic acid. Use: Formic acid is used industrially in textile dyeing, in leather tanning, and in coagulating latex rubber.

Cosmetic grade hydrogen peroxide is suitable for dilution to low concentrations (e.g. 3%) with deionised or distilled water. Hydrogen peroxide is a clear colourless liquid. It is soluble with water in any concentration. As it decomposes into water and oxygen H2O2 does not leave any toxic residues. Hydrogen peroxide solutions themselves are non-flammable but can ignite flammable materials. Contamination with organic material such as dirt, heavy metals, salts, etc. can cause decomposition Data at 20 °C at 35% concentration: Specific gravity: 1.132. pH value (approximately): 1.7 Boiling point: 108 °C Viscosity: 1.11 cP. Data at 20 °C at 50% concentration: Specific gravity: 1.196. pH value (approximately): 1.0 Boiling point: 114 °C Viscosity: 1.17 cP. Data at 20 °C at 68% concentration: Specific gravity: 1.278. pH value (approximately): 0.2 Boiling point: 125 °C Viscosity: 1.24 cP. Hydrogen Peroxide Grades 3% Hydrogen Peroxide (Drug/Grocery Store Variety) Used as antimicrobial agent for treating wounds and sanitizing agent. [Made from 50% Super D Peroxide, Diluted. Contains stabilizers - phenol, acetanilide, sodium stanate, tetra sodium phosphate among them.] 6% Hydrogen Peroxide Used by Beauticians for colouring Hair. Used as sanitizing agent. Comes in strengths labeled 10, 20, 40 volume%. Must have activator added to be used as a bleach. Contains stabilizers, additives, and impurities dependent on manufacturing and dilution process. 30% Re-Agent Hydrogen Peroxide Used in medical research. Contains stabilizers, additives, and impurities dependent on manufacturing and dilution process. 30-32% Electronic Grade Hydrogen Peroxide Used for washing transistors and integrated chip parts before assembly. Contains stabilizers, additives, and impurities dependent on manufacturing and dilution process. 35% Food Grade Hydrogen Peroxide (Also 50% Food Grade H2O2) Used in food products like cheese, eggs, whey products. Also used to spray inside of foil-lined containers for food storage - known as the aseptic packaging system. Used for the disinfection of potable water. Also used (diluted) to disinfect, kill bacteria, sanitize wounds and introduce oxygen into the body. E.g. bathing, gargle, toothpaste, treat drinking water, etc. Contains stabilizers, additives, and impurities dependent on manufacturing and dilution process. 35% Technical Grade Hydrogen Peroxide Used for wastewater treatment and the disinfection of potable water, cosmetics, and laundry applications. Also used (diluted) to disinfect, kill bacteria, sanitize wounds and introduce oxygen into the body. E.g. bathing, gargle, toothpaste, treat drinking water, etc. [May contain a small amount of phosphorus to neutralize any chlorine in the water it is combined with.] 35% Standard Grade Hydrogen Peroxide (Also 50%, 60%, 70% Standard Grades) Used mainly for bleaching in the pulp and paper industry and in the textile industry; oxidation reactions in the chemical industry; environmental processes (detoxification and deodorization). Used for Waste water treatment. [Contains stabilizers, additives, and impurities. 90% Hydrogen Peroxide Used by the military as a source of Oxygen at Cape Canaveral. Used as a propulsion source in rocket fuel. 99.6% Hydrogen Peroxide This was first made in 1954 as an experiment to see how pure a hydrogen peroxide could be manufactured.

Phenol (C6H5OH) is a colorless, combustible, crystalline solid with a characteristic odor. Liquid water and phenol show limited miscibility below 70 °C. It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phenol is a poisonous and hazardous liquid; rapidly absorbed through the skin, causing severe burns. It is an aromatic alcohol that exhibits weak acidic properties and is corrosive and poisonous.
Melting point: about 41 °C. Boiling point: 182 °C (conc.) Flash point: 79 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 715 °C. Explosion limits: 1.5 % - 8.6 % pH of phenol water mixtures are slightly acidic (around 5-6) Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.06 (80%) and 1.07 (conc.) Viscosity at 45 °C: 3.8 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 60 °C: 2.5 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 80 °C: 1.6 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 100 °C: 1.1 cSt. (conc.)
The main use of phenol is as a feedstock for phenolic resins, bisphenol A and caprolactam (an intermediate in the production of nylon-6). It is used in the manufacture of many products including insulation materials, adhesives, lacquers, paint, rubber, ink and dyes. It is found in some commercial disinfectants, antiseptics and lotions.
The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Isopropyl alcohol or 2-propanol, (CH3)2CHOH is a colorless, highly flammable liquid with slight alcohol odour. It is a secondary alcohol that is miscible with water. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 82 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79. Viscosity: 1.77 cP at 30 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Explosion limits: 2.0 % - 12 %. Auto ignition temperature: 425 °C. Isopropyl alcohol is poisonous if taken internally. Use: Isopropyl alcohol is commonly used as an industrial solvent and as a rubbing alcohol applied to the skin. It is used in antifreeze compositions, cosmetics and in denaturing ethyl alcohol. It is one of the cheapest alcohols and has replaced ethanol for many uses because of its similar solvent properties. Although isopropyl alcohol is more toxic than ethanol, it has less of a drying effect on the skin, and it is not regulated and taxed as ethanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Melting point: 64 °C. Solubility in water 665 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3-4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used in the manufacture of inks, in wool dyeing as a mordant, and in sewage and water treatment as a substitute for aluminum sulfate. Used as a pigment, fertilizer, and feed additive, and as a medicine in the treatment of iron deficiency.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C), pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Melting point: 64 °C. Solubility in water 665 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3-4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used in the manufacture of inks, in wool dyeing as a mordant, and in sewage and water treatment as a substitute for aluminum sulfate. Used as a pigment, fertilizer, and feed additive, and as a medicine in the treatment of iron deficiency.

Ferric chloride: Dark brown liquid. Liquid solution with 35 to 40% ferric chloride in water has a specific gravity - 1.45 at 30 °C. Solubility in water 920g/l (20 °C) pH value about 1.8 (10 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Use: Ferric chloride is used principally as a flocculating agent for water treatment. It is also used in metal surface treatment as etching agent for engraving, photography and printed circuitry. Ferric chloride is sometimes used as a disinfectant. It deodourizes sewage and industrial wastes with partial reduction to ferrous chloride (FeCl2). Ferric chloride is aggressive to most metals. Pronounced tendency to crystallisation.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C) , pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Boiling point: 82 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79. Viscosity: 1.77 cP at 30 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Explosion limits: 2.0 % - 12 %. Auto ignition temperature: 425 °C. Jet fuel: A kerosene-based product used in jet engines. Flammable liquid, flash point from 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: from 300 °C to 400 °C. Jet Fuel This category comprises both gasoline and kerosene type jet fuels meeting specifications for use in aviation turbine power units. Gasoline type jet fuel This includes all light hydrocarbon oils for use in aviation turbine power units. They distill between 100 °C and 250 °C. It is obtained by blending kerosenes and gasoline or naphthas in such a way that the aromatic content does not exceed 25 per cent in volume, and the vapour pressure is between 13.7 kPa and 20.6 kPa. Additives can be included to improve fuel stability and combustibility. Kerosene type jet fuel This is medium distillate used for aviation turbine power units. It has the same distillation characteristics and flash point as kerosene (between 150 °C and 300 °C C but not generally above 250 °C. In addition, it has particular specifications (such as freezing point) which are established by the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Fruit juice: Processing fruit juices presents some special problems because the acids contained in fruits are corrosive to many metals. There also can be corrosive action from some of the preservatives used.
Viscosity: Varies from thin to thick, depending on the stage in the process and the pulp content. pH varies from about 2 for lime juice to about 7 for melon juice.
Processing of fruit juices may involve sanitary requirements, possible flushing cycles and handling of many additives and preservatives, as well as the fruit juices. Some viscosity may be involved, depending on the extent to which the juices have been concentrated.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from thin to thick, depending on the stage in the process and the pulp content.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Kerosene: A colourless, low-sulfur petroleum product that burns without producing much smoke. A complex combination of hydrocarbons including naphthenes, paraffins, and aromatics. Kerosene consists mostly of C9 through C17 hydrocarbons. Kerosene is a colourless to yellowish oily liquid with a strong characteristic odour. Flammable liquid. Flash point 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 225 °C. Specific gravity is between 0.75 - 0.85 kg/m3. Use: At one time kerosene was the most important refinery product because of its use in lamps. Now it is most noted for its use as the primary ingredient in most jet fuels and as a carrier in insecticide sprays. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Lactic acid : CH3CHOHCO2H, a colourless, odourless syrupy liquid organic acid. It is miscible with water, pH value 2.8 (10 g/l (of 90% solution), H2O, 20 °C), ethanol or glycerin. Specific Gravity: 1.2. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 122 °C. Viscosity: 40 to 100 cP.
Lactic acid is a fermentation product of lactose (milk sugar); it is present in sour milk, yoghourt, and cottage cheese. The protein in milk is coagulated (curdled) by lactic acid. Lactic acid is produced in the muscles during intense activity. Calcium lactate, a soluble lactic acid salt, is used as a source of calcium in the diet. Lactic acid is produced commercially for use in pharmaceuticals and foods, in leather tanning and textile dyeing, and in making plastics, solvents, inks, and lacquers. Other Names: Milk acid

Source: WIKIPEDIA Leachate is any liquid that, in passing through matter, extracts solutes, suspended solids or any other component of the material through which it has passed. Leachate is a widely used term in the Environmental sciences where it has the specific meaning of a liquid that has dissolved or entrained environmentally harmful substances which may then enter the environment. It is most commonly used in the context of land-filling of putrescible or industrial waste. In the narrow environmental context leachate is therefore any liquid material that drains from land or stockpiled material and contains significantly elevated concentrations of undesirable material derived from the material that it has passed through Leachate from a landfill varies widely in composition depending on the age of the landfill and the type of waste that it contains. It can usually contain both dissolved and suspended material. The generation of leachate is caused principally by precipitation percolating through waste deposited in a landfill. Once in contact with decomposing solid waste, the percolating water becomes contaminated and if it then flows out of the waste material it is termed leachate. Composition of landfill leachate When water percolates through the waste, it promotes and assists process of decomposition by bacteria and fungi. These processes in turn release by-products of decomposition and rapidly use up any available oxygen creating an anoxic environment. In actively decomposing waste the temperature rises and the pH falls rapidly and many metal ions which are relatively insoluble at neutral pH can become dissolved in the developing leachate. The decomposition processes themselves release further water which adds to the volume of leachate. Leachate also reacts with materials that are not themselves prone to decomposition such as fire ash, cement based building materials and gypsum based materials changing the chemical composition. In sites with large volumes of building waste, especially those containing gypsum plaster, the reaction of leachate with the gypsum can generate large volumes of hydrogen sulfide which may be released in the leachate and may also form a large component of the landfill gas. In a landfill that receives a mixture of municipal, commercial, and mixed industrial waste, but excludes significant amounts of concentrated specific chemical waste, landfill leachate may be characterized as a water-based solution of four groups of contaminants ; dissolved organic matter (alcohols, acids, aldehydes, short chain sugars etc.), inorganic macro components (common cations and anions including sulfate, chloride, Iron, aluminium, zinc and ammonia), heavy metals (Pb, Ni, Cu, Hg) , and xenobiotic organic compounds such as halogenated organics, (PCBs, dioxins, etc.). The physical appearance of leachate when it emerges from a typical landfill site is a strongly odoured black, yellow or orange coloured cloudy liquid. The smell is acidic and offensive and may be very pervasive because of hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur rich organic species such as mercaptans.

Linoleic acid:Colourless liquid with a specific gravity of 0.9 at 22 °C. Melting point -12 °C. Insoluble in water.
Linoleic acid is an unsaturated fatty acid, C17H31COOH, considered essential to the human diet.
Linoleic acid is an important component of drying oils, such as linseed oil.
Linoleic acid is a major constituent of many vegetable oils e.g. cottonseed, soybean, peanut, corn, sunflower seed and linseed. It is used for manufacturing of paints, coatings, emulsifiers, vitamins and as a nutrient.

LPG is a colourless, odourless gas. Normally LPG is odorised by adding an odorant prior to supply to the user, to aid the detection of any leaks). LPG is Flammable. LPG is heavier than air and has approximately half the weight of water. LPG is non-toxic but can cause suffocation. LPG expands upon release and 1 litre of liquid will form approximately 250 litres of vapour. LPG consists of propane (C3H8), butane (C4H10), or propane-butane mixtures derived from crude oil refining or natural gas fractionation. For convenience of transportation, these gases are liquefied through pressurization. Propane vaporises, changing from a liquid to a vapour when released to the atmosphere at a temperature above -42 °C and butane at 0 °C. Propane: Boiling point: -42 °C Flash point: -100 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 8.5 bar. Butane Boiling point: -1 °C. Flash point: -60 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 2.8 bar. Use: LPG is used as a fuel for domestic, industrial, agricultural, cooking, heating and drying processes. LPG can be used as an automotive fuel or as a propellant for aerosols, in addition to other specialist applications. Hazards in using liquefied petroleum gas? LPG is a flammable gas, which has the potential to create a hazard. Therefore it is important that the properties and safe handling of LPG are understood and applied in the domestic and commercial/industrial situations. Liquefied petroleum gas is stored under pressure. The gas will leak from any joint or connection, which is not sealed properly. Liquefied petroleum gas is heavier than air. Any significant leak will move downwards and stay on the ground. LPG will accumulate in any low-lying area such as depressions in the ground, drains or pits. Since LPG is stored in two phases, liquid and gaseous, there is potential for either a liquid leak or a gas leak. If the Liquefied petroleum gas leak is a gas leak it may not be seen (because LPG is colourless), except where the leak is of sufficient size to be seen shimmering in the air. When a liquid Liquefied petroleum gas leak occurs, the gas release will be seen as a patch of ice around the area of the leak, or as a jet of white liquid. This white appearance is due to the cooling effect created by the rapid expansion of the LPG liquid into a gas. The condensing atmospheric moisture makes the leak visible. In concentrated amounts and in uncontrolled conditions, liquefied petroleum gas has the potential to create a fire or an explosion.

LPG consists of propane (C3H8), butane (C4H10), or propane-butane mixtures derived from crude oil refining or natural gas fractionation. For convenience of transportation, these gases are liquefied through pressurization. Propane vaporises, changing from a liquid to a vapour when released to the atmosphere at a temperature above -42 °C and butane at 0 °C. Propane: Boiling point: -42 °C Flash point: -100 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 8.5 bar. Butane Boiling point: -1 °C. Flash point: -60 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 2.8 bar. Use: LPG is used as a fuel for domestic, industrial, agricultural, cooking, heating and drying processes. LPG can be used as an automotive fuel or as a propellant for aerosols, in addition to other specialist applications. Hazards in using liquefied petroleum gas? LPG is a flammable gas, which has the potential to create a hazard. Therefore it is important that the properties and safe handling of LPG are understood and applied in the domestic and commercial/industrial situations. Liquefied petroleum gas is stored under pressure. The gas will leak from any joint or connection, which is not sealed properly. Liquefied petroleum gas is heavier than air. Any significant leak will move downwards and stay on the ground. LPG will accumulate in any low-lying area such as depressions in the ground, drains or pits. Since LPG is stored in two phases, liquid and gaseous, there is potential for either a liquid leak or a gas leak. If the Liquefied petroleum gas leak is a gas leak it may not be seen (because LPG is colourless), except where the leak is of sufficient size to be seen shimmering in the air. When a liquid Liquefied petroleum gas leak occurs, the gas release will be seen as a patch of ice around the area of the leak, or as a jet of white liquid. This white appearance is due to the cooling effect created by the rapid expansion of the LPG liquid into a gas. The condensing atmospheric moisture makes the leak visible. In concentrated amounts and in uncontrolled conditions, liquefied petroleum gas has the potential to create a fire or an explosion.

Ammonia: Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) exists naturally in a gaseous state under atmospheric pressure and temperature. Under moderate pressure it changes easily to a liquid, becoming a gas again when the pressure is reduced.
Boiling point -33 °C at atm. pressure. Extremely soluble in water e.g. 529g/l at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.638 (at 0 °C, atm. pressure). Vapour pressure is 9 bar at 20 °C and about 20 bar at 50 °C. Viscosity: 0.3 cP at -33 °C.
Industries take advantage of this characteristic by shipping and storing liquefied ammonia in pressurized railway cars, tank trucks and cylinders of various sizes.
It is primarily used as fertilizer. It is also widely used as a refrigerant and in manufacturing nitric acid, explosives, plastics and as a solvent in the chemical laboratory.
Anhydrous ammonia is one of the most water-soluble of all gases, but it should not be confused with aqueous ammonia, which is a 15 to 30 per cent solution of ammonia in water. Generally, ammonia has good warning properties because of its characteristic pungent and irritating odour.
With rising temperature ammonia expands rapidly, increasing the internal pressure in vessels and pipes, etc. This must be considered in the design and operation of ammonia systems.

Sugar syrup: Other Names: Liquid sugar, sugar, beet sugar, cane sugar, sucrose. Formula: C12H22O11 Specific gravity: 1.1 to 1.5. Viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature. E.g 50 Brix* syrup has a viscosity of about 15 cP (21 °C). 68 Brix syrup (21 °C) has a viscosity of about 240 cP, while 76 Brix sugar (21 °C) has a viscosity of 1300 cP. Remarks: The term sugar syrup or syrup is a very broad one and is applied very generally to a number of sweet tasting carbohydrates. Use: Sugar syrups are used in food, for sweetening, in candy, preserves and jams, in making soap, pharmaceuticals, caramel, as a chemical intermediate for detergents, as an emulsifying agent in such things as plasticisers, resins, explosives, glues and insecticides. * BRIX is the measurement in percentage by weight of sucrose in pure water solution. This designation of BRIX degrees is only valid for pure sucrose solutions. Pure sucrose is extract from sugar-cane or sugar-beet.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Calcium hypochlorite: White powder with a chlorine-like odour. Normally a mixture of calcium chloride hypochlorite, CaCl(OCl); calcium hypochlorite, Ca(OCl)2; and calcium chloride, CaCl2. Calcium hypochlorite is a strong oxidiser. Solubility (wt.% in water): 217 g/l at 27 °C. Specific gravity 2.350. Sometimes called chloride of lime, it can be prepared by reacting calcium hydroxide or slaked lime, Ca(OH)2, with chlorine gas, Cl2. It is used as a strong bleaching agent, as a general disinfectant to destroy bacteria, algae, slime, fungi and other microorganisms and in making Javelle water (see Sodium hypochlorite). Use: Calcium hypochlorite is used primarily to chlorinate swimming pools, and to disinfect drinking water supplies and sewage systems. It is also used as a sanitizer in a number of food processings, commercial, institutional, and domestic applications. Bleaching powder was first produced in 1799 by Charles Tennant in Glasgow, Scotland.

LPG is a colourless, odourless gas. Normally LPG is odorised by adding an odorant prior to supply to the user, to aid the detection of any leaks). LPG is Flammable. LPG is heavier than air and has approximately half the weight of water. LPG is non-toxic but can cause suffocation. LPG expands upon release and 1 litre of liquid will form approximately 250 litres of vapour. LPG consists of propane (C3H8), butane (C4H10), or propane-butane mixtures derived from crude oil refining or natural gas fractionation. For convenience of transportation, these gases are liquefied through pressurization. Propane vaporises, changing from a liquid to a vapour when released to the atmosphere at a temperature above -42 °C and butane at 0 °C. Propane: Boiling point: -42 °C Flash point: -100 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 8.5 bar. Butane Boiling point: -1 °C. Flash point: -60 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 2.8 bar. Use: LPG is used as a fuel for domestic, industrial, agricultural, cooking, heating and drying processes. LPG can be used as an automotive fuel or as a propellant for aerosols, in addition to other specialist applications. Hazards in using liquefied petroleum gas? LPG is a flammable gas, which has the potential to create a hazard. Therefore it is important that the properties and safe handling of LPG are understood and applied in the domestic and commercial/industrial situations. Liquefied petroleum gas is stored under pressure. The gas will leak from any joint or connection, which is not sealed properly. Liquefied petroleum gas is heavier than air. Any significant leak will move downwards and stay on the ground. LPG will accumulate in any low-lying area such as depressions in the ground, drains or pits. Since LPG is stored in two phases, liquid and gaseous, there is potential for either a liquid leak or a gas leak. If the Liquefied petroleum gas leak is a gas leak it may not be seen (because LPG is colourless), except where the leak is of sufficient size to be seen shimmering in the air. When a liquid Liquefied petroleum gas leak occurs, the gas release will be seen as a patch of ice around the area of the leak, or as a jet of white liquid. This white appearance is due to the cooling effect created by the rapid expansion of the LPG liquid into a gas. The condensing atmospheric moisture makes the leak visible. In concentrated amounts and in uncontrolled conditions, liquefied petroleum gas has the potential to create a fire or an explosion.

Lubricating Oil: Three general types of lubricating oils are used today. Straight mineral oils which are produced entirely from natural "petroleum" base, synthetic oils which are derived from hydrocarbons, esters, glycols or silicones and finally "additive" oils which are petroleum oils having enhanced properties.
Those properties include slower oxidation, better corrosion inhibition, increased film strength, greater solid particle suspension, high viscosity, lower pour point and increased friction and wear properties.
Viscosity is probably the most important lube oil property. It is a measure of resistance to flow. A thick oil has high viscosity while a thin oil has low viscosity. Generally, the higher viscosity, oil has better ability to maintain the fluid film between wearing surfaces even when pressed together with great force. Viscosity is greatly affected by temperature in that the viscosity drops drastically as the temperature increases.
Viscosity Index (VI) is a measure of how viscosity changes with temperature. Viscosity improvers are used to keep the rate of change of viscosity to a minimum from low to high temperature.
