Silver nitrate, AgNO3 is a colourless crystalline material that is very soluble in water. It is darkened by sunlight or contact with organic matter such as the skin. Melting point: 212 °C. Solubility in water 2.16 kg/m3 (20 °C). Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.2. Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.5 and viscosity: 0.9 cSt. pH value 5.4 - 6.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Silver nitrate is the most important compound of silver. Use: Silver nitrate is used in the preparation of silver salts for photography, in chemical analysis, in silver plating, in inks and hair dyes, and to silver mirrors. It is used in medicine in the treatment of eye infections and gonorrhea. Taken internally silver nitrate is a poison.

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

Melting point: 250 °C. Solubility in water 710g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 6.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (26%, 20 °C): 1.2. Viscosity (26%, 20 °C): 2.4 cSt. It was first prepared from the waters of mineral springs at Epsom, England; it also occurs as the mineral epsomite. Use: Magnesium sulfate is used medicinally as a purgative, it is also used in leather tanning, mordant dyeing, fertilizers, explosives and as a filler in cotton goods and paper.

Maleic acid, or cis-butenedioic acid, is a geometric isomer of fumaric acid. Appearance: White crystals, faint acidulous odor. Specific gravity: 1.59. pH: less than 7 acidic. White crystals, dissolves readily in water and alcohol . Solubility in water 79 g/100g (25 °C). Melting point 139 °C-140 °C. At higher temperatures it forms the anhydride, which, like the acid, is irritating to the skin and toxic.
Maleic acid is a stronger organic acid, also called Cis-butenedioic Acid (HO2CCH=CHCO2H). It is an unsaturated organic dibasic acid, that is used in making polyesters for fibre-reinforced laminated moldings, paint for vehicles, and in the manufacture of fumaric acid and many other chemical products.
Maleic Acid is used in the production of insecticide (e.g. Malathion), medicine, synthetic resin and other chemicals, such as tartaric acid and malic acid. Maleic acid is also used as a mordant in dyeing.Maleic anhydride is interchangeable with the acid in most applications.

Methylethylketone (MEK) or butanone is a flammable organic solvent used in plastic industry for e.g. gums, resins and cellulose acetate. It has a sweet smell and is colorless. It is soluble in water up to 27.5 grams per 100 mL water. It is miscible with alcohols and paraffinic oils. Melting Point: -86 °C Boiling Point: 79.6 °C Flash point: -9 °C Density: 0.805 g/mL at 20 °C Viscosity: 0.43 cP at 20 °C

Methylene chloride is a colourless, volatile, practically nonflammable liquid belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Methylene chloride has a chloroform-like odor and is highly toxic and a suspected carcinogen. Its toxic effects can be exerted through inhalation, ingestion, and skin/tissue absorption. Melting point -97 °C. Boiling point 40 °C at atmospheric pressure. Flash point: none. Auto ignition temperature: 605 °C. It is denser than water and very slightly soluble in it (1.32 g/100g at 25 °C). Specific gravity: 1.32. Viscosity: 0.45 cP. at 15 °C. Dichloromethane is commercially produced along with methyl chloride, chloroform, and carbon tetrachloride by the chlorination of methane. It is an effective solvent for fats, oils, greases, and many polymeric substances; its use is favoured by low toxicity, low flammability, high stability, and ease of recovery for reuse. Use: It is extensively used as a solvent, especially in paint-stripping formulations.

Acetic acid, CH3CO2H, colourless liquid that has a characteristic pungent odor, boils at 118 °C, and is miscible with water in all proportions; it is a weak organic carboxylic acid (see carboxyl group). Glacial acetic acid is concentrated, 99.5% pure acetic acid; it solidifies at about 17 °C to a crystalline mass resembling ice. Specific gravity: 1.050. Flash point 39 °C. Auto ignition temperature 463 °C. Melting point: 17 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. pH value: 2.9 (6 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Use: Acetic acid is the major acid in vinegar; as such, it is widely used as a food preservative and condiment. For industrial use concentrated acetic acid is prepared from the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Acetic acid is also a product in the destructive distillation of wood. It reacts with other chemicals to form numerous compounds of commercial importance. These include cellulose acetate, used in making acetate rayon, nonflammable motion-picture film, lacquers, and plastics; various inorganic salts, e.g., lead, potassium, and copper acetates; and amyl, butyl, ethyl, methyl, and propyl acetates, which are used as solvents, mostly in certain quick-drying lacquers and cements. Amyl acetate is sometimes called banana oil because it has a characteristic banana odor.

Formic acid: or methanoic acid, HCO2H, a colourless, corrosive liquid with a sharp odor.; it boils at 101 °C and solidifies at 8 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 2.2 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Note: Often used in an aqueous solution. It has the lowest molecular weight and is the simplest of the carboxylic acids. Functionally, it is both an acid and an aldehyde. Like other acids, it reacts with most alcohols to form esters and decomposes when heated; like other aldehydes, it is easily oxidized. Formic acid occurs in the bodies of red ants and in the stingers of bees. It can be made by the oxidation of formaldehyde; it is prepared commercially by heating carbon monoxide and sodium hydroxide to form sodium formate which, when carefully treated with sulfuric acid, yields formic acid. Use: Formic acid is used industrially in textile dyeing, in leather tanning, and in coagulating latex rubber.

Methyl alcohol: or wood alcohol, CH3OH, a colourless, flammable liquid that is miscible with water in all proportions. Methyl alcohol is a monohydric alcohol. Melting point: -98 °C. Flash point: 11 °C. Boiling point: 67 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 464 °C. Viscosity: 0.55 cP at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.791. It reacts with certain acids to form methyl esters. Methanol is a fatal poison. Methanol is often called wood alcohol because it was once produced mostly as a byproduct of the destructive distillation of wood. It is now produced synthetically. Small internal doses, continued inhalation of the vapor, or prolonged exposure of the skin to the liquid may cause blindness. As a result, commercial use of methanol has sometimes been prohibited. Use: Methanol is used as a solvent for varnishes and lacquers, as an antifreeze, and as a gasoline extender in the production of gasohol. Large amounts of it are used in the synthesis of formaldehyde. Because of its poisonous properties, methanol is also used as a denaturant for ethanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Methyl alcohol as antifreeze: Methyl alcohol/water is an antifreeze solution used in refrigeration services and ground source heat pumps. Similar to glycols, this solution can be inhibited to stop corrosion. It can be used at temperatures as low as -40 °C owing to its relatively high heat transfer rate in this temperature range. Its main disadvantages as a heat transfer fluid are its toxicological considerations. It is considered more harmful than ethylene glycol and consequently is used only for process applications located outdoors. Methyl alcohol also is flammable and, as such, introduces a potential fire hazard where it is stored, handled or used. Auto ignition temperature: 464 °C. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Toluene is a colourless, flammable liquid. Soluble in alcohol, benzene and ether; insoluble in water. Toxic by inhalation, ingestion or by absorption through skin. Serious irritant. Melting point: -95 °C. Boiling point 111 °C. Flash point 4 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 506 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87. Viscosity: 1 cP. Toluene is obtained from coal tar and petroleum by distillation. It is used as a solvent and as a starting material for the synthesis of many compounds, including dyes and explosives. When toluene is treated with a mixture of nitric and sulfuric acids (a process known as nitration), trinitrotoluene (TNT) is produced. Use: Toluene is used in blending aviation gasoline, as a raw material for benzene phenol, as a solvent for paints, coatings, gums, resins and rubber cement. Used for making chemicals, in medicines, dyes, perfumes and as a source of toluene diisocyanates used in polyurethane resins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Methylene chloride is a colourless, volatile, practically nonflammable liquid belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Methylene chloride has a chloroform-like odor and is highly toxic and a suspected carcinogen. Its toxic effects can be exerted through inhalation, ingestion, and skin/tissue absorption. Melting point -97 °C. Boiling point 40 °C at atmospheric pressure. Flash point: none. Auto ignition temperature: 605 °C. It is denser than water and very slightly soluble in it (1.32 g/100g at 25 °C). Specific gravity: 1.32. Viscosity: 0.45 cP. at 15 °C. Dichloromethane is commercially produced along with methyl chloride, chloroform, and carbon tetrachloride by the chlorination of methane. It is an effective solvent for fats, oils, greases, and many polymeric substances; its use is favoured by low toxicity, low flammability, high stability, and ease of recovery for reuse. Use: It is extensively used as a solvent, especially in paint-stripping formulations.

Acetic acid, CH3CO2H, colourless liquid that has a characteristic pungent odor, boils at 118 °C, and is miscible with water in all proportions; it is a weak organic carboxylic acid (see carboxyl group). Glacial acetic acid is concentrated, 99.5% pure acetic acid; it solidifies at about 17 °C to a crystalline mass resembling ice. Specific gravity: 1.050. Flash point 39 °C. Auto ignition temperature 463 °C. Melting point: 17 °C. Boiling point: 118 °C. pH value: 2.9 (6 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Viscosity: 1.22 cP at 20 °C. Use: Acetic acid is the major acid in vinegar; as such, it is widely used as a food preservative and condiment. For industrial use concentrated acetic acid is prepared from the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Acetic acid is also a product in the destructive distillation of wood. It reacts with other chemicals to form numerous compounds of commercial importance. These include cellulose acetate, used in making acetate rayon, nonflammable motion-picture film, lacquers, and plastics; various inorganic salts, e.g., lead, potassium, and copper acetates; and amyl, butyl, ethyl, methyl, and propyl acetates, which are used as solvents, mostly in certain quick-drying lacquers and cements. Amyl acetate is sometimes called banana oil because it has a characteristic banana odor.

Cresol is a brownish liquid with a phenol-like odour. Melting point: 11 °C to 35 °C. Boiling point: about 20 °C. Flash point (closed cup): 86 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 550 °C - 600 °C. CSpecific gravity: 1.04 Viscosity: about 10-20 cSt. Water solubility: moderate Cresol is a mixture of the three isomeric cresols (ortho-, meta-, para-cresol). It is obtained from coal tar. Use: Mixed cresols are used as disinfectants, preservatives and wood preservatives.
No Liquid info

Calcium hydroxide: Ca(OH)2, colourless crystal or white powder. It is prepared by reacting calcium oxide (CaO, lime) with water, a process called slaking, and is also known as hydrated lime or slaked lime. Solubility in water 1.7 g/l (20 °C), pH value 12.6 (20 °C) (saturated solution). When heated above 580 °C it dehydrates, forming the oxide. Because calcium hydroxide readily reacts with carbon dioxide, CO2, to form calcium carbonate, a mixture of gases can be tested for the presence of CO2 by shaking it with limewater in a clear container; if CO2 is present, a cloudy calcium carbonate precipitate will form. Use: Like the oxide, it has many uses, e.g., in liming soil, in sugar refining, and in preparing other compounds. It is a strong base and is widely used as an inexpensive alkali, often as a suspension in water (milk of lime); it is used in leather tanning to remove hair from hides. It is used in whitewash, mortar, and plaster. It is only slightly soluble in water, about 0.2 grams per 100 cubic centimeters, so its solutions are weakly basic. Limewater is a clear, saturated water solution of calcium hydroxide. It is used in medicine to treat acid burns and as an antacid.

Mine water: Mine water consists of all water that collects in mine workings, both surface and underground, as a result of inflow from rain or surface water and groundwater seepage.
Characteristics: Corrosive and normally of low pH because of its contact with sulfur-bearing material. Mine water can have high concentrations of heavy metals, oils, and total dissolved solids as well as the temperature can be elevated. Depending on the source of the water and the regional and hydrological conditions, mine water can be a significant problem because of its enormous quantity and chemical composition. Mine water may have to be pumped continuously from the mine during operations.
Mine Water Treatment: Since mine water is often acidic, one of the most effective treatment techniques is to raise the pH by adding lime or other suitable basic chemicals. Dissovled solids can be effectively removed from the water in settling ponds, adding flocculates, or "filtering" the water with ion exchange or reverse osmosis.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Lubricating Oil: Three general types of lubricating oils are used today. Straight mineral oils which are produced entirely from natural "petroleum" base, synthetic oils which are derived from hydrocarbons, esters, glycols or silicones and finally "additive" oils which are petroleum oils having enhanced properties.
Those properties include slower oxidation, better corrosion inhibition, increased film strength, greater solid particle suspension, high viscosity, lower pour point and increased friction and wear properties.
Viscosity is probably the most important lube oil property. It is a measure of resistance to flow. A thick oil has high viscosity while a thin oil has low viscosity. Generally, the higher viscosity, oil has better ability to maintain the fluid film between wearing surfaces even when pressed together with great force. Viscosity is greatly affected by temperature in that the viscosity drops drastically as the temperature increases.
Viscosity Index (VI) is a measure of how viscosity changes with temperature. Viscosity improvers are used to keep the rate of change of viscosity to a minimum from low to high temperature.
No Info

Appearance: colourless liquid with an odour of ammonia. Melting point: 10 °C - 12 °C. Boiling point: 170 °C. Specific gravity: 1.01. Viscosity (100% conc.): 24.1 cP at 20 °C and 16.2 cP at 30 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 85 C (closed cup). Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Water solubility: 100% Ethanolamine is harmful by ingestion, inhalation or if absorbed through skin. Ethanolamine may cause severe eye, skin and respiratory irritation. Use: Ethanolamnine is used as a non-ionic detergent in dry cleaning, as cleaning agent in the electronic industry, emulsion paints, polishes and agricultural sprays and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Ethylene glycol: CH2OHCH2OH, clear, colourless, syrupy liquid. Sweet taste. Hygroscopic. Lowers freezing point of water; soluble in water, alcohol and ether. Boiling point 197 °C. Freezing point -13 °C. Flash point 116 °C. Specific Gravity: 1.10. Viscosity: 7 to 15 cP. range 50-50 mix by weight with water has viscosity of 8 cP. at 24 °C. Use: as an anti-freeze in automobiles. Ethylene glycol is the most widely used automotive cooling-system antifreeze, although methanol, ethanol, isopropyl alcohol, and propylene glycol are also used. Ethylene glycol is also used for brake fluid, in making polyester fibers, in films, as a dye solvent; used in lacquers, resins, printing inks, glue mixtures, as a solvent for waxes, resins and drugs. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.

Morpholine, a strong base is a colourless, oily, hygroscopic, volatile liquid with a characteristic amine odour. Morpholine is distributed as an anhydrous liquid and as 40% and 88% solutions with water. Melting point: -5 °C. Boiling point: 129 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 39 °C (Closed cup). Auto ignition temperature (100% conc.): 310 °C. Specific gravity: 1.0. Viscosity (100%): 2.23 cP at 20 °C. Water solubility: 100% Use: Morpholine is used as a chemical intermediate in the rubber industry, as a corrosion inhibitor (especially in boiler systems), in the synthesis of optical brighteners, pharmaceutical products, in waxes, polishes and in dyes. Morpholine causes burn to any area of contact. Harmful if swallowed, inhaled or absorbed through skin.

Hydrochloric acid: HCl, a colourless, poisonous gas with an unpleasant, acrid odor. It is very soluble in water and readily soluble in alcohol and ether. It fumes in moist air. It is not flammable, and the liquid is a poor conductor of electricity. Hydrochloric acid is prepared commercially by the reaction of sulfuric acid with sodium chloride (common salt); niter cake, a mixture of sodium bisulfite and sulfuric acid that is a byproduct of nitric acid manufacture, is sometimes used in place of sulfuric acid. Hydrochloric acid is also produced as a byproduct of the manufacture of chlorinated organic chemicals. It can be prepared directly by reaction of hydrogen and chlorine gases; the reaction is very exothermic and takes place readily in sunlight or at elevated temperatures. Although anhydrous (water-free) hydrochloric acid is commercially available as a high-pressure compressed gas in steel cylinders, most of the gas produced is dissolved in water to form hydrochloric acid, a commercially important chemical. Pure grades of hydrochloric acid are colourless, but technical grades, commonly called muriatic acid, are often yellow-coloured because of impurities such as dissolved metals. Most hydrochloric acid produced has a concentration of 30% to 35% hydrogen chloride by weight. Use: The major use of hydrochloric acid is in the manufacture of other chemicals. It is also used in large amounts in pickling (cleaning) metal surfaces, e.g., iron before galvanizing. It reacts with most common metals, releasing hydrogen and forming the metal chloride; with most metal oxides and hydroxides it reacts to form water and the metal chloride. Hydrochloric acid is also used in small amounts in processing glucose and other foods and for various other uses. Concentrated solutions are strong acids and highly corrosive. Hydrochloric acid is not an oxidizing agent but can be oxidized by very strong oxidizing agents, liberating chlorine gas. In dilute solutions of the acid the hydrogen chloride is almost completely dissociated into hydrogen and chloride ions.

Sodium nitrite is odourless, white to light yellow granules or powder. Sodium nitrite is a strong oxidizer, but it can also act as a reducing agent. Melting point: 271 °C. Solubility in water 820 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrite forms corrosion-resistant oxide coatings on iron and steel; it is used in phosphatizing and heat transfer salts. Frequently used in Vapor Corrosion Inhibitor (VCI) paper coatings. Use: Sodium nitrite is used for manufacture of dyestuffs, pharmaceuticals, used in organic synthesis, in corrosion inhibitors; photography; bleaching of flax; silk and linen; dyeing and printing of textile fabrics, etc.Sodium nitrite is also used in chemical synthesis reactions in the manufacture of organic insecticides and herbicides.

Naphtha is an low boiling fraction of petroleum i.e. intermediate product between gasoline and kerosene. Naphtha is a clear colourless, highly flammable, volatile liquid with a characteristic odor. The vapors mixed with air will explode if ignited. Naphtha is insoluble in water. Specific gravity about 0.86 to 0.89. Boiling point between 150 °C-220 °C. Flash point -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 277 °C. Use: Naphtha is used as a solvent, cleaner, and gasoline component.

Naphthalene is a colourless, crystalline, solid flammable aromatic hydrocarbon with a pungent odor. The molecular structure of naphthalene is that of two benzene rings fused together with two adjacent carbon atoms common to both rings. It is insoluble in water, somewhat soluble in ethanol, soluble in benzene, and very soluble in ether, chloroform, or carbon disulfide. There may be some tendency for crystals to form. Melting point: 80 °C. Boiling point: 218 °C. Flash point: 88 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 567 °C. Specific gravity: 1.14. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 80 °C. Explosion limits: 0.9 - 5.9% Naphthalene is obtained from coal tar, a byproduct of the coking of coal. Use:It is used in mothballs and gives them their characteristic odor. Also used as lubricant in synthetic resins and as solvent for textile chemicals. From it are prepared derivatives that are used in the preparation of dyes and as insecticides and organic solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Naphthalene is a colourless, crystalline, solid flammable aromatic hydrocarbon with a pungent odor. The molecular structure of naphthalene is that of two benzene rings fused together with two adjacent carbon atoms common to both rings. It is insoluble in water, somewhat soluble in ethanol, soluble in benzene, and very soluble in ether, chloroform, or carbon disulfide. There may be some tendency for crystals to form. Melting point: 80 °C. Boiling point: 218 °C. Flash point: 88 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 567 °C. Specific gravity: 1.14. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 80 °C. Explosion limits: 0.9 - 5.9% Naphthalene is obtained from coal tar, a byproduct of the coking of coal. Use:It is used in mothballs and gives them their characteristic odor. Also used as lubricant in synthetic resins and as solvent for textile chemicals. From it are prepared derivatives that are used in the preparation of dyes and as insecticides and organic solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Naphthalene is a colourless, crystalline, solid flammable aromatic hydrocarbon with a pungent odor. The molecular structure of naphthalene is that of two benzene rings fused together with two adjacent carbon atoms common to both rings. It is insoluble in water, somewhat soluble in ethanol, soluble in benzene, and very soluble in ether, chloroform, or carbon disulfide. There may be some tendency for crystals to form. Melting point: 80 °C. Boiling point: 218 °C. Flash point: 88 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 567 °C. Specific gravity: 1.14. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 80 °C. Explosion limits: 0.9 - 5.9% Naphthalene is obtained from coal tar, a byproduct of the coking of coal. Use:It is used in mothballs and gives them their characteristic odor. Also used as lubricant in synthetic resins and as solvent for textile chemicals. From it are prepared derivatives that are used in the preparation of dyes and as insecticides and organic solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Sodium bicarbonate: or sodium hydrogen carbonate, chemical compound, NaHCO3, a white crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as bicarbonate of soda or baking soda. It is soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 95.5 g/l (20 °C). pH value 8.35 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). NaHCO3 evolves carbon dioxide gas when heated above about 50 °C, a property made use of in baking powder, of which it is a component. It is also decomposed by most acids; the acid is neutralised and carbon dioxide is given off. Use: The major use of sodium bicarbonate is in foods, e.g., baked goods. It is used in effervescent "salts" and is sometimes used medically to correct excess stomach acidity. It is also used in several kinds of fire extinguishers.

Appearance: blue to blue-green crystals. Nickel sulfate is odorless.
Nickel sulfate is very soluble in water (about 75%). It forms a solution with a pH about 4.5
Nickel sulfate is used in electroplating, organic chemical synthesis, metal colouring, dye mordant, manufacturing other nickel salts, Ni-Cd battery.

Nitric acid: chemical compound, HNO3, colourless, highly corrosive, poisonous liquid that gives off choking fumes in moist air. It is miscible with water in all proportions. It forms an azeotrope (constant-boiling mixture) that has the composition 68% nitric acid and 32% water and that boils at 121 °C. The nitric acid of commerce is typically a solution of 52% to 68% nitric acid in water. More concentrated solutions are available. Solutions containing over 86% nitric acid are commonly called fuming nitric acid; they often have a reddish-brown colour from dissolved nitrogen oxides. It is produced mostly by oxidation of ammonia (the Ostwald process). Small amounts are produced by the treatment of sodium nitrate with sulfuric acid. Nitric acid was known to the alchemists as aqua fortis; the name is used in commerce for impure grades of it. Aqua regia is a mixture of nitric and hydrochloric acids. Nitric acid is a strong oxidizing agent. It ionizes readily in solution, forming a good conductor of electricity. It reacts with metals, oxides, and hydroxides, forming nitrate salts. Use: Main uses of nitric acid are in the preparation of fertilizers, e.g., ammonium nitrate, and explosives (e.g. nitroglycerin). It is also used in the manufacture of chemicals, e.g., in making dyes.

Linoleic acid:Colourless liquid with a specific gravity of 0.9 at 22 °C. Melting point -12 °C. Insoluble in water.
Linoleic acid is an unsaturated fatty acid, C17H31COOH, considered essential to the human diet.
Linoleic acid is an important component of drying oils, such as linseed oil.
Linoleic acid is a major constituent of many vegetable oils e.g. cottonseed, soybean, peanut, corn, sunflower seed and linseed. It is used for manufacturing of paints, coatings, emulsifiers, vitamins and as a nutrient.

Stearic acid: A colourless, odorless, waxlike saturated fatty acid, CH3(CH2)16COOH, almost insoluble in water (less than 0.1%).
Melting point: 69 °C. Boiling point: 383 °C. Flash point: 196 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 395 °C. Specific gravity 0.87
Stearic acid is also called octedacanoic acid, and it is one of the most common long-chain fatty acids, found in combined form in natural animal and vegetable fats. Commercial "stearic acid" is a mixture of approximately equal amounts of stearic and palmitic acids and small amounts of oleic acid. It is employed in the manufacture of candles, cosmetics, shaving soaps, lubricants, and pharmaceuticals.
In nature stearic acid occurs primarily as a mixed triglyceride, or fat, with other long-chain acids and as an ester of a fatty alcohol. It is much more abundant in animal fat than in vegetable fat; lard and tallow often contain up to 30 percent stearic acid.
Alkaline hydrolysis, or saponification, of fats yields soaps, which are the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Pure stearic acid is obtained with difficulty from such a mixture by crystallization, vacuum distillation, or chromatography of the acids or suitable derivatives. The pure acid undergoes chemical reactions typical of carboxylic acids.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Appearance: pale yellow viscous liquid.
Melting point: -10 °C. Boiling point: 313 °C. Flash point: about 235 °C. Specific gravity: 0.96. Viscosity: 44 cPs. to 660 cPs. Auto ignition temperature: about 450 °C. Water solubility: negligible.
Castor Oil is a triglyceride (ester) of fatty acid extracted from plants. It has the advantage over other mineral oils that it is a renewable resource. Castor oil is bio-degradable and eco-friendly. Many derivatives can be produced which have a similar chemical composition to petroleum based oils.
There are many uses for castor oil and its derivatives. Some of these include: lubricants, greases and hydraulic fluids, plastics, textiles and textile finishing materials, paints and varnishes, cosmetics and hair oils, inks, adhesives, synthetic resins, fibres, plasticizers, fungi static (fungus-growth-inhibiting) compounds and soaps.

Corn oil: Melting point -20 °C. Specific gravity 0.910. Viscosity about 32 cSt. at 54 °C.
A pale yellow liquid obtained from the embryos of corn grains, used especially as a cooking and salad oil and in the manufacture of margarine.

Crude oil: Flammable liquid varying in colour from yellow to dark reddish-brown, has a peculiar heavy odor. Specific gravity ranges from 0.78 to 0.97. Viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP. Some crudes have to be heated before they can be easily handle. Crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons that exists as a liquid in natural underground reservoirs and remains liquid at atmospheric pressure after passing through surface separating facilities. It consists predominately of paraffins, cyclo-paraffins, cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons having carbon numbers greater than C1. Crude oil may also contain small amounts of benzene, hydrocarbons, oxygenated compounds, sulfur, naphthenic acid and numerous chemicals introduced during the production of the crude. Crude oil is the raw material which is refined into gasoline, heating oil, jet fuel, propane, petrochemicals and other products. Sour crude oil: Crude oil with a high sulphur content. Sweet crude oil: Crude oil with a low sulphur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Diesel fuel: Diesel fuel is principally a blend of petroleum-derived compounds called middle distillates (heavier than gasoline but lighter than lubricating oil) and may or may not contain additional additives. Molecular formula: Depends upon formulation, typically composed of a hydrocarbon mix (mostly ranging from C10 to C22). Flash point of 48 °C to 72 °C. Auto ignition temperature: about 200 °C. During the operation of a diesel engine, diesel fuel is injected into the compressed, high-temperature air in the combustion chamber where it ignites spontaneously. The important properties of diesel fuels are volatility, heating value, ignition quality, viscosity, low-temperature flow, storage stability, component compatibility, and sulfur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Heat Transfer Liquids Mineral or synthetic hydrocarbon based heat transfer liquids (thermal stable liquids) containing effective oxidation and corrosion inhibitors. Heat transfer liquid is also known by a variety of trade names. Other Names: Heat transmission oil, thermal oil, HTO.
Specific gravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature. Viscosity: About 1-5 cSt at service temperatures. At 20 °C the viscosity typically is about 20-100 cSt.
Remarks: Heat transfer liquids are used instead of steam for transferring heat from a source to a point of use such as dies, presses, cooking vessels, processing equipment, etc. Many of them can operate at temperatures up to 315 °C. FKM elastomers are normally recommended but PTFE, FXM or FFKM may also be needed.
rdf:Description.specificGravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature.

Straight mineral oils which are produced entirely from natural "petroleum" base, synthetic oils which are derived from hydrocarbons, esters, glycols or silicones and finally "additive" oils which are petroleum oils having enhanced properties.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Olive oil: Pale yellow oil obtained from the pulp of olives by separating the liquids from solids. Olive oil was used in the ancient world for lighting, in the preparation of food, and as an anointing oil for both ritual and cosmetic purposes. It is produced mainly in Algeria, Greece, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Spain, Tunisia, and Turkey. The characteristics of the oil vary with the climate, cultivation, and variety of olive. Olive oil is one of the most digestible of the edible oils. To make the finest, or extra-virgin olive oil, the fruit is gathered when fully ripened, ground to a paste under granite or steel millstones, layered over straw mats, and pressed in a hydraulic press. Today, most olive oil is produced by just one pressing. The resulting oil is separated from the juice by settling or by centrifuge and then filtered. Olive oil of good quality is ready to use, without further refinement. Use: Although olive oil is chiefly used as a food or in food preservation, it is also used in soaps, certain pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics.

Peanut oil: Melting point about 3 °C. Specific gravity 0.91. Viscosity about 47 cSt. at 38 °C.
Among edible vegetable oils, peanut oil is exceeded in world production only by soybean. In extracting the oil in the U.S., the cleaned nuts are passed through hullers or shellers to separate the kernels. The kernels, which contain 48 to 56 percent of oil, are then crushed, heated and pressed hot in hydraulic presses.
The oil is used in the manufacture of margarine and shortenings, and as a salad and cooking oil, in soaps, and as a solvent for pharmaceutical preparations. The press cake is used for cattle food.

Specific gravity about 1.0. Commercially available in a range of viscosities from 1 cSt. to several thousand cSt.
Silicones are polymers in which organics groups, such as methyl and phenyl groups are bonded to the silicone atoms in chains of inorganic siloxanes (-Si-O-Si-).
Silicone oils have low surface tension, defoaming properties, excellent gloss and film properties, thermal and oxidative stability, and exhibit excellent viscosity stability over a wide temperature range. Silicone oils are also chemically inert to most common materials of construction and have low flammability.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Specific gravity about 1.0. Commercially available in a range of viscosities from 1 cSt. to several thousand cSt.

Silicone oils have low surface tension, defoaming properties, excellent gloss and film properties, thermal and oxidative stability, and exhibit excellent viscosity stability over a wide temperature range. Silicone oils are also chemically inert to most common materials of construction and have low flammability.

Melting point -16 °C. Specific gravity 0.93 - 0.98. Viscosity about 40 cSt. at 38 °C and 73 cSt at 20 °C.
Soybean oil is the world's most widely used edible oil. In the United States, soybean oil accounts for nearly 80% of edible oil consumption. Soybean oil is one of the few non-fish oils containing linolenic acid, an omega-3 fatty acid that has been shown to help prevent heart disease.
Almost all margarine and shortenings contain soybean oil. It also is frequently found in mayonnaise, salad dressings, frozen foods, imitation dairy, meat products and commercially baked goods.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Olive oil: Pale yellow oil obtained from the pulp of olives by separating the liquids from solids. Olive oil was used in the ancient world for lighting, in the preparation of food, and as an anointing oil for both ritual and cosmetic purposes. It is produced mainly in Algeria, Greece, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Spain, Tunisia, and Turkey. The characteristics of the oil vary with the climate, cultivation, and variety of olive. Olive oil is one of the most digestible of the edible oils. To make the finest, or extra-virgin olive oil, the fruit is gathered when fully ripened, ground to a paste under granite or steel millstones, layered over straw mats, and pressed in a hydraulic press. Today, most olive oil is produced by just one pressing. The resulting oil is separated from the juice by settling or by centrifuge and then filtered. Olive oil of good quality is ready to use, without further refinement. Use: Although olive oil is chiefly used as a food or in food preservation, it is also used in soaps, certain pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics.

Phosphoric acid: H3PO4, a common acid of phosphorus that is the source of industrially important compounds called phosphates. At room temperature, phosphoric acid is a crystalline material with a specific gravity of 1.83. The solid melts at 42 °C. Soluble in water, pH value below 0.5 (100 g/l (of 85% solution), H2O, 20 °C). Phosphoric acid is normally stored and sold as a solution. Phosphoric acid is made by treating calcium phosphate rock with sulphuric acid, followed by filtration of the resultant liquid to remove calcium sulfate. It can be prepared also by burning phosphorus vapour and treating the resulting oxide with steam. Use: The acid is useful in the laboratory because of its resistance to oxidation, to reduction, and to evaporation. Phosphoric acid has found many uses e.g. as an ingredient in soft drinks and dental cements, as a catalyst, in pickling and rustproofing metals, and in making phosphates, which are used in water softeners, fertilisers, and detergents.

Oxalic acid or ethanedioic acid, HO2CCO2H, is a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 102 °C with sublimation. Solubility in water 102 g/l (20 °C) pH value 0.7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Oxalic acid and oxalate salts are poisonous. Oxalic acid is found in many plants, e.g., sorrel and rhubarb, normally as its calcium or potassium salts.
Oxalic acid is the only possible compound in which two carboxyl groups are joined directly; for this reason oxalic acid is one of the strongest organic acids. Unlike other carboxylic acids (except formic acid), it is readily oxidized. This makes it useful as a reducing agent for photography, bleaching, and ink removal.

Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Ozonation is the process of feeding ozone into a water supply for the purpose of decolorization, deodorization, disinfection and oxidation. Ozone, a form of oxygen, is the most powerful disinfectant, but it is not effective in controlling biological contaminants in the distribution pipes because it does not have a long-lasting residual. Ozonation destroys bacteria and viruses and requires a shorter time period to treat water than most other water treatment methods. Ozone, a reactive gas, is made by subjecting oxygen to high electrical voltages. Ozone's reactive nature allows it to readily react with and break up many organic compounds and kill bacteria and other organisms in the water supply. On-site production of ozone is energy-intensive. Ozone treatment is becoming more common in the United States as questions arise about disinfection byproducts. Ozone has been widely used in Europe for 100 years.
Typical values: Bottled water, drinking water, swimming pool spa water purification: less than 1 ppm. Cleaning: less than 10 ppm. Semiconductor industry, pharmaceutical industry: less than 100 ppm

Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Palmitic acid: Appearance: white chips, crystals or powder. Odor: Slight characteristic odor. Insoluble in water. Melting point: 61 °C - 64 °C Boiling point: 352 °C. Specific gravity: 0.840. Viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.
Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and a major component of solid fats. It is found in palm oil and many animal fats (milk or butterfat is 21 percent palmitic acid). Glycerides of palmitic acid occur widely in plant and animal oils and fats. As an additive, palmitic acid is used in the manufacture of soap and to enhance the flavor of butter and cheese spreads.
rdf:Description.viscosity: several hundred cP., depending on the specific acid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Paraffin: white, more-or-less translucent, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid. It melts between 47 °C and 65 °C and is insoluble in water but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Specific gravity 0.83. Viscosity 24 cSt. at 55 °C and 20 cSt. at 70 °C.
Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but burns readily in air. Paraffin is obtained from petroleum during refining, it is used in candles, for coating paper, and for various other purposes.
Chemically, paraffin is a mixture of high-molecular-weight alkanes, i.e., saturated hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is an integer between 22 and 27.

Paraffin: white, more-or-less translucent, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid. It melts between 47 °C and 65 °C and is insoluble in water but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Specific gravity 0.83. Viscosity 24 cSt. at 55 °C and 20 cSt. at 70 °C.
Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but burns readily in air. Paraffin is obtained from petroleum during refining, it is used in candles, for coating paper, and for various other purposes.
Chemically, paraffin is a mixture of high-molecular-weight alkanes, i.e., saturated hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is an integer between 22 and 27.

Peanut oil: Melting point about 3 °C. Specific gravity 0.91. Viscosity about 47 cSt. at 38 °C.
Among edible vegetable oils, peanut oil is exceeded in world production only by soybean. In extracting the oil in the U.S., the cleaned nuts are passed through hullers or shellers to separate the kernels. The kernels, which contain 48 to 56 percent of oil, are then crushed, heated and pressed hot in hydraulic presses.
The oil is used in the manufacture of margarine and shortenings, and as a salad and cooking oil, in soaps, and as a solvent for pharmaceutical preparations. The press cake is used for cattle food.

This heat transfer fluid for cooling applications is a non-flammable solution. The composition is based on two specific salts in water solution (potassium acetate and potassium formate). Specially formulated corrosion inhibitors are added.
pH-value: 9 - 11.

Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Tetrachloroethylene: Also called Perchloroethylene, a colourless, dense, nonflammable, highly stable liquid with ether-like odour belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Tetrachloroethylene is denser than water and practically insoluble in it. Boiling point: 121 °C. Specific gravity: 1.62. Viscosity: 0.89 cP at 25 °C Tetrachloroethylene was first prepared in 1821 by the English physicist Michael Faraday; it has been commercially manufactured since about 1910, mostly from trichloroethylene. Use: Tetrachloroethylene is a powerful solvent for many organic substances. By the mid-20th century it had become the most widely used solvent in dry cleaning (displacing carbon tetrachloride and trichloroethylene) and was also commonly used for cleaning metal objects in vapour-degreasing apparatuses. Its broad acceptance has been based upon its nonflammability and low toxicity. Small quantities are also employed as a vermifuge, particularly against hookworm. However tetrachloroethylene is harmful if inhaled, ingested or in contact with skin.

Source: WIKIPEDIA Leachate is any liquid that, in passing through matter, extracts solutes, suspended solids or any other component of the material through which it has passed. Leachate is a widely used term in the Environmental sciences where it has the specific meaning of a liquid that has dissolved or entrained environmentally harmful substances which may then enter the environment. It is most commonly used in the context of land-filling of putrescible or industrial waste. In the narrow environmental context leachate is therefore any liquid material that drains from land or stockpiled material and contains significantly elevated concentrations of undesirable material derived from the material that it has passed through Leachate from a landfill varies widely in composition depending on the age of the landfill and the type of waste that it contains. It can usually contain both dissolved and suspended material. The generation of leachate is caused principally by precipitation percolating through waste deposited in a landfill. Once in contact with decomposing solid waste, the percolating water becomes contaminated and if it then flows out of the waste material it is termed leachate. Composition of landfill leachate When water percolates through the waste, it promotes and assists process of decomposition by bacteria and fungi. These processes in turn release by-products of decomposition and rapidly use up any available oxygen creating an anoxic environment. In actively decomposing waste the temperature rises and the pH falls rapidly and many metal ions which are relatively insoluble at neutral pH can become dissolved in the developing leachate. The decomposition processes themselves release further water which adds to the volume of leachate. Leachate also reacts with materials that are not themselves prone to decomposition such as fire ash, cement based building materials and gypsum based materials changing the chemical composition. In sites with large volumes of building waste, especially those containing gypsum plaster, the reaction of leachate with the gypsum can generate large volumes of hydrogen sulfide which may be released in the leachate and may also form a large component of the landfill gas. In a landfill that receives a mixture of municipal, commercial, and mixed industrial waste, but excludes significant amounts of concentrated specific chemical waste, landfill leachate may be characterized as a water-based solution of four groups of contaminants ; dissolved organic matter (alcohols, acids, aldehydes, short chain sugars etc.), inorganic macro components (common cations and anions including sulfate, chloride, Iron, aluminium, zinc and ammonia), heavy metals (Pb, Ni, Cu, Hg) , and xenobiotic organic compounds such as halogenated organics, (PCBs, dioxins, etc.). The physical appearance of leachate when it emerges from a typical landfill site is a strongly odoured black, yellow or orange coloured cloudy liquid. The smell is acidic and offensive and may be very pervasive because of hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur rich organic species such as mercaptans.

Peracetic Acid (PAA): CH3CO3H, slightly yellow liquid easy to volatise and easily soluble in water, ethanol and ethyl ether. It is unstable and easy to decompose. Soluble in water pH value: About 1. Melting point: -44 °C. Boiling point: 105 °C (explodes) Flash point: 41 °C. Specific gravity: Depends on concentration.
Peracetic acid is the result of a reaction between hydrogen peroxide and acetic acid (stabilised solution of about 25% H2O2 in acetic acid). Peracetic acid solutions have a pungent odour and should be used in a well ventilated area. Concentrated solutions are strong oxidisers and can be corrosive to the skin.
Peracetic acid is a very effective oxidant and disinfecting agent against all micro-organisms, including bacterial spores. It is effective over a wide pH range and is applied in cool or warm water. It is largely used in the disinfection of wastewater, in the sterilisation of industrial plants and industrial laundries pharmaceutical room, drinking water, environment, medical treatment and sanitation and as oxidant in organic synthesis.
PAA is used for bleaching in the pulp industry and for dye fixation in the textile industry.

Petrol (gasoline): A refined petroleum product used as fuel for reciprocating engines, primarily automobiles. Formula varies between C6H14 and C10H22. Specific Gravity: 0.75. Viscosity: Thin. Highly flammable liquid, flash point: -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 260 °C to 460 °C. Petrol is a mixture of volatile hydrocarbons suitable for operation of internal combustion engines. Petrol intended for use in engines is rated by octane number, an index of quality that reflects the ability of the fuel to resist detonation and burn evenly when subjected to high pressures and temperatures inside an engine. Petrol is also used as a solvent. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Kerosene: A colourless, low-sulfur petroleum product that burns without producing much smoke. A complex combination of hydrocarbons including naphthenes, paraffins, and aromatics. Kerosene consists mostly of C9 through C17 hydrocarbons. Kerosene is a colourless to yellowish oily liquid with a strong characteristic odour. Flammable liquid. Flash point 38 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 225 °C. Specific gravity is between 0.75 - 0.85 kg/m3. Use: At one time kerosene was the most important refinery product because of its use in lamps. Now it is most noted for its use as the primary ingredient in most jet fuels and as a carrier in insecticide sprays. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Crude oil: Flammable liquid varying in colour from yellow to dark reddish-brown, has a peculiar heavy odor. Specific gravity ranges from 0.78 to 0.97. Viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP. Some crudes have to be heated before they can be easily handle. Crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons that exists as a liquid in natural underground reservoirs and remains liquid at atmospheric pressure after passing through surface separating facilities. It consists predominately of paraffins, cyclo-paraffins, cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons having carbon numbers greater than C1. Crude oil may also contain small amounts of benzene, hydrocarbons, oxygenated compounds, sulfur, naphthenic acid and numerous chemicals introduced during the production of the crude. Crude oil is the raw material which is refined into gasoline, heating oil, jet fuel, propane, petrochemicals and other products. Sour crude oil: Crude oil with a high sulphur content. Sweet crude oil: Crude oil with a low sulphur content. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies, depending on oil field source. Can range from 8 cP. to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Naphtha is an low boiling fraction of petroleum i.e. intermediate product between gasoline and kerosene. Naphtha is a clear colourless, highly flammable, volatile liquid with a characteristic odor. The vapors mixed with air will explode if ignited. Naphtha is insoluble in water. Specific gravity about 0.86 to 0.89. Boiling point between 150 °C-220 °C. Flash point -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 277 °C. Use: Naphtha is used as a solvent, cleaner, and gasoline component.

Naphtha is an low boiling fraction of petroleum i.e. intermediate product between gasoline and kerosene. Naphtha is a clear colourless, highly flammable, volatile liquid with a characteristic odor. The vapors mixed with air will explode if ignited. Naphtha is insoluble in water. Specific gravity about 0.86 to 0.89. Boiling point between 150 °C-220 °C. Flash point -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 277 °C. Use: Naphtha is used as a solvent, cleaner, and gasoline component.

The vapors mixed with air will explode if ignited. Naphtha is insoluble in water. Specific gravity about 0.86 to 0.89. Boiling point between 150 °C-220 °C. Flash point -40 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 277 °C. Use: Naphtha is used as a solvent, cleaner, and gasoline component.

Phenol (C6H5OH) is a colorless, combustible, crystalline solid with a characteristic odor. Liquid water and phenol show limited miscibility below 70 °C. It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phenol is a poisonous and hazardous liquid; rapidly absorbed through the skin, causing severe burns. It is an aromatic alcohol that exhibits weak acidic properties and is corrosive and poisonous.
Melting point: about 41 °C. Boiling point: 182 °C (conc.) Flash point: 79 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 715 °C. Explosion limits: 1.5 % - 8.6 % pH of phenol water mixtures are slightly acidic (around 5-6) Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.06 (80%) and 1.07 (conc.) Viscosity at 45 °C: 3.8 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 60 °C: 2.5 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 80 °C: 1.6 cSt. (conc.) Viscosity at 100 °C: 1.1 cSt. (conc.)
The main use of phenol is as a feedstock for phenolic resins, bisphenol A and caprolactam (an intermediate in the production of nylon-6). It is used in the manufacture of many products including insulation materials, adhesives, lacquers, paint, rubber, ink and dyes. It is found in some commercial disinfectants, antiseptics and lotions.
The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Aniline: Colourless, combustible oily liquid with an pleasant and weakly amine odour. Darkens on exposure to light or air. A primary aromatic amine, a weak base which forms salts with mineral acids. Aniline is highly soluble in water (36 g/l (20 °C), pH value 8.8). Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 184 °C. Specific gravity: 1.082 Viscosity: 4.4 cP at 20 °C. Flash point: 70 °C. Explosion limits: 1.3 - 11%. Auto ignition temperature: 615 °C. Highly toxic. Possible carcinogenic. Aniline was first obtained in 1826 by the destructive distillation of indigo. Its name is taken from the specific name of the indigo-yielding plant Indigofera anil (Indigofera suffruticosa). In acidic solution, nitrous acid converts aniline into a diazonium salt that is an intermediate in the preparation of a great number of dyes and other organic compounds of commercial interest. When aniline is heated with organic acids, it gives amides, called anilides, such as acetanilide from aniline and acetic acid. Use: Aniline is used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and elastomer chemicals. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Benzoic acid: C6H5CO2H, crystalline solid organic acid that melts at 122 °C and boils at 249 °C. Solubility in water 3.4 g/l (20 °C), pH value 2.5 - 3.5 (2.9 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid. In addition to being synthesized from a variety of organic compounds (e.g., benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, toluene, and phthalic acid), it may be obtained from resins, notably gum benzoin. Use: It is used largely for making its salts and esters, most notably sodium benzoate, which is widely used as a preservative in foods and beverages and as a mild antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.

It is soluble up to around 8% and then again from around 80 °C. Phenol is sometimes called carbolic acid, especially when in water solution. Phosphoric acid: H3PO4, a common acid of phosphorus that is the source of industrially important compounds called phosphates. At room temperature, phosphoric acid is a crystalline material with a specific gravity of 1.83. The solid melts at 42 °C. Soluble in water, pH value below 0.5 (100 g/l (of 85% solution), H2O, 20 °C). Phosphoric acid is normally stored and sold as a solution. Phosphoric acid is made by treating calcium phosphate rock with sulphuric acid, followed by filtration of the resultant liquid to remove calcium sulfate. It can be prepared also by burning phosphorus vapour and treating the resulting oxide with steam. Use: The acid is useful in the laboratory because of its resistance to oxidation, to reduction, and to evaporation. Phosphoric acid has found many uses e.g. as an ingredient in soft drinks and dental cements, as a catalyst, in pickling and rustproofing metals, and in making phosphates, which are used in water softeners, fertilisers, and detergents.

Specific gravity about 1.0. Commercially available in a range of viscosities from 1 cSt. to several thousand cSt.
Silicones are polymers in which organics groups, such as methyl and phenyl groups are bonded to the silicone atoms in chains of inorganic siloxanes (-Si-O-Si-).
Silicone oils have low surface tension, defoaming properties, excellent gloss and film properties, thermal and oxidative stability, and exhibit excellent viscosity stability over a wide temperature range. Silicone oils are also chemically inert to most common materials of construction and have low flammability.

Swimming pool water: The common chemicals in pool and spa water can be sorted in to three distinct groups 1 Chemicals used to disinfect the water. 2 Chemicals that affect the water "balance". 3 Residual chemicals.
Group No 1 includes Chlorine, Bromine, or any other disinfecting chemical used. Group No 2 includes pH, Total Alkalinity and Calcium Hardness. Group No 3 includes Cyanuric Acid, Sulpahates, and Chlorides.
Acceptable Chemical levels: pH value about 7.4, Free Chlorine 1.5-5mg/l, Combined Chlorine max 1.0 mg/l, Chlorides max 600 ppm (mg/l).

Potassium carbonate K2CO3, a transparent, white, deliquescent, granular powder that forms a strongly alkaline water solution. Specific Gravity: 2.29. Solubility in water 1120g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 - 12.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting Point: 891 °C. It is available commercially as a white, granular powder commonly called potash, or pearl ash. It was originally obtained from wood ashes or from the residue left in pots after certain plants, e.g., kelp, were burned in them. Use: It is used in the manufacture of soft soaps, enamels and glass, for washing wool, in liquid automatic dishwashing, fertilizer markets and in the production of other potassium compounds.

Potassium acetate: Solubility in water 2530 g/l (20 °C) pH value 7.5 - 8.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Potassium acetate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols).Potassium acetate is highly effective as antifreeze. It exerts much lower BOD-effects (Biological Oxygen Demand), and it offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

This heat transfer fluid for cooling applications is a non-flammable solution. The composition is based on two specific salts in water solution (potassium acetate and potassium formate). Specially formulated corrosion inhibitors are added.
pH-value: 9 - 11.

Potassium bicarbonate, KHCO3 is colourless, odourless, transparent crystals or white powder with a slightly alkaline, salty taste. Decomposes between 100 °C and 120 °C. Specific gravity 2.17. Solubility in water 224g/l (20 °C). pH value 8 - 8.6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Commonly used in baking powders, soft drinks, medicines (antacid), in the manufacture of pure potassium carbonate, fire-extinguishing agents, low pH liquid detergents, laboratory reagents, and as a food additive.

Potassium dichromate, K2Cr2O7, a bright yellowish-red crystalline compound. Melting point: 398 °C. Boiling point: 500 °C. Solubility in water 130g/l (20 °C) pH value 3.6 (100 g/l, H2O) and 4.0 (10 g/l, H2O) Specific gravity: 2.676. Hexavalent chromium compounds are generally more toxic than trivalent chromium compounds. May be fatal if absorbed through the skin, if swallowed or inhaled. Contains chromium (VI), a known cancer hazard. Use:Used as an oxidizing agent, and in pyrotechnics, explosives, and safety matches.

Potassium carbonate K2CO3, a transparent, white, deliquescent, granular powder that forms a strongly alkaline water solution. Specific Gravity: 2.29. It was originally obtained from wood ashes or from the residue left in pots after certain plants, e.g., kelp, were burned in them. Use: It is used in the manufacture of soft soaps, enamels and glass, for washing wool, in liquid automatic dishwashing, fertilizer markets and in the production of other potassium compounds.

Potassium cyanide is a white crystalline solid. It is very soluble in water (about 60% at 20 °C) and forms a strong alkaline solution with a faint bitter almond odor. It is a poison that reacts with acid, acid salts or carbon dioxide to liberate extremely toxic hydrogen cyanide (HCN) gas.
Cyanide itself is an ion (CN-). It is a powerful and rapid-acting poison.
Sodium cyanide and potassium cyanide are examples of simple cyanide salts. Cyanide salts are mainly used in electroplating, metallurgy, and the production of organic chemicals; in photographic development; as anti-caking agents in road salts; in the extraction of gold and silver from ores; and in the making of plastics.
Of the cyanide compounds, sodium cyanide and potassium cyanide are the most likely to be found in the environment from industrial activities.

Potassium dichromate, K2Cr2O7, a bright yellowish-red crystalline compound. Melting point: 398 °C. Boiling point: 500 °C. Solubility in water 130g/l (20 °C) pH value 3.6 (100 g/l, H2O) and 4.0 (10 g/l, H2O) Specific gravity: 2.676. Hexavalent chromium compounds are generally more toxic than trivalent chromium compounds. May be fatal if absorbed through the skin, if swallowed or inhaled. Contains chromium (VI), a known cancer hazard. Use:Used as an oxidizing agent, and in pyrotechnics, explosives, and safety matches.
