Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium hydroxide: Chemical compound with the formula KOH. Pure potassium hydroxide forms white, deliquescent crystals. Solubility in water 1100 g/l (20 °C). pH value >13.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). pH value 12 (0.05% aqueous solution) and 14 (5% solution). Specific gravity 1.2 (20% aqueous solution) and 1500 kg/m3 (50% aqueous solution).
For commercial and laboratory use it is normally in the form of white pellets. A strong base, it dissolves readily in water, giving off much heat and forming a strongly alkaline caustic solution. It is commonly called caustic potash. It closely resembles sodium hydroxide in its chemical properties and has similar uses, e.g., in making soap, in bleaching, and in manufacturing chemicals, but is less widely used because of its higher cost. It is prepared chiefly by electrolysis of potassium chloride. Commercial grades of potassium hydroxide sometimes contain the chloride as well as other impurities.

Potassium bicarbonate, KHCO3 is colourless, odourless, transparent crystals or white powder with a slightly alkaline, salty taste. Decomposes between 100 °C and 120 °C. Specific gravity 2.17. Solubility in water 224g/l (20 °C). pH value 8 - 8.6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Commonly used in baking powders, soft drinks, medicines (antacid), in the manufacture of pure potassium carbonate, fire-extinguishing agents, low pH liquid detergents, laboratory reagents, and as a food additive.

Potassium hydroxide: Chemical compound with the formula KOH. Pure potassium hydroxide forms white, deliquescent crystals. Solubility in water 1100 g/l (20 °C). pH value >13.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). pH value 12 (0.05% aqueous solution) and 14 (5% solution). Specific gravity 1.2 (20% aqueous solution) and 1500 kg/m3 (50% aqueous solution).
For commercial and laboratory use it is normally in the form of white pellets. A strong base, it dissolves readily in water, giving off much heat and forming a strongly alkaline caustic solution. It is commonly called caustic potash. It closely resembles sodium hydroxide in its chemical properties and has similar uses, e.g., in making soap, in bleaching, and in manufacturing chemicals, but is less widely used because of its higher cost. It is prepared chiefly by electrolysis of potassium chloride. Commercial grades of potassium hydroxide sometimes contain the chloride as well as other impurities.

Potassium perchlorate:colourless crystals or white powder. Strong oxidiser, but less reactive than the chlorate. Only slightly soluble in water. Melting point (decomposes): 610 °C. Specific gravity: 2.02. Solubility in water 17 g/l (20 °C). pH-value: 5.0 - 7.0 (10 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Perchlorates are safer to handle than chlorates; they are more stable when exposed to heat or shock. Use: Potassium perchlorate, KClO4, is perhaps most widely used, e.g., in matches, fireworks, explosives and automotive safety air bags.

Potassium permanganate, KMnO4 a purple-black, crystalline compound that forms deep purple, aqueous solutions. Melting point: 150 °C(decoposes). Specific gravity: 2.7. Solubility in water 64 g/l (20 °C). pH value 7 - 9 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Harmful by inhalation, ingestion and through skin absorption. Irritant. Readily absorbed through skin. Use: Potassium permanganate is used in the chemical laboratory as a powerful oxidizing agent and in medicine as an antiseptic and disinfectant.

Potassium sulfate, K2SO4, a odourless, bitter, colourless or white crystalline compound. Melting point: 1070 °C. Solubility in water 110 g/l (20 °C) and 240g/l (100 °C). pH of 5% solution 5.5-8.5 (20 °C). Use: Potassium sulfate is used in glassmaking and fertilizers and as a reagent in analytical chemistry.

In filtration processes, the part of a solution that does not cross the membrane is termed the retentate or reject water. Depending on the filtered media and the pore size of the membrane the retentate will contain various substances.
In desalination the retentate will, besides other less important ions corrosion-wise, concentrate the Chloride ions. The concentration of chloride ions might be critical for some types of material.
rdf:Description.prefLabel: Process Water - Reject (Process water, reject water)

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
In filtration processes, the part of a solution that does not cross the membrane is termed the retentate or reject water. Depending on the filtered media and the pore size of the membrane the retentate will contain various substances.
In desalination the retentate will, besides other less important ions corrosion-wise, concentrate the Chloride ions. The concentration of chloride ions might be critical for some types of material.

LPG is a colourless, odourless gas. Normally LPG is odorised by adding an odorant prior to supply to the user, to aid the detection of any leaks). LPG is Flammable. LPG is heavier than air and has approximately half the weight of water. LPG is non-toxic but can cause suffocation. LPG expands upon release and 1 litre of liquid will form approximately 250 litres of vapour. LPG consists of propane (C3H8), butane (C4H10), or propane-butane mixtures derived from crude oil refining or natural gas fractionation. For convenience of transportation, these gases are liquefied through pressurization. Propane vaporises, changing from a liquid to a vapour when released to the atmosphere at a temperature above -42 °C and butane at 0 °C. Propane: Boiling point: -42 °C Flash point: -100 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 8.5 bar. Butane Boiling point: -1 °C. Flash point: -60 °C. Vapour pressure at 20 °C: 2.8 bar. Use: LPG is used as a fuel for domestic, industrial, agricultural, cooking, heating and drying processes. LPG can be used as an automotive fuel or as a propellant for aerosols, in addition to other specialist applications. Hazards in using liquefied petroleum gas? LPG is a flammable gas, which has the potential to create a hazard. Therefore it is important that the properties and safe handling of LPG are understood and applied in the domestic and commercial/industrial situations. Liquefied petroleum gas is stored under pressure. The gas will leak from any joint or connection, which is not sealed properly. Liquefied petroleum gas is heavier than air. Any significant leak will move downwards and stay on the ground. LPG will accumulate in any low-lying area such as depressions in the ground, drains or pits. Since LPG is stored in two phases, liquid and gaseous, there is potential for either a liquid leak or a gas leak. If the Liquefied petroleum gas leak is a gas leak it may not be seen (because LPG is colourless), except where the leak is of sufficient size to be seen shimmering in the air. When a liquid Liquefied petroleum gas leak occurs, the gas release will be seen as a patch of ice around the area of the leak, or as a jet of white liquid. This white appearance is due to the cooling effect created by the rapid expansion of the LPG liquid into a gas. The condensing atmospheric moisture makes the leak visible. In concentrated amounts and in uncontrolled conditions, liquefied petroleum gas has the potential to create a fire or an explosion.

Glycerol: C3H5(OH)3, clear, colourless, odorless, syrupy liquid; hygroscopic. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 290 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) and alcohol, insoluble in ether. Flash point 177 °C. Specific gravity: 1.3. Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. Use: as a component of antifreeze mixtures, as a sweetener, in alkyd resins, cellophane, explosives, ester gums, pharmaceuticals, perfumery, cosmetics, foodstuffs, as a solvent, in printer's ink rolls, as an emulsifying agent, in anti-freeze, for paper coatings and finishes, for special soaps, lubricants and softeners and as a hydraulic fluid. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: 1-Propyl alcohol, also called Propanol is a colourless, highly flammable, fragrant liquids miscible with water in all proportions (pH value almost neutral). Melting point: -127 °C. Boiling point: 97 °C. Specific gravity: 0.80. Viscosity: 2.26 cP at 20 °C and 1.13 cP at 50 °C. Flash point: 15 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 405 °C. Explosion limits: 2.1% - 12%. Vapour/air mixtures are explosive and somewhat toxic.Normal (n-)propyl alcohol (molecular formula CH3CH2CH2OH), or 1-propanol, is a by-product of the synthesis of methyl alcohol from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. It occurs in fusel oil (higher alcohols and their esters). It easily forms esters and ethers, some of commercial importance. Use: 1-Propyl alcohol is used especially in the preparation of lacquers. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Isopropyl alcohol or 2-propanol, (CH3)2CHOH is a colorless, highly flammable liquid with slight alcohol odour. It is a secondary alcohol that is miscible with water. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 82 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79. Viscosity: 1.77 cP at 30 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Explosion limits: 2.0 % - 12 %. Auto ignition temperature: 425 °C. Isopropyl alcohol is poisonous if taken internally. Use: Isopropyl alcohol is commonly used as an industrial solvent and as a rubbing alcohol applied to the skin. It is used in antifreeze compositions, cosmetics and in denaturing ethyl alcohol. It is one of the cheapest alcohols and has replaced ethanol for many uses because of its similar solvent properties. Although isopropyl alcohol is more toxic than ethanol, it has less of a drying effect on the skin, and it is not regulated and taxed as ethanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Acetone: CH3COCH3, colourless, highly flammable (flash point <. -20 °C) and volatile liquid. Soluble in water. Acetone is the simplest aliphatic ketone. Melting point: -97 °C. Boiling point: 57 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 465 °C. Viscosity: 0.30 cP at 20 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79 at 20 °C. Use: Acetone is widely used in industry as a solvent for numerous organic substances and is a component of most paint and varnish removers. It is used in the manufacture of synthetic resins and fillers, smokeless powders (e.g., cordite), and numerous other organic compounds. Acetone is produced commercially mostly by catalytic dehydrogenation of isopropanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

1-Propyl alcohol, also called Propanol is a colourless, highly flammable, fragrant liquids miscible with water in all proportions (pH value almost neutral). Melting point: -127 °C. Boiling point: 97 °C. Specific gravity: 0.80. Viscosity: 2.26 cP at 20 °C and 1.13 cP at 50 °C. Flash point: 15 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 405 °C. Explosion limits: 2.1% - 12%. Vapour/air mixtures are explosive and somewhat toxic.Normal (n-)propyl alcohol (molecular formula CH3CH2CH2OH), or 1-propanol, is a by-product of the synthesis of methyl alcohol from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. It occurs in fusel oil (higher alcohols and their esters). It easily forms esters and ethers, some of commercial importance. Use: 1-Propyl alcohol is used especially in the preparation of lacquers. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Isopropyl alcohol or 2-propanol, (CH3)2CHOH is a colorless, highly flammable liquid with slight alcohol odour. It is a secondary alcohol that is miscible with water. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 82 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79. Viscosity: 1.77 cP at 30 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Explosion limits: 2.0 % - 12 %. Auto ignition temperature: 425 °C. Isopropyl alcohol is poisonous if taken internally. Use: Isopropyl alcohol is commonly used as an industrial solvent and as a rubbing alcohol applied to the skin. It is used in antifreeze compositions, cosmetics and in denaturing ethyl alcohol. It is one of the cheapest alcohols and has replaced ethanol for many uses because of its similar solvent properties. Although isopropyl alcohol is more toxic than ethanol, it has less of a drying effect on the skin, and it is not regulated and taxed as ethanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Propylene glycol: CH3CHOHCH2OH, colourless, viscous, stable, hygroscopic sweet-tasting liquid. Miscible with water, alcohols and many organic solvents. Boiling point 187 °C. Flash point (open cup) 107 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 371 °C. Vapour pressure 0.07 mm at 20 °C. Solubility in water >100 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific Gravity: 1.04. Viscosity: From 10 to 100 cP. Use: in making polyester resins, anti-freeze solutions; used as a solvent for fats, oils, waxes, resins, perfumes. Serves as a hygroscopic agent; lubricant in refrigeration machines, plasticizer, cosmetics, solvent in foods, as a wetting agent, an emulsifier and as an animal feed additive. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Pyridine or azine C5H5N is a colorless, highly flammable, toxic liquid with a very unpleasant fish-like odour. It is miscible with water and with most organic solvents. Its aqueous solution is slightly alkaline. Melting point: -42 °C. Boiling point: 116 °C. Flash point: 19 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 480 °C. Explosion limits: 1.8 % - 12.4 % Specific gravity: 0.98 kg/m3. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 20 °C. Chemically, it is a heterocyclic aromatic tertiary amine. Its molecule resembles that of benzene, one carbon-hydrogen unit in the benzene ring being replaced with a nitrogen molecule. Pyridine is obtained from bone oil or from coal tar by destructive distillation, which decomposes alkaloids that contain it. Alkaloids that contain pyridine include coniine, piperine (the alkaloid in pepper), and nicotine (present in tobacco); free pyridine is present in tobacco smoke. Use: Pyridine is used as a solvent, as a denaturant for alcohol, in paints, medicine, textile dying and as a starting material in the synthesis of other compounds. Compounds that can be derived from pyridine include antihistamines and vitamins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Tartaric acid: HO2CCHOHCHOHCO2H, white colourless, odourless, crystalline powder. Very soluble in water: 1390 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.6 (100 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Melting point: 206 °C. Tartaric acid is an organic fruit acid. It occurs in many plants, particularly in the grape and is easily obtained from tartar.This natural acid is chiefly the dextrorotatory D-tartaric acid, called also D-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid or L-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid. This form can be partially converted to the others by heating it with an aqueous alkali, e.g., potassium hydroxide. Tartaric acids can be synthesized from maleic acids or fumaric acids by reaction with aqueous potassium permanganate. The various isomeric forms differ in such physical properties as boiling point. Use: Tartaric acid is used in the form of its salts, e.g., cream of tartar and Rochelle salt. It is also used as synergist for antioxidants, acid, sequestrant and flavouring agent. Widely used in foodstuffs industry such as foaming agent of beer, acidity agent, taste improvement of foodstuffs, cold drink, candy, fruit juice and ferment powder.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

In filtration processes, the part of a solution that does not cross the membrane is termed the retentate or reject water. Depending on the filtered media and the pore size of the membrane the retentate will contain various substances.
In desalination the retentate will, besides other less important ions corrosion-wise, concentrate the Chloride ions. The concentration of chloride ions might be critical for some types of material.

Heavy fuel oil (HFO) is a low-grade fuel primarily used in industrial boilers and other direct source heating applications (i.e., blast furnaces). It is also used as a principal fuel in marine applications in large diesel engines.
The viscosity of heavy fuel oil is above 25 cSt at 40 °C. The flashpoint is always above 50 °C and their density is higher than 0.90.
Given its high boiling point and tar-like consistency, HFO typically requires heating before it can be moved through pipes or dispensed into a boiler or other heating vessel to be burned.
HFO is the least expensive of the refined oil fuels and can only be used by facilities that have preheating capabilities.
HFO is typically high in sulphur and other impurities that are released into the air when the fuel is burned.

In filtration processes, the part of a solution that does not cross the membrane is termed the retentate or reject water. Depending on the filtered media and the pore size of the membrane the retentate will contain various substances.
In desalination the retentate will, besides other less important ions corrosion-wise, concentrate the Chloride ions. The concentration of chloride ions might be critical for some types of material.

Appearance: pale yellow viscous liquid.
Melting point: -10 °C. Boiling point: 313 °C. Flash point: about 235 °C. Specific gravity: 0.96. Viscosity: 44 cPs. to 660 cPs. Auto ignition temperature: about 450 °C. Water solubility: negligible.
Castor Oil is a triglyceride (ester) of fatty acid extracted from plants. It has the advantage over other mineral oils that it is a renewable resource. Castor oil is bio-degradable and eco-friendly. Many derivatives can be produced which have a similar chemical composition to petroleum based oils.
There are many uses for castor oil and its derivatives. Some of these include: lubricants, greases and hydraulic fluids, plastics, textiles and textile finishing materials, paints and varnishes, cosmetics and hair oils, inks, adhesives, synthetic resins, fibres, plasticizers, fungi static (fungus-growth-inhibiting) compounds and soaps.

Salicylic acid: or 2-hydroxybenzoic acid, C6H4(OH)CO2H, a colourless, crystalline organic carboxylic acid that melts at 159 °C; it is soluble in ethanol and ether but is only slightly soluble in water. Solubility in water 1.8 g/l (20 °C) pH value 3 (20 °C) (saturated solution).
Salicylic acid and its derivatives are toxic when consumed in large amounts. Sodium salicylate is used to a small extent as a food preservative and as an antiseptic in mouthwashes and toothpastes.
The major use of salicylic acid is in the preparation of its ester derivatives; since it contains both a hydroxyl (-OH) and a carboxyl (-CO2H) group, it can react with either an acid or an alcohol.
The hydroxyl group reacts with acetic acid to form the acetate ester, acetylsalicylic acid. Several useful esters are formed by reaction of the carboxyl group with alcohols.
The methyl ester, methyl salicylate (also called oil of wintergreen since it produces the fragrance of wintergreen), is formed with methanol. Methyl salicylate is used in food flavourings and in liniments.
The phenyl ester, phenyl salicylate, or salol, is formed with phenol; it is used in medicine as an antiseptic and antipyretic. This ester does not hydrolyse in the acidic stomach, but in the alkaline intestines, releasing free salicylic acid.
The menthyl ester, menthyl salicylate, which is used in suntan lotions, is formed with menthol.

Sodium sulfate, Na2SO4, is a white, crystalline compound at ordinary temperatures. Sodium sulfate is soluble in cold water and very soluble in hot water. Melting point: 884 °C.Solubility in water 160 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). The decahydrate of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4, 10H2O) is Glauber's salt. Use: The principal use of sodium sulfate is in processing wood pulp for making kraft paper. It is also used in glass manufacture, textile dyeing, and synthetic detergents.

Potassium carbonate K2CO3, a transparent, white, deliquescent, granular powder that forms a strongly alkaline water solution. Specific Gravity: 2.29. Solubility in water 1120g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 - 12.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting Point: 891 °C. It is available commercially as a white, granular powder commonly called potash, or pearl ash. It was originally obtained from wood ashes or from the residue left in pots after certain plants, e.g., kelp, were burned in them. Use: It is used in the manufacture of soft soaps, enamels and glass, for washing wool, in liquid automatic dishwashing, fertilizer markets and in the production of other potassium compounds.

Aluminium chloride: Yellow to grey crystals with odour of hydrochloric acid. Available in different forms. In anhydrous (AlCl3) form it combines with water with explosive violence and liberation of much heat. Soluble in water (450g/l at 20 °C) and in many organic solvents. pH value 2.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting point: about 190 °C Use: The hexahydrate form AlCl3,6H2O is used in preserving wood, disinfecting stables, slaughterhouses etc.; in deodorants and antiperspirants preparations and in refining crude oil. Poly Aluminium Chlorides (PAC, A1n(OH)mC13n-m)x) are highly efficient flocculants, capable of removing every kind of particle from aqueous suspensions. Polymeric aluminium chlorides are used for treatment and cleaning of industrial water, drinking water, waste water and swimming pool water. Furthermore they are used in paper industry as an auxiliary, where excellent results are achieved The chemical composition of polymeric aluminium chloride is optimised for each application.

Aluminium sulfate: A white crystalline compound, Al2(SO4)3, also called ALUM. It reacts acidic with water. Melting point: 92 °C. Solubility in water about 600 g/l (20 °C). pH value about 2.5 - 4.0 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Aluminium sulfate is used in the paper industry to clarify and control the pH of process waters, process, waste and potable water treatment, as mordant for textile fabric, the manufacture of chemicals, catalysts, greases, soaps, leather tanning chemicals, fire extinguishing chemicals, in foods and for modifying concrete.

Ammonium bicarbonate: A colourless to white crystalline salt with an faint ammonia odour. Releases CO2 when heated and decomposes at about 60 °C. Solubility in water 220g/l at 20 °C (decomposes in hot water). pH value about 8 (50 g/l, H2O at 20 °C). Use: Ammonium bicarbonate is used as a food additive and in baking powder. Utilized as a source of ammonia in the production of ammonium salts pharmaceuticals, pigments and dyes. Used in fire-extinguishing compounds.

Ammonium nitrate: Chemical compound, NH4NO3, that exists as colorless, rhombic crystals at room temperature but changes to monoclinic crystals when heated above 32 °C. It is a strong oxidizer and is extremely soluble in water and soluble in alcohol and liquid ammonia. Melting point: 170 °C. Specific gravity: 1.725 at 25 °C. Solubility in water 1920g/l (20 °C). pH value about 5.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). It is prepared commercially by reaction of nitric acid and ammonia. Use: Major uses are in fertilizers and explosives. For fertilizers it is in the form of small clay-coated pellets. For explosives it is sometimes mixed with other substances, e.g., TNT, so that it is more easily detonated. It is also used in solid-fuel rocket propellants, in pyrotechnics, and in the production of nitrous oxide.

Ammonium sulfate: Chemical compound, (NH4)2SO4, a colorless-to-gray, crystalline substance that occurs in nature as the mineral mascagnite. It is soluble in water and insoluble in alcohol or liquid ammonia. Melting point: 280 °C, decomposes. Solubility in water: 754g/l (20 °C). pH value: 5 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity: (40%, 20 °C): 1.23. Viscosity (40%, 20 °C): 2.06 cSt. Use: Ammonium sulfate is used as a fertilizer, in galvanizing, in preparing other ammonium compounds and for fireproofing.

Melting point: 250 °C. Solubility in water 710g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 6.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (26%, 20 °C): 1.2. Viscosity (26%, 20 °C): 2.4 cSt. It was first prepared from the waters of mineral springs at Epsom, England; it also occurs as the mineral epsomite. Use: Magnesium sulfate is used medicinally as a purgative, it is also used in leather tanning, mordant dyeing, fertilizers, explosives and as a filler in cotton goods and paper.

Calcium acetate: White crystals or powder with slight acetic acid odour. Melting point 230 °C. Decomposes to form acetone, calcium carbonate. Solubility in water 300g/l (0 °C). pH value 7.2 - 8.2 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Use: Used as deicer, in lubricants, as food stabilizer and as a corrosion inhibitor.

Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Ferric chloride: Dark brown liquid. Liquid solution with 35 to 40% ferric chloride in water has a specific gravity - 1.45 at 30 °C. Solubility in water 920g/l (20 °C) pH value about 1.8 (10 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Use: Ferric chloride is used principally as a flocculating agent for water treatment. It is also used in metal surface treatment as etching agent for engraving, photography and printed circuitry. Ferric chloride is sometimes used as a disinfectant. It deodourizes sewage and industrial wastes with partial reduction to ferrous chloride (FeCl2). Ferric chloride is aggressive to most metals. Pronounced tendency to crystallisation.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C) , pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Ferric sulfate: or iron(III)sulfate, chemical compound, Fe2 (SO4)3, a yellow rhombic crystalline hygroscopic water-soluble salt that decomposes when heated to a temperature of 480 °C. Freely soluble (20 °C), pH value 1.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: as a mordant in dyeing, as a coagulant for industrial wastes, in pickling baths for aluminum and steel, and in pigments.

Melting point: 64 °C. Solubility in water 665 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3-4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used in the manufacture of inks, in wool dyeing as a mordant, and in sewage and water treatment as a substitute for aluminum sulfate. Used as a pigment, fertilizer, and feed additive, and as a medicine in the treatment of iron deficiency.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Melting point: 250 °C. Solubility in water 710g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 6.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (26%, 20 °C): 1.2. Viscosity (26%, 20 °C): 2.4 cSt. It was first prepared from the waters of mineral springs at Epsom, England; it also occurs as the mineral epsomite. Use: Magnesium sulfate is used medicinally as a purgative, it is also used in leather tanning, mordant dyeing, fertilizers, explosives and as a filler in cotton goods and paper.

Potassium bicarbonate, KHCO3 is colourless, odourless, transparent crystals or white powder with a slightly alkaline, salty taste. Decomposes between 100 °C and 120 °C. Specific gravity 2.17. Solubility in water 224g/l (20 °C). pH value 8 - 8.6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Commonly used in baking powders, soft drinks, medicines (antacid), in the manufacture of pure potassium carbonate, fire-extinguishing agents, low pH liquid detergents, laboratory reagents, and as a food additive.

Potassium carbonate K2CO3, a transparent, white, deliquescent, granular powder that forms a strongly alkaline water solution. Specific Gravity: 2.29. Solubility in water 1120g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 - 12.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) Melting Point: 891 °C. It is available commercially as a white, granular powder commonly called potash, or pearl ash. It was originally obtained from wood ashes or from the residue left in pots after certain plants, e.g., kelp, were burned in them. Use: It is used in the manufacture of soft soaps, enamels and glass, for washing wool, in liquid automatic dishwashing, fertilizer markets and in the production of other potassium compounds.

Potassium dichromate, K2Cr2O7, a bright yellowish-red crystalline compound. Melting point: 398 °C. Boiling point: 500 °C. Solubility in water 130g/l (20 °C) pH value 3.6 (100 g/l, H2O) and 4.0 (10 g/l, H2O) Specific gravity: 2.676. Hexavalent chromium compounds are generally more toxic than trivalent chromium compounds. May be fatal if absorbed through the skin, if swallowed or inhaled. Contains chromium (VI), a known cancer hazard. Use:Used as an oxidizing agent, and in pyrotechnics, explosives, and safety matches.

Potassium perchlorate:colourless crystals or white powder. Strong oxidiser, but less reactive than the chlorate. Only slightly soluble in water. Melting point (decomposes): 610 °C. Specific gravity: 2.02. Solubility in water 17 g/l (20 °C). pH-value: 5.0 - 7.0 (10 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Perchlorates are safer to handle than chlorates; they are more stable when exposed to heat or shock. Use: Potassium perchlorate, KClO4, is perhaps most widely used, e.g., in matches, fireworks, explosives and automotive safety air bags.

Potassium permanganate, KMnO4 a purple-black, crystalline compound that forms deep purple, aqueous solutions. Melting point: 150 °C(decoposes). Specific gravity: 2.7. Solubility in water 64 g/l (20 °C). pH value 7 - 9 (20 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Harmful by inhalation, ingestion and through skin absorption. Irritant. Readily absorbed through skin. Use: Potassium permanganate is used in the chemical laboratory as a powerful oxidizing agent and in medicine as an antiseptic and disinfectant.

Potassium sulfate, K2SO4, a odourless, bitter, colourless or white crystalline compound. Melting point: 1070 °C. Solubility in water 110 g/l (20 °C) and 240g/l (100 °C). pH of 5% solution 5.5-8.5 (20 °C). Use: Potassium sulfate is used in glassmaking and fertilizers and as a reagent in analytical chemistry.

Silver nitrate, AgNO3 is a colourless crystalline material that is very soluble in water. It is darkened by sunlight or contact with organic matter such as the skin. Melting point: 212 °C. Solubility in water 2.16 kg/m3 (20 °C). Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.2. Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.5 and viscosity: 0.9 cSt. pH value 5.4 - 6.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Silver nitrate is the most important compound of silver. Use: Silver nitrate is used in the preparation of silver salts for photography, in chemical analysis, in silver plating, in inks and hair dyes, and to silver mirrors. It is used in medicine in the treatment of eye infections and gonorrhea. Taken internally silver nitrate is a poison.

Sodium acetate is white powder or transparent crystals with an odourless to slightly acetic odor. Melting point: 58 °C. Specific gravity: 1.45. Solubility in water 1190 g/l (20 °C). Specific gravity (300g/l, 20 °C): 1.2 and viscosity: 4.3 cSt. pH value7.5 - 9.0 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Sodium acetate is used in the manufacture of acetic anhydride, cinematic acid, intermediates, organic chemicals, synthetic dyestuffs, pharmaceuticals, soap, copper acetate, pigments; as mordant for dyeing and printing textiles, photographic and laboratory reagent; in purifying glucose and preserving met, and as an electroplating reagent.

Sodium bicarbonate: or sodium hydrogen carbonate, chemical compound, NaHCO3, a white crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as bicarbonate of soda or baking soda. It is soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 95.5 g/l (20 °C). pH value 8.35 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). NaHCO3 evolves carbon dioxide gas when heated above about 50 °C, a property made use of in baking powder, of which it is a component. It is also decomposed by most acids; the acid is neutralised and carbon dioxide is given off. Use: The major use of sodium bicarbonate is in foods, e.g., baked goods. It is used in effervescent "salts" and is sometimes used medically to correct excess stomach acidity. It is also used in several kinds of fire extinguishers.

Sodium bisulfate is odourless, off-white granules, crystals or powder. It is readily soluble in water and strongly acidic. Melting point: 59 °C. Solubility in water about 500g/l (20 °C). pH of a 5% Aqueous Solution 1.0. Use: Sodium bisulfate is used in some agents to tan leather, as a photographic reducing agent, pickling of metals and as a food preservative.

Sodium bisulfite: White crystals or powder with a slight odor of sulfur dioxide. Commercially available in two acidic solutions, 40% and 43%. These are clear, colorless to pale yellow solutions with a pungent odour. Solubility 29% in water. It is manufactured by absorbing SO2 in an alkaline solution. Use: Sodium bisulfite is a reducing agent made available in a ready-to-use liquid form. It is used in many purposes: Chemical reduction of chlorine, chlorine dioxide, and hydrogen peroxide from pulp and vent gas scrubbing processes. Thermo mechanical pulping additives to improve strength, increase brightness, and lower pulping energy. Dechlorination of municipal and industrial waste water. Reducing agent for bichromate (hexavalent chromium) to the trivalent form. Raw material for the production of sodium thiosulfate and sodium sulfite. Used in paper manufacture, as an anti-darkening agent when drying fruit.

Sodium carbonate: chemical compound, Na2CO3, soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 210 g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Pure sodium carbonate is a white, odourless powder that absorbs moisture from the air, it has an alkaline taste, and it forms a strongly alkaline water solution. It is one of the most basic industrial chemicals. Sodium carbonate, Na2CO3, is a colourless, transparent crystalline compound commonly called sal soda or washing soda. Because seaweed ashes were an early source of sodium carbonate, it is often called soda ash or, simply, soda. Use: the principal uses of sodium carbonate are in the manufacture of glass and the production of chemicals. It is also used in processing wood pulp to make paper, in making soaps and detergents, in refining aluminum, in water softening, and in many other applications.

Sodium chlorate: a white, hygroscopic, odourless, crystalline solid. Solubility in water 1000 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5 - 7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (25%, 25 °C): 1.2. Viscosity: (25%, 25 °C: 2.33 cP. Sodium chlorate is a powerful oxidizing agent. When heated in the pure state, it will begin to decompose slowly at about 300 °C with the evolution of oxygen and the formation of sodium chloride. This decomposition is strongly exothermic and self-sustaining above a critical temperature. The large amounts of oxygen released can cause the burning of combustible materials to be explosively rapid. Alkaline chlorate solutions do not exhibit strong oxidizing properties. However, as pH decreases, the oxidizing activity of these solutions will increase. Concentrated acid solutions are vigorous oxidizing agents. Commercial sodium chlorate solutions are neutral or slightly basic. Under these conditions they are stable in storage over a long period of time. Use: Up to 95% of all sodium chlorate produced worldwide goes into the pulp and paper industry where it is used to generate chlorine dioxide, a key bleaching agent, in the production of wood pulp for paper products. With growing environmental concerns, sodium chlorate is in even greater demand by papermakers as a key ingredient for making chlorine dioxide. It's also use in agriculture for herbicides and defoliants, in refining for vanadium and uranium, and in making rocket propellants and dyes. Notes: Mixtures of this material with organic fibrous or absorbent material and with a variety of other materials are potentially explosive.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium chlorite is a pale green or clear liquid (25% solution in water). It is a strong oxidizing agent. Melting point: 13 °C - 18 °C (25% solution in water). pH value: 12.5-13 (25% solution in water). Sodium chlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as toxic chlorine dioxide and chlorine gases will be liberated. Sodium chlorite is the only chlorite salt produced commercially in significant quantities. Use: It is used mainly for the generation of chlorine dioxide "in situ" for bleaching textiles, in pulp and paper processing, and for disinfection. Sodium chlorite is used in a small number of water treatment plants to generate chlorine dioxide; this may result in low residual concentrations of chlorite in drinking-water.

Sodium metasilicate: is a white crystalline powder, readily soluble in water, thus forming alkaline solution. The product is commonly known as water glass. Formula: Na2O.3.75 SiO2 to 2Na2O.SiO2 with various proportions of water. Viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP. Soluble in water, pH value 12.0 - 12.8 (1% of concentration in water, 20 °C. A little water dissolves water glass more readily than much water does. Use: Both the types of sodium metasilicate, i.e. pentahydrate as well nonahydrate are used particularly in the manufacture of industrial detergents, corrosion inhibitors, washing preparations and disinfectants, adhesives, pigments, water treatment, bleaching and sizing of textiles and paper pulp, as a binder for foundry cores and molds and in waterproofing mortars and cements. Sodium silicates are very abrasive and harmful to the shaft seal faces. Double shaft seal may be required.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium nitrate: chemical compound, NaNO3, a colourless, odorless crystalline compound that closely resembles potassium nitrate (saltpeter or niter) in appearance and chemical properties. It is soluble in water, alcohol, and liquid ammonia. Solubility in water 880 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 7.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrate is also called soda niter or Chile saltpeter. It is found naturally in large deposits in arid regions of Chile, Peru, Argentina, and Bolivia as caliche, a crude, impure nitrate rock or gravel. Use: sodium nitrate is used in making potassium nitrate, fertilizers, and explosives. It was formerly an important raw material for the production of nitric acid.

Sodium nitrite is odourless, white to light yellow granules or powder. Sodium nitrite is a strong oxidizer, but it can also act as a reducing agent. Melting point: 271 °C. Solubility in water 820 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrite forms corrosion-resistant oxide coatings on iron and steel; it is used in phosphatizing and heat transfer salts. Frequently used in Vapor Corrosion Inhibitor (VCI) paper coatings. Use: Sodium nitrite is used for manufacture of dyestuffs, pharmaceuticals, used in organic synthesis, in corrosion inhibitors; photography; bleaching of flax; silk and linen; dyeing and printing of textile fabrics, etc.Sodium nitrite is also used in chemical synthesis reactions in the manufacture of organic insecticides and herbicides.

Sodium phosphate (dibasic): Colorless or white, odourless granular salt. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Solubility in water 93 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9.1 - 9.4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Because phosphoric acid is tribasic (having three replaceable hydrogen atoms), it forms monophosphate, diphosphate, and triphosphate salts in which one, two, or three of the hydrogens of the acid are replaced, respectively. Use: Disodium phosphate is used in boiler compounds, detergents and to some extent in medicine and in preparing baking powders.

Sodium phosphate (monobasic): white, odourless crystals or granules. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 100 °C. Solubility in water 850 g/l (20 °C) pH value 4.5 (12 g/l, H2O, 25 °C) Use: Sodium phosphate is used in baking powders and in boiler treatment.

Sodium phosphate (tribasic):Sodium Phosphate Tribasic is a colorless to white crystalline (sugar or sand-like) or powdered solid. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 73 °C - 76 °C. Solubility in water 120 g/l (20 °C). pH value 12 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used as a water softener, detergent, metal cleaner, in paper manufacturing, as photographic developer ingredient and for softening water.

Sodium sulfate, Na2SO4, is a white, crystalline compound at ordinary temperatures. Sodium sulfate is soluble in cold water and very soluble in hot water. Melting point: 884 °C.Solubility in water 160 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). The decahydrate of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4, 10H2O) is Glauber's salt. Use: The principal use of sodium sulfate is in processing wood pulp for making kraft paper. It is also used in glass manufacture, textile dyeing, and synthetic detergents.

Sodium sulfite: Na2SO3, a white crystalline or powdered compound. Solubility in water 220 g/l (20 °C) pH value 8.8 - 10 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: in preserving foods, silvering mirrors, developing photographs, and making dyes. Sodium sulfite is primarily used as a pulping and dechlorination agent by the pulp industry. Other applications include its use to remove oxygen in boiler water and as an antioxidant in film processing. Sodium sulfite also serves to remove chlorine in many industrial applications.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Zinc chloride: White, odourless granules. Very soluble in water. Melting Point: 293 °C. Specific Gravity: 2.9. Solubility in water 3680 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Galvanizing fluxes; soldering fluxes; electroplating; batteries uses; wood preservative; dehydrating and condensing agent in organic synthesis; burnishing and polishing compounds for steels; antiseptic and deodorant preparations; textiles; adhesives; dental cements; glass etching; petroleum refining; parchment; dentifrices; embalming and taxidermists fluids; medicine; dyestuff; pigments; antistatic.

Zinc sulfate chemical compound ZnSO4, a very water soluble, transparent, colorless, crystalline compound. Solubility in water 960 g/l (20 °C). pH value 4 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used to supply zinc in animal feeds, fertilizers, and agricultural sprays; in making lithopone; in coagulation baths for rayon; in electrolyte for zinc plating; as a mordant in dyeing; as a preservative for skins and leather; and in medicine as an astringent.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Seawater: Most of the elements that can be found on earth are present in seawater, at least in trace amounts. However, eleven of the constituents alone account for 99.95% of the total solutes, chloride ions being by far the largest constituent. The concentration of dissolved materials in the sea varies greatly with location and time because seawater is diluted by rivers, rain, or melting ice, or is concentrated by evaporation. Salinity of Ocean/Sea waters The Practical Salinity Scale defines salinity in terms of the conductivity ratio of a sample to that of a solution of 32.4356 g of KCl at 15 °C in a 1 kg solution. A sample of seawater at 15 °C with a conductivity equal to this KCl solution has a salinity of exactly 35 practical salinity units (psu). Baltic Sea: about 5 to 15 psu. Black Sea: less than 20 psu. Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean: from 33 to 37 psu. Mediterranean: about 40 psu. Dead Sea: about 300-400 psu. Conversion of salinity to chloride: Chloride (ppm) = (Salinity x 1000) / 1.8 Use: Seawater systems are used by many industries such as shipping, offshore oil and gas production, power plants and coastal industrial plants. The main use of seawater is for cooling purposes but it is also used for fire fighting, oil field water injection and for desalination plants.
No Info

Isopropyl alcohol or 2-propanol, (CH3)2CHOH is a colorless, highly flammable liquid with slight alcohol odour. It is a secondary alcohol that is miscible with water. Melting point: -89 °C. Boiling point: 82 °C. Specific gravity: 0.79. Viscosity: 1.77 cP at 30 °C. Flash point: 12 °C. Explosion limits: 2.0 % - 12 %. Auto ignition temperature: 425 °C. Isopropyl alcohol is poisonous if taken internally. Use: Isopropyl alcohol is commonly used as an industrial solvent and as a rubbing alcohol applied to the skin. It is used in antifreeze compositions, cosmetics and in denaturing ethyl alcohol. It is one of the cheapest alcohols and has replaced ethanol for many uses because of its similar solvent properties. Although isopropyl alcohol is more toxic than ethanol, it has less of a drying effect on the skin, and it is not regulated and taxed as ethanol. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Wastewater is a common designation for any water that in one way has been affected in quality by human influence and which is transported through a combined or separate sewer system. Wastewater contains a broad spectrum of waste of organic or inorganic origin that can be discharged from different sources. These sources can be, for example, domestic residences, commercial properties, industrial plants, agriculture as well as surface run-off and infiltrated water in the sewer system. These different sources are commonly divided into three categories: Domestic wastewater Water which is contaminated by use and normally discharged from toilets, showers, baths, wash basins, sinks, and floor gullies. Trade effluent Wastewater discharge resulting from any industrial or commercial activity. Surface water Water from precipitation which as not seeped into the ground and which is discharged to the drain or sewer system directly form the ground or from exterior building surfaces. If the wastewater is comprised mostly of domestic wastewater and surface water, it is often referred to as municipal wastewater whereas if the main part of the wastewater is comprised of trade effluent it is often referred to as industrial. If the content of trade effluent in the wastewater is significant or completely composed of trade effluent special considerations must be taken during evaluation of material variants as some chemicals might be present in high concentrations. The terms black and grey water is sometimes also used to describe wastewater. The term black water describes wastewater which contains faecal matter and urine. Wastewater without the content of faecal matter or urine is referred to as grey water, and comprises 50-80% of residential wastewater Wastewater encompasses a wide range of potential contaminants of inorganic or organic origin. Below is a partial list of wastewater constituents:
  • Bacteria, viruses, prions and parasitic worms.
  • Organic particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibres, plant material, humus, etc.
  • Soluble organic material such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, pharmaceuticals etc.
  • Inorganic particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.
  • Soluble inorganic material such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, hydrogen sulphide, heavy metals, etc.
  • Macro-solids such as sanitary napkins, napkins/diapers, condoms, needles, children's toys, dead pets etc.
  • Gases such as hydrogen sulphide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.
  • Emulsions such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.
  • Toxins such as pesticides, poisons, herbicides, etc.
