Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Hexafluorosilicic acid: or fluorosilicic acid, H2SiF6, is an aqueous solution of H2SiF6 in water. It is white to straw yellow in colour. It is a corrosive acid, irritating to the skin, and has a pungent odour. It is not known to exist in any anhydrous form. The boiling point increases with increasing acid content. At a typical commercial strength of 25 per cent acid content, the boiling point is 106 °C, and the freezing point is approximately -16 °C. A 25 per cent solution has a pH of 1.2 and weighs 1.20 kg/L. The molecular weight of H2SiF6 is 144.08. The commercial solutions typically contain between 20 and 30% Fluorosilicic acid by weight. Use: Fluorosilicic acid (H2SiF6) is one of several fluoride compounds presently being added to drinking water as a source of fluoride during water.

Specific gravity about 1.0. Commercially available in a range of viscosities from 1 cSt. to several thousand cSt.
Silicones are polymers in which organics groups, such as methyl and phenyl groups are bonded to the silicone atoms in chains of inorganic siloxanes (-Si-O-Si-).
Silicone oils have low surface tension, defoaming properties, excellent gloss and film properties, thermal and oxidative stability, and exhibit excellent viscosity stability over a wide temperature range. Silicone oils are also chemically inert to most common materials of construction and have low flammability.

Silver nitrate, AgNO3 is a colourless crystalline material that is very soluble in water. It is darkened by sunlight or contact with organic matter such as the skin. Melting point: 212 °C. Solubility in water 2.16 kg/m3 (20 °C). Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.2. Specific gravity (20% at 20 °C): 1.5 and viscosity: 0.9 cSt. pH value 5.4 - 6.4 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Silver nitrate is the most important compound of silver. Use: Silver nitrate is used in the preparation of silver salts for photography, in chemical analysis, in silver plating, in inks and hair dyes, and to silver mirrors. It is used in medicine in the treatment of eye infections and gonorrhea. Taken internally silver nitrate is a poison.

Soap cleaning: Soaps are water-soluble sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Soaps are made from fats and oils, or their fatty acids, by treating them chemically with a strong alkali. Although soap is a good cleaning agent, its effectiveness is reduced when used in hard water.
Hardness in water is caused by the presence of mineral salts - mostly those of calcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg), but sometimes also iron (Fe) and manganese (Mn). The mineral salts react with soap to form an insoluble precipitate known as soap film or scum.

Soap cleaning: Soaps are water-soluble sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Soaps are made from fats and oils, or their fatty acids, by treating them chemically with a strong alkali. Although soap is a good cleaning agent, its effectiveness is reduced when used in hard water.
Hardness in water is caused by the presence of mineral salts - mostly those of calcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg), but sometimes also iron (Fe) and manganese (Mn). The mineral salts react with soap to form an insoluble precipitate known as soap film or scum.

Sodium carbonate: chemical compound, Na2CO3, soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 210 g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Pure sodium carbonate is a white, odourless powder that absorbs moisture from the air, it has an alkaline taste, and it forms a strongly alkaline water solution. It is one of the most basic industrial chemicals. Sodium carbonate, Na2CO3, is a colourless, transparent crystalline compound commonly called sal soda or washing soda. Because seaweed ashes were an early source of sodium carbonate, it is often called soda ash or, simply, soda. Use: the principal uses of sodium carbonate are in the manufacture of glass and the production of chemicals. It is also used in processing wood pulp to make paper, in making soaps and detergents, in refining aluminum, in water softening, and in many other applications.

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

Sodium acetate is white powder or transparent crystals with an odourless to slightly acetic odor. Melting point: 58 °C. Specific gravity: 1.45. Solubility in water 1190 g/l (20 °C). Specific gravity (300g/l, 20 °C): 1.2 and viscosity: 4.3 cSt. pH value7.5 - 9.0 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Sodium acetate is used in the manufacture of acetic anhydride, cinematic acid, intermediates, organic chemicals, synthetic dyestuffs, pharmaceuticals, soap, copper acetate, pigments; as mordant for dyeing and printing textiles, photographic and laboratory reagent; in purifying glucose and preserving met, and as an electroplating reagent.

Sodium bicarbonate: or sodium hydrogen carbonate, chemical compound, NaHCO3, a white crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as bicarbonate of soda or baking soda. It is soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 95.5 g/l (20 °C). pH value 8.35 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). NaHCO3 evolves carbon dioxide gas when heated above about 50 °C, a property made use of in baking powder, of which it is a component. It is also decomposed by most acids; the acid is neutralised and carbon dioxide is given off. Use: The major use of sodium bicarbonate is in foods, e.g., baked goods. It is used in effervescent "salts" and is sometimes used medically to correct excess stomach acidity. It is also used in several kinds of fire extinguishers.

Sodium phosphate (monobasic): white, odourless crystals or granules. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 100 °C. Solubility in water 850 g/l (20 °C) pH value 4.5 (12 g/l, H2O, 25 °C) Use: Sodium phosphate is used in baking powders and in boiler treatment.

Sodium bisulfate is odourless, off-white granules, crystals or powder. It is readily soluble in water and strongly acidic. Melting point: 59 °C. Solubility in water about 500g/l (20 °C). pH of a 5% Aqueous Solution 1.0. Use: Sodium bisulfate is used in some agents to tan leather, as a photographic reducing agent, pickling of metals and as a food preservative.

Sodium bisulfite: White crystals or powder with a slight odor of sulfur dioxide. Commercially available in two acidic solutions, 40% and 43%. These are clear, colorless to pale yellow solutions with a pungent odour. Solubility 29% in water. It is manufactured by absorbing SO2 in an alkaline solution. Use: Sodium bisulfite is a reducing agent made available in a ready-to-use liquid form. It is used in many purposes: Chemical reduction of chlorine, chlorine dioxide, and hydrogen peroxide from pulp and vent gas scrubbing processes. Thermo mechanical pulping additives to improve strength, increase brightness, and lower pulping energy. Dechlorination of municipal and industrial waste water. Reducing agent for bichromate (hexavalent chromium) to the trivalent form. Raw material for the production of sodium thiosulfate and sodium sulfite. Used in paper manufacture, as an anti-darkening agent when drying fruit.

Sodium carbonate: chemical compound, Na2CO3, soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 210 g/l (20 °C) pH value 11.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Pure sodium carbonate is a white, odourless powder that absorbs moisture from the air, it has an alkaline taste, and it forms a strongly alkaline water solution. It is one of the most basic industrial chemicals. Sodium carbonate, Na2CO3, is a colourless, transparent crystalline compound commonly called sal soda or washing soda. Because seaweed ashes were an early source of sodium carbonate, it is often called soda ash or, simply, soda. Use: the principal uses of sodium carbonate are in the manufacture of glass and the production of chemicals. It is also used in processing wood pulp to make paper, in making soaps and detergents, in refining aluminum, in water softening, and in many other applications.

Sodium chlorate: a white, hygroscopic, odourless, crystalline solid. Solubility in water 1000 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5 - 7 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (25%, 25 °C): 1.2. Viscosity: (25%, 25 °C: 2.33 cP. Sodium chlorate is a powerful oxidizing agent. When heated in the pure state, it will begin to decompose slowly at about 300 °C with the evolution of oxygen and the formation of sodium chloride. This decomposition is strongly exothermic and self-sustaining above a critical temperature. The large amounts of oxygen released can cause the burning of combustible materials to be explosively rapid. Alkaline chlorate solutions do not exhibit strong oxidizing properties. However, as pH decreases, the oxidizing activity of these solutions will increase. Concentrated acid solutions are vigorous oxidizing agents. Commercial sodium chlorate solutions are neutral or slightly basic. Under these conditions they are stable in storage over a long period of time. Use: Up to 95% of all sodium chlorate produced worldwide goes into the pulp and paper industry where it is used to generate chlorine dioxide, a key bleaching agent, in the production of wood pulp for paper products. With growing environmental concerns, sodium chlorate is in even greater demand by papermakers as a key ingredient for making chlorine dioxide. It's also use in agriculture for herbicides and defoliants, in refining for vanadium and uranium, and in making rocket propellants and dyes. Notes: Mixtures of this material with organic fibrous or absorbent material and with a variety of other materials are potentially explosive.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium chlorite is a pale green or clear liquid (25% solution in water). It is a strong oxidizing agent. Melting point: 13 °C - 18 °C (25% solution in water). pH value: 12.5-13 (25% solution in water). Sodium chlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as toxic chlorine dioxide and chlorine gases will be liberated. Sodium chlorite is the only chlorite salt produced commercially in significant quantities. Use: It is used mainly for the generation of chlorine dioxide "in situ" for bleaching textiles, in pulp and paper processing, and for disinfection. Sodium chlorite is used in a small number of water treatment plants to generate chlorine dioxide; this may result in low residual concentrations of chlorite in drinking-water.

Sodium cyanide is a white crystalline solid. It is very soluble in water (about 60% at 20 °C) and forms a strong alkaline solution with a faint bitter almond odor. It is a poison that reacts with acid, acid salts or carbon dioxide to liberate extremely toxic hydrogen cyanide (HCN) gas.
Cyanide itself is an ion (CN-). It is a powerful and rapid-acting poison.
Sodium cyanide and potassium cyanide are examples of simple cyanide salts. Cyanide salts are mainly used in electroplating, metallurgy, and the production of organic chemicals; in photographic development; as anti-caking agents in road salts; in the extraction of gold and silver from ores; and in the making of plastics.
Of the cyanide compounds, sodium cyanide and potassium cyanide are the most likely to be found in the environment from industrial activities.

Sodium phosphate (monobasic): white, odourless crystals or granules. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 100 °C. Solubility in water 850 g/l (20 °C) pH value 4.5 (12 g/l, H2O, 25 °C) Use: Sodium phosphate is used in baking powders and in boiler treatment.

Sodium bicarbonate: or sodium hydrogen carbonate, chemical compound, NaHCO3, a white crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as bicarbonate of soda or baking soda. It is soluble in water and very slightly soluble in alcohol. Solubility in water 95.5 g/l (20 °C). pH value 8.35 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). NaHCO3 evolves carbon dioxide gas when heated above about 50 °C, a property made use of in baking powder, of which it is a component. It is also decomposed by most acids; the acid is neutralised and carbon dioxide is given off. Use: The major use of sodium bicarbonate is in foods, e.g., baked goods. It is used in effervescent "salts" and is sometimes used medically to correct excess stomach acidity. It is also used in several kinds of fire extinguishers.

Sodium bisulfate is odourless, off-white granules, crystals or powder. It is readily soluble in water and strongly acidic. Melting point: 59 °C. Solubility in water about 500g/l (20 °C). pH of a 5% Aqueous Solution 1.0. Use: Sodium bisulfate is used in some agents to tan leather, as a photographic reducing agent, pickling of metals and as a food preservative.

Sodium bisulfite: White crystals or powder with a slight odor of sulfur dioxide. Commercially available in two acidic solutions, 40% and 43%. These are clear, colorless to pale yellow solutions with a pungent odour. Solubility 29% in water. It is manufactured by absorbing SO2 in an alkaline solution. Use: Sodium bisulfite is a reducing agent made available in a ready-to-use liquid form. It is used in many purposes: Chemical reduction of chlorine, chlorine dioxide, and hydrogen peroxide from pulp and vent gas scrubbing processes. Thermo mechanical pulping additives to improve strength, increase brightness, and lower pulping energy. Dechlorination of municipal and industrial waste water. Reducing agent for bichromate (hexavalent chromium) to the trivalent form. Raw material for the production of sodium thiosulfate and sodium sulfite. Used in paper manufacture, as an anti-darkening agent when drying fruit.

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

Sodium hypochlorite: NaClO is a pale greenish liquid with chlorine odour. Also known as soda bleach or liquid bleach. Household bleaches normally contain about 5% sodium hypochlorite (about pH11), and more concentrated bleaches contain 10-15% sodium hypochlorite (about pH13).Commercial sodium hypochlorites are normally stabilised with sodium hydroxide. Sodium hypochlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as chlorine (a toxic gas) will be liberated. Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 40 °C (decomposes). Specific gravity: 1.21. pH value: 6 to 9. Use: sodium hypochlorite is used for a wide range of applications where its powerful disinfection and oxidation properties are utilised. The main application areas include: Bleaching; Formulated Disinfectants; Potable and Waste Water Treatment; Swimming Pool Water Treatment; Process and Cooling Water Treatment; Odour Control; Chemical Intermediates; etc. Sodium hypochlorite is aggressive to many metals and elastomers. Javelle water: aqueous solution of sodium or potassium hypochlorite. It was originally made near the French town of Javelle (now part of Paris) and was the first chemical bleach, a use first demonstrated by C. L. Berthollet in 1785. It was produced by passing chlorine gas through a water solution of potash (potassium carbonate). After the invention of bleaching powder Javelle water was sometimes produced by reacting the bleaching powder with potash or soda ash (sodium carbonate).

Chlorine is a disinfectant added to water to reduce or eliminate microorganisms, such as bacteria and viruses, which can be present in water. The different forms of chlorine used for water treatment are gaseous chlorine, sodium hypochlorite solution and calcium hypochlorite. When chlorine is introduced into water, it dissociates into two parts, - Hypochlorous Acid (HOCl), which is the strong, fast, oxidizing disinfectant, and the Hypochlorite Ion (OCl-), which is a very slow, weak disinfectant. The ratio of HOCL to OCl- is determined by the pH value of the water (Cl2 will only be present in the water at very low pH). HOCl is 100 times more powerful an oxidant/disinfectant than is the hypochlorite ion. Consequently, disinfection is most effective at pH 5 to 7 where HOCl is the predominant form. Free Chlorine Free chlorine is defined as the concentration of residual chlorine in water present as dissolved gas (Cl2), hypochlorous acid (HOCl), and/or hypochlorite ion (OCl-). The three forms of free chlorine exist together in equilibrium. Combined Chlorine Combined chlorine is defined as the residual chlorine existing in water in chemical combination with ammonia or organic amines which can be found in natural or polluted bwaters. Total Chlorine Total chlorine is the sum of free and combined chlorine. Typical values: Bottled water, drinking water, swimming pool, spa-water purification: higher than 0.1-0.2 ppm and lower than 2-3 ppm.Sanitation (CIP): 20-300 ppm. Use: Process water disinfection for the food industry, potable water disinfection, CIP sanitization, pasteuriser sanitization, vegetable washing, odour control scrubbers, sulfide oxidation, manganese and iron oxidation.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Sodium metasilicate: is a white crystalline powder, readily soluble in water, thus forming alkaline solution. The product is commonly known as water glass. Formula: Na2O.3.75 SiO2 to 2Na2O.SiO2 with various proportions of water. Viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP. Soluble in water, pH value 12.0 - 12.8 (1% of concentration in water, 20 °C. A little water dissolves water glass more readily than much water does. Use: Both the types of sodium metasilicate, i.e. pentahydrate as well nonahydrate are used particularly in the manufacture of industrial detergents, corrosion inhibitors, washing preparations and disinfectants, adhesives, pigments, water treatment, bleaching and sizing of textiles and paper pulp, as a binder for foundry cores and molds and in waterproofing mortars and cements. Sodium silicates are very abrasive and harmful to the shaft seal faces. Double shaft seal may be required.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium nitrate: chemical compound, NaNO3, a colourless, odorless crystalline compound that closely resembles potassium nitrate (saltpeter or niter) in appearance and chemical properties. It is soluble in water, alcohol, and liquid ammonia. Solubility in water 880 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5.5 - 7.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrate is also called soda niter or Chile saltpeter. It is found naturally in large deposits in arid regions of Chile, Peru, Argentina, and Bolivia as caliche, a crude, impure nitrate rock or gravel. Use: sodium nitrate is used in making potassium nitrate, fertilizers, and explosives. It was formerly an important raw material for the production of nitric acid.

Sodium nitrite is odourless, white to light yellow granules or powder. Sodium nitrite is a strong oxidizer, but it can also act as a reducing agent. Melting point: 271 °C. Solubility in water 820 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Sodium nitrite forms corrosion-resistant oxide coatings on iron and steel; it is used in phosphatizing and heat transfer salts. Frequently used in Vapor Corrosion Inhibitor (VCI) paper coatings. Use: Sodium nitrite is used for manufacture of dyestuffs, pharmaceuticals, used in organic synthesis, in corrosion inhibitors; photography; bleaching of flax; silk and linen; dyeing and printing of textile fabrics, etc.Sodium nitrite is also used in chemical synthesis reactions in the manufacture of organic insecticides and herbicides.

Sodium hypochlorite: NaClO is a pale greenish liquid with chlorine odour. Also known as soda bleach or liquid bleach. Household bleaches normally contain about 5% sodium hypochlorite (about pH11), and more concentrated bleaches contain 10-15% sodium hypochlorite (about pH13).Commercial sodium hypochlorites are normally stabilised with sodium hydroxide. Sodium hypochlorite should NEVER BE MIXED WITH ACIDS as chlorine (a toxic gas) will be liberated. Melting point: -6 °C. Boiling point: 40 °C (decomposes). Specific gravity: 1.21. pH value: 6 to 9. Use: sodium hypochlorite is used for a wide range of applications where its powerful disinfection and oxidation properties are utilised. The main application areas include: Bleaching; Formulated Disinfectants; Potable and Waste Water Treatment; Swimming Pool Water Treatment; Process and Cooling Water Treatment; Odour Control; Chemical Intermediates; etc. Sodium hypochlorite is aggressive to many metals and elastomers. Javelle water: aqueous solution of sodium or potassium hypochlorite. It was originally made near the French town of Javelle (now part of Paris) and was the first chemical bleach, a use first demonstrated by C. L. Berthollet in 1785. It was produced by passing chlorine gas through a water solution of potash (potassium carbonate). After the invention of bleaching powder Javelle water was sometimes produced by reacting the bleaching powder with potash or soda ash (sodium carbonate).

Sodium phosphate (dibasic): Colorless or white, odourless granular salt. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Solubility in water 93 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9.1 - 9.4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Because phosphoric acid is tribasic (having three replaceable hydrogen atoms), it forms monophosphate, diphosphate, and triphosphate salts in which one, two, or three of the hydrogens of the acid are replaced, respectively. Use: Disodium phosphate is used in boiler compounds, detergents and to some extent in medicine and in preparing baking powders.

Sodium phosphate (dibasic): Colorless or white, odourless granular salt. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Solubility in water 93 g/l (20 °C). pH value 9.1 - 9.4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Because phosphoric acid is tribasic (having three replaceable hydrogen atoms), it forms monophosphate, diphosphate, and triphosphate salts in which one, two, or three of the hydrogens of the acid are replaced, respectively. Use: Disodium phosphate is used in boiler compounds, detergents and to some extent in medicine and in preparing baking powders.

Sodium phosphate (monobasic): white, odourless crystals or granules. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 100 °C. Solubility in water 850 g/l (20 °C) pH value 4.5 (12 g/l, H2O, 25 °C) Use: Sodium phosphate is used in baking powders and in boiler treatment.

Sodium phosphate (monobasic): white, odourless crystals or granules. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 100 °C. Solubility in water 850 g/l (20 °C) pH value 4.5 (12 g/l, H2O, 25 °C) Use: Sodium phosphate is used in baking powders and in boiler treatment.

Sodium phosphate (tribasic):Sodium Phosphate Tribasic is a colorless to white crystalline (sugar or sand-like) or powdered solid. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 73 °C - 76 °C. Solubility in water 120 g/l (20 °C). pH value 12 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used as a water softener, detergent, metal cleaner, in paper manufacturing, as photographic developer ingredient and for softening water.

Sodium phosphate (tribasic):Sodium Phosphate Tribasic is a colorless to white crystalline (sugar or sand-like) or powdered solid. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 73 °C - 76 °C. Solubility in water 120 g/l (20 °C). pH value 12 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used as a water softener, detergent, metal cleaner, in paper manufacturing, as photographic developer ingredient and for softening water.

Sodium metasilicate: is a white crystalline powder, readily soluble in water, thus forming alkaline solution. The product is commonly known as water glass. Formula: Na2O.3.75 SiO2 to 2Na2O.SiO2 with various proportions of water. Viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP. Soluble in water, pH value 12.0 - 12.8 (1% of concentration in water, 20 °C. A little water dissolves water glass more readily than much water does. Use: Both the types of sodium metasilicate, i.e. pentahydrate as well nonahydrate are used particularly in the manufacture of industrial detergents, corrosion inhibitors, washing preparations and disinfectants, adhesives, pigments, water treatment, bleaching and sizing of textiles and paper pulp, as a binder for foundry cores and molds and in waterproofing mortars and cements. Sodium silicates are very abrasive and harmful to the shaft seal faces. Double shaft seal may be required.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sodium sulfate, Na2SO4, is a white, crystalline compound at ordinary temperatures. Sodium sulfate is soluble in cold water and very soluble in hot water. Melting point: 884 °C.Solubility in water 160 g/l (20 °C). pH value 6 - 8 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). The decahydrate of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4, 10H2O) is Glauber's salt. Use: The principal use of sodium sulfate is in processing wood pulp for making kraft paper. It is also used in glass manufacture, textile dyeing, and synthetic detergents.

Sodium sulfite: Na2SO3, a white crystalline or powdered compound. Solubility in water 220 g/l (20 °C) pH value 8.8 - 10 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: in preserving foods, silvering mirrors, developing photographs, and making dyes. Sodium sulfite is primarily used as a pulping and dechlorination agent by the pulp industry. Other applications include its use to remove oxygen in boiler water and as an antioxidant in film processing. Sodium sulfite also serves to remove chlorine in many industrial applications.

Sodium thiosulfate is readily soluble in water and is a mild reducing agent. Solubility: 790g/l at 4 °C. Melting point: 48 °C. Specific gravity: 1.73. pH of aqueous solution 6.5-8. Use: Because it dissolves silver salts, its major use is in photography for developing film. It is also used in chrome-tanning leather as a bleach and in chemical manufacture. Sodium thiosulfate is produced mostly from liquid waste products of sodium sulfide or sulfur dye manufacture. It is also produced from sodium carbonate, sulfur dioxide, and sulfur by a process that involves several steps.

Softened water: Any water that is treated to reduce hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) 17.1 mg/l or less, expressed as calcium carbonate.
The negative effects of hard water can be reversed through the use of softened water. It is normal practice for commercial, industrial and public sector organisations to soften their hard water. A water softener works on the principal of "cation exchange" in which ions of the hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) are exchanged for sodium or potassium ions, effectively reducing the concentration of hardness minerals to significant levels.
Excessive hardness combined with soaps and detergents create sticky and unpleasant scum, which reduces the effectiveness of these cleaners ultimately requiring more of the soap or detergent to do the same job. Calcium precipitates also build up and shortens useful life of laundry fabrics, appliances and fixtures. Energy efficiency in water heaters and boilers are minimized by the scaling of the heat exchange surfaces as the hardness minerals precipitate out of solution.

Softened water: Any water that is treated to reduce hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) 17.1 mg/l or less, expressed as calcium carbonate.
The negative effects of hard water can be reversed through the use of softened water. It is normal practice for commercial, industrial and public sector organisations to soften their hard water. A water softener works on the principal of "cation exchange" in which ions of the hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) are exchanged for sodium or potassium ions, effectively reducing the concentration of hardness minerals to significant levels.
Excessive hardness combined with soaps and detergents create sticky and unpleasant scum, which reduces the effectiveness of these cleaners ultimately requiring more of the soap or detergent to do the same job. Calcium precipitates also build up and shortens useful life of laundry fabrics, appliances and fixtures. Energy efficiency in water heaters and boilers are minimized by the scaling of the heat exchange surfaces as the hardness minerals precipitate out of solution.

Diethyl ether is a highly volatile, flammable and colorless organic solvent used in Plastic industry (e.g. cellulose acetate). Boiling Point: 34.6 °C Flash Point: -45 °C Viscosity: 0.224 cP at 20 °C Density: 0.7134 g/mL at 20 °C

Melting point -16 °C. Specific gravity 0.93 - 0.98. Viscosity about 40 cSt. at 38 °C and 73 cSt at 20 °C.
Soybean oil is the world's most widely used edible oil. In the United States, soybean oil accounts for nearly 80% of edible oil consumption. Soybean oil is one of the few non-fish oils containing linolenic acid, an omega-3 fatty acid that has been shown to help prevent heart disease.
Almost all margarine and shortenings contain soybean oil. It also is frequently found in mayonnaise, salad dressings, frozen foods, imitation dairy, meat products and commercially baked goods.

Stearic acid: A colourless, odorless, waxlike saturated fatty acid, CH3(CH2)16COOH, almost insoluble in water (less than 0.1%).
Melting point: 69 °C. Boiling point: 383 °C. Flash point: 196 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 395 °C. Specific gravity 0.87
Stearic acid is also called octedacanoic acid, and it is one of the most common long-chain fatty acids, found in combined form in natural animal and vegetable fats. Commercial "stearic acid" is a mixture of approximately equal amounts of stearic and palmitic acids and small amounts of oleic acid. It is employed in the manufacture of candles, cosmetics, shaving soaps, lubricants, and pharmaceuticals.
In nature stearic acid occurs primarily as a mixed triglyceride, or fat, with other long-chain acids and as an ester of a fatty alcohol. It is much more abundant in animal fat than in vegetable fat; lard and tallow often contain up to 30 percent stearic acid.
Alkaline hydrolysis, or saponification, of fats yields soaps, which are the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. Pure stearic acid is obtained with difficulty from such a mixture by crystallization, vacuum distillation, or chromatography of the acids or suitable derivatives. The pure acid undergoes chemical reactions typical of carboxylic acids.

Sugar syrup: Other Names: Liquid sugar, sugar, beet sugar, cane sugar, sucrose. Formula: C12H22O11 Specific gravity: 1.1 to 1.5. Viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature. E.g 50 Brix* syrup has a viscosity of about 15 cP (21 °C). 68 Brix syrup (21 °C) has a viscosity of about 240 cP, while 76 Brix sugar (21 °C) has a viscosity of 1300 cP. Remarks: The term sugar syrup or syrup is a very broad one and is applied very generally to a number of sweet tasting carbohydrates. Use: Sugar syrups are used in food, for sweetening, in candy, preserves and jams, in making soap, pharmaceuticals, caramel, as a chemical intermediate for detergents, as an emulsifying agent in such things as plasticisers, resins, explosives, glues and insecticides. * BRIX is the measurement in percentage by weight of sucrose in pure water solution. This designation of BRIX degrees is only valid for pure sucrose solutions. Pure sucrose is extract from sugar-cane or sugar-beet.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies widely depending on specific gravity and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Sulfamic acid: A very corrosive acid. For that reason an inhibited solution of sulfamic acid is often used for descaling. Melting point 205 °C. The substance decomposes on heating or on burning producing toxic and corrosive fumes including nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. It reacts slowly with water to form ammonium bisulfate. Sulfamic acid is a dry, non-volatile, non-hygroscopic, odorless, white crystalline, stable solid acid. It is moderately soluble in water and forms a strongly acidic and corrosive aqueous solution (pH value 1.18 (1 g/100ml, H2O, 25 °C)) that is comparable in acidity to the common strong mineral acids but may be easily handled and stored in the dry form. Its solution is less corrosive towards metals than other mineral acids. Salts of sulfamic acid are very soluble in water. Use: Acid Cleaning and pH adjustment. Descaling agent of cooling towers (air conditioners), marine equipment (sea water evaporators), water wells, dairy equipment (pipeline milkers, milk evaporators), brewery equipment, sugar evaporators, pulp and paper equipment, desalination equipment, general industrial equipment (boilers, condensers, heat exchangers, evaporators, etc.) and household equipment. Bleaching for Pulp. Dyes and Pigments. Electroplating.

Sulfamic acid: A very corrosive acid. For that reason an inhibited solution of sulfamic acid is often used for descaling. Melting point 205 °C. The substance decomposes on heating or on burning producing toxic and corrosive fumes including nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides. It reacts slowly with water to form ammonium bisulfate. Sulfamic acid is a dry, non-volatile, non-hygroscopic, odorless, white crystalline, stable solid acid. It is moderately soluble in water and forms a strongly acidic and corrosive aqueous solution (pH value 1.18 (1 g/100ml, H2O, 25 °C)) that is comparable in acidity to the common strong mineral acids but may be easily handled and stored in the dry form. Its solution is less corrosive towards metals than other mineral acids. Salts of sulfamic acid are very soluble in water. Use: Acid Cleaning and pH adjustment. Descaling agent of cooling towers (air conditioners), marine equipment (sea water evaporators), water wells, dairy equipment (pipeline milkers, milk evaporators), brewery equipment, sugar evaporators, pulp and paper equipment, desalination equipment, general industrial equipment (boilers, condensers, heat exchangers, evaporators, etc.) and household equipment. Bleaching for Pulp. Dyes and Pigments. Electroplating.

Sulfurous acid: A solution of about 6% SO2 in water. When sulfur dioxide (SO2) is dissolved in water, an acidic solution results. This has long been loosely called a sulfurous acid, H2SO3, solution. Sulfurous acid solutions can be oxidised by strong oxidising agents, and oxygen from the atmospheric air slowly oxidises the solution to the more stable sulfuric acid. Sulfurous Acid will react with a base to form sulfite salts. Use: Sulphurous acid is a strong reducing agent. The solution has bleaching properties. Moistened wool, straw for hats, and other materials normally injured by chlorine are bleached on exposure to sulphur dioxide.

Sulfuric acid: H2SO4, corrosive, oily, colourless liquid, with a specific gravity of 1.85. Melting point: 10 °C. Boiling point 340 °C. (pH value 1 at 25%, 20 °C) Sulfuric acid is soluble in all proportions in water. When sulfuric acid is mixed with water, considerable heat is released. Unless the mixture is well stirred, the added water may be heated beyond its boiling point and the sudden formation of steam may blow the acid out of its container. Properties: Sulfuric acid is a strong acid, that in aqueous solution is largely changed to hydrogen ions (H+) and sulfate ions (SO4--). Each molecule gives two H+ ions, thus sulfuric acid is dibasic. Dilute solutions of sulfuric acid show all the behavior characteristics of acids. They taste sour, conduct electricity, neutralize alkalies, and corrode active metals with formation of hydrogen gas. Concentrated sulfuric acid, formerly called oil of vitriol, is a valuable desiccating agent. It acts so vigorously in this respect that it removes water from (and therefore chars) wood, cotton, sugar, and paper. It is used in the manufacture of ether, nitroglycerin, and dyes for its property as a desiccant. When concentrated sulfuric acid is heated, it behaves also as an oxidizing agent, capable, for example, of dissolving such relatively unreactive metals as copper, mercury, and lead to produce metal sulfate, sulfur dioxide, and water. Use: The uses of sulfuric acid are so varied that the volume of its production provides an approximate index of general industrial activity. American production of sulfuric acid exceeded 29 million tons annually in the early 1970s, a figure corresponding to a daily production of 1/3 kg (3/4 lb) per person throughout the year. The largest single use of sulfuric acid is for making fertilizers, both superphosphate and ammonium sulfate. It is also used in making organic products, refining petroleum, making paints and pigments, processing metals, and making rayon. One of the few consumer products containing sulfuric acid as such is the lead storage battery, or car energizer.

Sulfurous Acid will react with a base to form sulfite salts. Use: Sulphurous acid is a strong reducing agent. The solution has bleaching properties. Moistened wool, straw for hats, and other materials normally injured by chlorine are bleached on exposure to sulphur dioxide.

Water from precipitation e.g. a stormwater event, which is not seeped into the ground and which is discharged to the drain or sewer system directly form the ground or from exterior building surfaces.
Surface water may cause problems due to the volume of water, the intensity of the runoff and the potential contaminants that the water is carrying, i.e. water pollution. When runoff flows towards the sewer system, it picks up different contaminants such as petroleum/fuels, oils/grease, metal species, pesticides or fertilizers from the ground and surfaces that it runs on. Furthermore the water also carries abrasive particles such as sand, grit etc. which is dragged into the sewer system.

Surface water may cause problems due to the volume of water, the intensity of the runoff and the potential contaminants that the water is carrying, i.e. water pollution. When runoff flows towards the sewer system, it picks up different contaminants such as petroleum/fuels, oils/grease, metal species, pesticides or fertilizers from the ground and surfaces that it runs on. Furthermore the water also carries abrasive particles such as sand, grit etc. which is dragged into the sewer system.

Swimming pool water: The common chemicals in pool and spa water can be sorted in to three distinct groups 1 Chemicals used to disinfect the water. 2 Chemicals that affect the water "balance". 3 Residual chemicals.
Group No 1 includes Chlorine, Bromine, or any other disinfecting chemical used. Group No 2 includes pH, Total Alkalinity and Calcium Hardness. Group No 3 includes Cyanuric Acid, Sulpahates, and Chlorides.
Acceptable Chemical levels: pH value about 7.4, Free Chlorine 1.5-5mg/l, Combined Chlorine max 1.0 mg/l, Chlorides max 600 ppm (mg/l).

Swimming pool water: The common chemicals in pool and spa water can be sorted in to three distinct groups 1 Chemicals used to disinfect the water. 2 Chemicals that affect the water "balance". 3 Residual chemicals.
Group No 1 includes Chlorine, Bromine, or any other disinfecting chemical used. Group No 2 includes pH, Total Alkalinity and Calcium Hardness. Group No 3 includes Cyanuric Acid, Sulpahates, and Chlorides.
Acceptable Chemical levels: pH value about 7.4, Free Chlorine 1.5-5mg/l, Combined Chlorine max 1.0 mg/l, Chlorides max 600 ppm (mg/l).

SYLTHERM XLT is a silicone oil based heat transfer fluid (Dimethyl Polysiloxane) designed for use as a low temperature liquid phase heat transfer medium. Flash Point (closed Cup): 47 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 350 °C. Specific gravity at 25 °C: 0.852. Recommended use temperature range: -100 °C to 260 °C.

Hydraulic oil is fluid serving as the power transmission medium in a hydraulic system. The commonly used oil is petroleum oils or synthetic lubricants. The principal requirements of a premium hydraulic fluid are proper viscosity, high viscosity index, rust prevention and resistance to foaming.

Lubricating Oil: Three general types of lubricating oils are used today. Straight mineral oils which are produced entirely from natural "petroleum" base, synthetic oils which are derived from hydrocarbons, esters, glycols or silicones and finally "additive" oils which are petroleum oils having enhanced properties.
Those properties include slower oxidation, better corrosion inhibition, increased film strength, greater solid particle suspension, high viscosity, lower pour point and increased friction and wear properties.
Viscosity is probably the most important lube oil property. It is a measure of resistance to flow. A thick oil has high viscosity while a thin oil has low viscosity. Generally, the higher viscosity, oil has better ability to maintain the fluid film between wearing surfaces even when pressed together with great force. Viscosity is greatly affected by temperature in that the viscosity drops drastically as the temperature increases.
Viscosity Index (VI) is a measure of how viscosity changes with temperature. Viscosity improvers are used to keep the rate of change of viscosity to a minimum from low to high temperature. a minimum from low to high temperature.

Sodium chloride: NaCl, readily soluble in water (360 g/l, 20 °C) and insoluble or only slightly soluble in most other liquids. It forms small, transparent, colourless to white cubic crystals. Sodium chloride is odorless but has a characteristic taste. Specific Gravity: 1.1 to 1.2. Viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water. Use: Sodium chloride brine is used for refrigeration purposes in food preservation, in making glass, pottery, textile dyes, and soap. It is used in large amounts to melt ice and snow on streets and highways. The major use of salt is as a raw material for the production of chlorine, sodium metal, and sodium hydroxide; it is also used in large amounts in the Solvay process for making sodium carbonate. Notes: Corrosion will take place when cast iron or stainless steel handling calcium chloride brine is exposed to air.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Brines being solutions in water are normally almost as thin as water.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Tannic acid: tannin or gallotannic acid, astringent vegetable product found in a wide variety of plants. Tannic acid is a colourless to pale yellow solid.
Decomposes at 210 °C - 215 °C. Solubility in water 250 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
Tannic acid of commerce use normally contains about 10% of water.
Tannin varies somewhat in composition, having the approximate empirical formula C76H52O46. It is believed to be a glucoside in which each of the five hydroxyl groups of the glucose molecule is esterified with a molecule of digallic acid.
Sources include the bark of oak, hemlock, chestnut, and mangrove; the leaves of certain sumacs, and plant galls. Tannic acid is also present in tea, coffee, and walnuts. A solution of tannic acid is obtained from one of these natural sources by extraction with hot water. Tannic acid is in particular obtained from plant gall.
Tannic acid is used in tanning animal skins to make leather, it transforms certain proteins of animal tissue into compounds that resist decomposition. It is also used in manufacturing inks, as a mordant in dyeing, and in medicine as an astringent and for treatment of burns.

Decomposes at 210 °C - 215 °C. Solubility in water 250 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3.5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C).
