Naphthalene is a colourless, crystalline, solid flammable aromatic hydrocarbon with a pungent odor. The molecular structure of naphthalene is that of two benzene rings fused together with two adjacent carbon atoms common to both rings. It is insoluble in water, somewhat soluble in ethanol, soluble in benzene, and very soluble in ether, chloroform, or carbon disulfide. There may be some tendency for crystals to form. Melting point: 80 °C. Boiling point: 218 °C. Flash point: 88 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 567 °C. Specific gravity: 1.14. Viscosity 0.97 cP at 80 °C. Explosion limits: 0.9 - 5.9% Naphthalene is obtained from coal tar, a byproduct of the coking of coal. Use:It is used in mothballs and gives them their characteristic odor. Also used as lubricant in synthetic resins and as solvent for textile chemicals. From it are prepared derivatives that are used in the preparation of dyes and as insecticides and organic solvents. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Tartaric acid: HO2CCHOHCHOHCO2H, white colourless, odourless, crystalline powder. Very soluble in water: 1390 g/l (20 °C) pH value 1.6 (100 g/l, H2O, 25 °C). Melting point: 206 °C. Tartaric acid is an organic fruit acid. It occurs in many plants, particularly in the grape and is easily obtained from tartar.This natural acid is chiefly the dextrorotatory D-tartaric acid, called also D-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid or L-2,3-dihydroxybutanedioic acid. This form can be partially converted to the others by heating it with an aqueous alkali, e.g., potassium hydroxide. Tartaric acids can be synthesized from maleic acids or fumaric acids by reaction with aqueous potassium permanganate. The various isomeric forms differ in such physical properties as boiling point. Use: Tartaric acid is used in the form of its salts, e.g., cream of tartar and Rochelle salt. It is also used as synergist for antioxidants, acid, sequestrant and flavouring agent. Widely used in foodstuffs industry such as foaming agent of beer, acidity agent, taste improvement of foodstuffs, cold drink, candy, fruit juice and ferment powder.

This heat transfer fluid for cooling applications is a non-flammable solution. The composition is based on two specific salts in water solution (potassium acetate and potassium formate). Specially formulated corrosion inhibitors are added.
pH-value: 9 - 11.

Tetrachloroethane: 1,1,2,2-Tetrachloroethane is a colourless or pale yellow liquid with a suffocating, sweetish odour. Almost insoluble in water.
Melting point: -44 °C, boiling point: 146 °C. Flash point: none. Specific gravity: 1.595. Viscosity: 1.7 cP at 20 °C.
It is used in making other chemicals, insecticides, paints, rust removers and varnishes. Tetrachloroethane is toxic, a powerful narcotic and possibly carcinogenic.

Tetrachloroethylene: Also called Perchloroethylene, a colourless, dense, nonflammable, highly stable liquid with ether-like odour belonging to the family of organic halogen compounds. Tetrachloroethylene is denser than water and practically insoluble in it. Boiling point: 121 °C. Specific gravity: 1.62. Viscosity: 0.89 cP at 25 °C Tetrachloroethylene was first prepared in 1821 by the English physicist Michael Faraday; it has been commercially manufactured since about 1910, mostly from trichloroethylene. Use: Tetrachloroethylene is a powerful solvent for many organic substances. By the mid-20th century it had become the most widely used solvent in dry cleaning (displacing carbon tetrachloride and trichloroethylene) and was also commonly used for cleaning metal objects in vapour-degreasing apparatuses. Its broad acceptance has been based upon its nonflammability and low toxicity. Small quantities are also employed as a vermifuge, particularly against hookworm. However tetrachloroethylene is harmful if inhaled, ingested or in contact with skin.

Morpholine, a strong base is a colourless, oily, hygroscopic, volatile liquid with a characteristic amine odour. Morpholine is distributed as an anhydrous liquid and as 40% and 88% solutions with water. Melting point: -5 °C. Boiling point: 129 °C. Flash point (100% conc.): 39 °C (Closed cup). Auto ignition temperature (100% conc.): 310 °C. Specific gravity: 1.0. Viscosity (100%): 2.23 cP at 20 °C. Water solubility: 100% Use: Morpholine is used as a chemical intermediate in the rubber industry, as a corrosion inhibitor (especially in boiler systems), in the synthesis of optical brighteners, pharmaceutical products, in waxes, polishes and in dyes. Morpholine causes burn to any area of contact. Harmful if swallowed, inhaled or absorbed through skin.

Heat Transfer Liquids Mineral or synthetic hydrocarbon based heat transfer liquids (thermal stable liquids) containing effective oxidation and corrosion inhibitors. Heat transfer liquid is also known by a variety of trade names. Other Names: Heat transmission oil, thermal oil, HTO.
Specific gravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature. Viscosity: About 1-5 cSt at service temperatures. At 20 °C the viscosity typically is about 20-100 cSt.
Remarks: Heat transfer liquids are used instead of steam for transferring heat from a source to a point of use such as dies, presses, cooking vessels, processing equipment, etc. Many of them can operate at temperatures up to 315 °C. FKM elastomers are normally recommended but PTFE, FXM or FFKM may also be needed.
rdf:Description.specificGravity: About 0.8-1.0 varies with liquid and temperature.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Toluene is a colourless, flammable liquid. Soluble in alcohol, benzene and ether; insoluble in water. Toxic by inhalation, ingestion or by absorption through skin. Serious irritant. Melting point: -95 °C. Boiling point 111 °C. Flash point 4 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 506 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87. Viscosity: 1 cP. Toluene is obtained from coal tar and petroleum by distillation. It is used as a solvent and as a starting material for the synthesis of many compounds, including dyes and explosives. When toluene is treated with a mixture of nitric and sulfuric acids (a process known as nitration), trinitrotoluene (TNT) is produced. Use: Toluene is used in blending aviation gasoline, as a raw material for benzene phenol, as a solvent for paints, coatings, gums, resins and rubber cement. Used for making chemicals, in medicines, dyes, perfumes and as a source of toluene diisocyanates used in polyurethane resins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Toluene is a colourless, flammable liquid. Soluble in alcohol, benzene and ether; insoluble in water. Toxic by inhalation, ingestion or by absorption through skin. Serious irritant. Melting point: -95 °C. Boiling point 111 °C. Flash point 4 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 506 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87. Viscosity: 1 cP. Toluene is obtained from coal tar and petroleum by distillation. It is used as a solvent and as a starting material for the synthesis of many compounds, including dyes and explosives. When toluene is treated with a mixture of nitric and sulfuric acids (a process known as nitration), trinitrotoluene (TNT) is produced. Use: Toluene is used in blending aviation gasoline, as a raw material for benzene phenol, as a solvent for paints, coatings, gums, resins and rubber cement. Used for making chemicals, in medicines, dyes, perfumes and as a source of toluene diisocyanates used in polyurethane resins. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Maleic acid, or cis-butenedioic acid, is a geometric isomer of fumaric acid. Appearance: White crystals, faint acidulous odor. Specific gravity: 1.59. pH: less than 7 acidic. White crystals, dissolves readily in water and alcohol . Solubility in water 79 g/100g (25 °C). Melting point 139 °C-140 °C. At higher temperatures it forms the anhydride, which, like the acid, is irritating to the skin and toxic.
Maleic acid is a stronger organic acid, also called Cis-butenedioic Acid (HO2CCH=CHCO2H). It is an unsaturated organic dibasic acid, that is used in making polyesters for fibre-reinforced laminated moldings, paint for vehicles, and in the manufacture of fumaric acid and many other chemical products.
Maleic Acid is used in the production of insecticide (e.g. Malathion), medicine, synthetic resin and other chemicals, such as tartaric acid and malic acid. Maleic acid is also used as a mordant in dyeing.Maleic anhydride is interchangeable with the acid in most applications.
No Info

Trichloroethylene: CHClCCl2, is a stable, low-boiling, colourless, heavy, mobile, nonflammable, nonexplosive, noncombustible, toxic liquid. Specific Gravity: 1.46. Viscosity: 0.57 cP at 25 °C. Melting point: -73 °C. Boiling point: 87 °C. Flash point: (open cup) none up to boiling point. Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Vapor is harmful. Miscible with common organic solvents, insoluble in water. Use: Used in metal degreasing, solvent for oils, fats and waxes, dry cleaning, as a refrigerant, heat exchange liquid, as a fumigant, and for cleaning and drying small intricate parts.

Trichloroethylene: CHClCCl2, is a stable, low-boiling, colourless, heavy, mobile, nonflammable, nonexplosive, noncombustible, toxic liquid. Specific Gravity: 1.46. Viscosity: 0.57 cP at 25 °C. Melting point: -73 °C. Boiling point: 87 °C. Flash point: (open cup) none up to boiling point. Auto ignition temperature: 410 °C. Vapor is harmful. Miscible with common organic solvents, insoluble in water. Use: Used in metal degreasing, solvent for oils, fats and waxes, dry cleaning, as a refrigerant, heat exchange liquid, as a fumigant, and for cleaning and drying small intricate parts.

Chloroform: or trichloromethane, CHCl3, is a volatile, colourless, nonflammable liquid that has a sweetish taste and a somewhat pungent odor.
Melting point: -63 °C. Boiling point: 61 °C. Vapour pressure: 159 mm Hg at 20 °C. Flash point: none. Specific gravity: 1.48. Viscosity 0.38 cSt at 20 °C and 0.35 cSt. at 60 °C.
It dissolves freely in ethanol and ether but is almost insoluble in water. It was once used as a general anesthetic in surgery but has been replaced by less toxic, safer anesthetics, such as ether. Chemically, it is employed as a solvent for fats, alkaloids, iodine, and other substances.
When exposed to sunlight and air it reacts to form phosgene, a poisonous gas.

Sodium phosphate (tribasic):Sodium Phosphate Tribasic is a colorless to white crystalline (sugar or sand-like) or powdered solid. Salt of phosphoric acid, H3PO4. Melting point: 73 °C - 76 °C. Solubility in water 120 g/l (20 °C). pH value 12 (10 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used as a water softener, detergent, metal cleaner, in paper manufacturing, as photographic developer ingredient and for softening water.

Turpentine (mineral) or "white spirit": Turpentine substitutes consisting of naphtha thinners (solvent distilled from petroleum). They are colourless hydrocarbons. Boiling point: From 100 °C to 160 °C. Flash point: From 20 °C to 60 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 253 °C. Specific gravity: From 0.765 to 0.795. Viscosity: From 0.7 cPs to 1.7 cPs. Depending on which country you are in, "white spirit" can be one of several substances. In the UK it is "turpentine substitute" ie. paint thinner and is not recommended for burning. In Australia it is a cleaning solvent but it is not the same as the stuff in the UK. Following composition is typical: Solvent naphtha 45-50% , aliphatic petroleum distillates 45-50%, xylene 2%, toluene 2%. Use: as a paint thinner as well as for the cleaning of various surfaces.

Turpentine (oil) is distilled pine oil consisting of an essential oil (oil of turpentine) and a type of resin called rosin. Commercial turpentine is oil of turpentine with the rosin removed. When pure, it is a colorless, transparent, oily liquid with a penetrating odor and characteristic taste. It is a flammable liquid. Melting point: -60 °C to -50 °C. Boiling point: 150 °C 180 °C. Flash point: 35 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 253 °C. Specific gravity: 0.86. Viscosity: 1.49 cP at 20 °C. Use: Turpentine (oil) is used as a cleaner, and as a solvent or thinner for oil-based and alkyd coatings.

Potassium acetate: Solubility in water 2530 g/l (20 °C) pH value 7.5 - 8.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Potassium acetate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols).Potassium acetate is highly effective as antifreeze. It exerts much lower BOD-effects (Biological Oxygen Demand), and it offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Potassium formate: Very soluble in water. The aqueous solution is alkaline. Potassium formate is an alternative to common cooling liquids (glycols). Potassium formate is effective as antifreeze, it exerts much lower BOD effects and offers less environmental impact. However, it is more expensive than traditional formulations, and there is limited information available on the corrosion potential of this alternative. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the shaft seal faces.

Demineralized water (deionized (DI) water) - water from which both anions (e.g. chloride, sulfate, nitrate, phosphate, bicarbonate) and cations (e.g. calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium) have been removed by an ion exchange process. Only those substances, which ionize in water, are removed by deionization. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Today, deionized water has become an essential ingredient in hundreds of applications including: medical, laboratory, pharmaceutical, cosmetics, electronics manufacturing, food processing, plating, countless industrial processes, and even the final rinse at the local car wash. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Water quality from deionizers varies with the type of resins used, feed water quality, flow, efficiency of regeneration, remaining capacity, etc. because of these variables, it is critical in many DI water applications to know the precise quality. Resistivity/conductivity is the most convenient method for testing DI water quality. DI high purity water is a poor electrical conductor, having a resistivity of 18.2 million ohm-cm (18.2 megaohm) and conductivity of 0.055 micro Siemens/cm. It is the amount of ionized substances (or salts) dissolved in the water which determines water's ability to conduct electricity. Therefore, resistivity and its inverse, conductivity, are good general purpose quality parameters. Notes: Deionised water is corrosive to copper and cast iron because the water is "soft" and may contain traces of dissolved oxygen or CO2. It is corrosive to cement and concrete because it is "hungry" for calcium. Various thermoplastic and thermosetting resin formulations, as well as stainless steels and aluminium, can be used. Ultra pure water - water with a specific resistance higher than 1 megaohm-cm (less than 1 micro Siemens/cm). In the laboratory, it normally refers to ASTM D1193 Type 1 reagent grade water. Anything in laboratory water that is not H2O is an impurity. Although chemically pure water is not attainable, ultrapure water systems are now capable of reducing impurities down to the limits of detection. Distilled water - water that has been purified by passing through an evaporation-condensation cycle. It contains small quantities of dissolved solids. Multiple distilling will further lower the percentage of dissolved liquids. Softened water - water that was originally hard, but from which calcium and magnesium ions have been removed.

Appearance: white crystalline with a slight ammonia-like odor. Melting point: decomposes at 133 °C. Specific gravity at 20 °C: 1.03 (15 %w/w), 1.15 (50% w/w). Viscosity at 20 °C: 1.6 cSt (50% w/w). Water solubility: 1080g/l at 20 °C. pH: 7.2 (10% solution). Use: Urea is widely used in the agricultural industry as an animal feed additive and fertilizer.

Corn oil: Melting point -20 °C. Specific gravity 0.910. Viscosity about 32 cSt. at 54 °C.
A pale yellow liquid obtained from the embryos of corn grains, used especially as a cooking and salad oil and in the manufacture of margarine.

Olive oil: Pale yellow oil obtained from the pulp of olives by separating the liquids from solids. Olive oil was used in the ancient world for lighting, in the preparation of food, and as an anointing oil for both ritual and cosmetic purposes. It is produced mainly in Algeria, Greece, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Spain, Tunisia, and Turkey. The characteristics of the oil vary with the climate, cultivation, and variety of olive. Olive oil is one of the most digestible of the edible oils. To make the finest, or extra-virgin olive oil, the fruit is gathered when fully ripened, ground to a paste under granite or steel millstones, layered over straw mats, and pressed in a hydraulic press. Today, most olive oil is produced by just one pressing. The resulting oil is separated from the juice by settling or by centrifuge and then filtered. Olive oil of good quality is ready to use, without further refinement. Use: Although olive oil is chiefly used as a food or in food preservation, it is also used in soaps, certain pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics.

Peanut oil: Melting point about 3 °C. Specific gravity 0.91. Viscosity about 47 cSt. at 38 °C.
Among edible vegetable oils, peanut oil is exceeded in world production only by soybean. In extracting the oil in the U.S., the cleaned nuts are passed through hullers or shellers to separate the kernels. The kernels, which contain 48 to 56 percent of oil, are then crushed, heated and pressed hot in hydraulic presses.
The oil is used in the manufacture of margarine and shortenings, and as a salad and cooking oil, in soaps, and as a solvent for pharmaceutical preparations. The press cake is used for cattle food.

Rapeseed oil: Rapeseeds yield an oil, rapeseed-oil, or canola that in its crude form is used in cooking, as an ingredient in soap and margarine, and as a lamp fuel.
The use of the oil in cooking (frying and baking) increased in the late 20th century because it is the lowest in saturated fat of any edible oil. The refined form of rapeseed oil, known as colza oil, is used as a lubricant.
Viscosity: 1 poise - 40 poise at 25 °C.

Melting point -16 °C. Specific gravity 0.93 - 0.98. Viscosity about 40 cSt. at 38 °C and 73 cSt at 20 °C.
Soybean oil is the world's most widely used edible oil. In the United States, soybean oil accounts for nearly 80% of edible oil consumption. Soybean oil is one of the few non-fish oils containing linolenic acid, an omega-3 fatty acid that has been shown to help prevent heart disease.
Almost all margarine and shortenings contain soybean oil. It also is frequently found in mayonnaise, salad dressings, frozen foods, imitation dairy, meat products and commercially baked goods.

Glycerol: C3H5(OH)3, clear, colourless, odorless, syrupy liquid; hygroscopic. Melting point 18 °C. Boiling point 290 °C. Soluble in water, pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C) and alcohol, insoluble in ether. Flash point 177 °C. Specific gravity: 1.3. Viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration. Glycerol is present in the form of its esters (glycerides) in all animal and vegetable fats and oils. Use: as a component of antifreeze mixtures, as a sweetener, in alkyd resins, cellophane, explosives, ester gums, pharmaceuticals, perfumery, cosmetics, foodstuffs, as a solvent, in printer's ink rolls, as an emulsifying agent, in anti-freeze, for paper coatings and finishes, for special soaps, lubricants and softeners and as a hydraulic fluid. Notes: When used as antifreeze substances that inhibit corrosion are normally added. These substances may cause problems with abrasive wear at the the shaft seal faces.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from 44 to 1,000 cP. depending on temperature and concentration.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Vinegar is a sour liquid (pH 2.0 - 3.4) consisting mainly of acetic acid and water, produced by the action of bacteria on dilute solutions of ethyl alcohol derived from previous yeast fermentation. The coloring and flavoring are characteristic of the alcoholic liquor (as cider, beer, wine, fermented fruit juices, solutions of barley malt, hydrolyzed cereals, starches, or sugars) from which the vinegar is made. Use: Vinegar is used as a salad dressing, a preservative, a household remedy to allay irritations, a mild disinfectant, and in cooking, as a fiber softener. Vinegar has been known from antiquity as a natural byproduct of wine; the name is derived from the French vin aigre (sour wine). The manufacture as a separate industry began in France in the 17th cent.

Copper sulfate: copper (II) sulfate, common name for the blue crystalline heptahydrate of cupric sulfate, in which copper has valence +2. Solubility in water 317g/l (20 °C). pH value3.5 - 4.5 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Specific gravity (15%, 20 °C): 1.170. Viscosity (15%, 20 °C): 1.7 cSt. Use: Copper sulfate is used in copperplating, in dyeing (as a mordant), in wet-cell batteries, in pigments, and in insecticides, fungicides, and algicides. The anhydrous sulfate is used to detect the presence of water in certain organic liquids; it turns into the blue pentahydrate, e.g., when added to alcohol that contains water.

Melting point: 64 °C. Solubility in water 665 g/l (20 °C). pH value 3-4 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used in the manufacture of inks, in wool dyeing as a mordant, and in sewage and water treatment as a substitute for aluminum sulfate. Used as a pigment, fertilizer, and feed additive, and as a medicine in the treatment of iron deficiency.

Zinc sulfate chemical compound ZnSO4, a very water soluble, transparent, colorless, crystalline compound. Solubility in water 960 g/l (20 °C). pH value 4 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used to supply zinc in animal feeds, fertilizers, and agricultural sprays; in making lithopone; in coagulation baths for rayon; in electrolyte for zinc plating; as a mordant in dyeing; as a preservative for skins and leather; and in medicine as an astringent.

Zinc sulfate chemical compound ZnSO4, a very water soluble, transparent, colorless, crystalline compound. Solubility in water 960 g/l (20 °C). pH value 4 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used to supply zinc in animal feeds, fertilizers, and agricultural sprays; in making lithopone; in coagulation baths for rayon; in electrolyte for zinc plating; as a mordant in dyeing; as a preservative for skins and leather; and in medicine as an astringent.

Effluent is the outflow of water from a natural body of water or from a man-made structure.
Effluent in the man-made sense is generally considered to be pollution. This could entail outflow from a sewage treatment facility, the wastewater discharge from industrial facilities or water from a detention or process tank. The water can be of varying quality - ranging from heavily polluted to completely clean.

Wastewater is a common designation for any water that in one way has been affected in quality by human influence and which is transported through a combined or separate sewer system. Wastewater contains a broad spectrum of waste of organic or inorganic origin that can be discharged from different sources. These sources can be, for example, domestic residences, commercial properties, industrial plants, agriculture as well as surface run-off and infiltrated water in the sewer system. These different sources are commonly divided into three categories: Domestic wastewater Water which is contaminated by use and normally discharged from toilets, showers, baths, wash basins, sinks, and floor gullies. Trade effluent Wastewater discharge resulting from any industrial or commercial activity. Surface water Water from precipitation which as not seeped into the ground and which is discharged to the drain or sewer system directly form the ground or from exterior building surfaces. If the wastewater is comprised mostly of domestic wastewater and surface water, it is often referred to as municipal wastewater whereas if the main part of the wastewater is comprised of trade effluent it is often referred to as industrial. If the content of trade effluent in the wastewater is significant or completely composed of trade effluent special considerations must be taken during evaluation of material variants as some chemicals might be present in high concentrations. The terms black and grey water is sometimes also used to describe wastewater. The term black water describes wastewater which contains faecal matter and urine. Wastewater without the content of faecal matter or urine is referred to as grey water, and comprises 50-80% of residential wastewater Wastewater encompasses a wide range of potential contaminants of inorganic or organic origin. Below is a partial list of wastewater constituents:
  • Bacteria, viruses, prions and parasitic worms.
  • Organic particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibres, plant material, humus, etc.
  • Soluble organic material such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, pharmaceuticals etc.
  • Inorganic particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.
  • Soluble inorganic material such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, hydrogen sulphide, heavy metals, etc.
  • Macro-solids such as sanitary napkins, napkins/diapers, condoms, needles, children's toys, dead pets etc.
  • Gases such as hydrogen sulphide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.
  • Emulsions such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.
  • Toxins such as pesticides, poisons, herbicides, etc.

Wastewater is a common designation for any water that in one way has been affected in quality by human influence and which is transported through a combined or separate sewer system. Wastewater contains a broad spectrum of waste of organic or inorganic origin that can be discharged from different sources. These sources can be, for example, domestic residences, commercial properties, industrial plants, agriculture as well as surface run-off and infiltrated water in the sewer system. These different sources are commonly divided into three categories: Domestic wastewater Water which is contaminated by use and normally discharged from toilets, showers, baths, wash basins, sinks, and floor gullies. Trade effluent Wastewater discharge resulting from any industrial or commercial activity. Surface water Water from precipitation which as not seeped into the ground and which is discharged to the drain or sewer system directly form the ground or from exterior building surfaces. If the wastewater is comprised mostly of domestic wastewater and surface water, it is often referred to as municipal wastewater whereas if the main part of the wastewater is comprised of trade effluent it is often referred to as industrial. If the content of trade effluent in the wastewater is significant or completely composed of trade effluent special considerations must be taken during evaluation of material variants as some chemicals might be present in high concentrations. The terms black and grey water is sometimes also used to describe wastewater. The term black water describes wastewater which contains faecal matter and urine. Wastewater without the content of faecal matter or urine is referred to as grey water, and comprises 50-80% of residential wastewater Wastewater encompasses a wide range of potential contaminants of inorganic or organic origin. Below is a partial list of wastewater constituents:
  • Bacteria, viruses, prions and parasitic worms.
  • Organic particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibres, plant material, humus, etc.
  • Soluble organic material such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, pharmaceuticals etc.
  • Inorganic particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.
  • Soluble inorganic material such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, hydrogen sulphide, heavy metals, etc.
  • Macro-solids such as sanitary napkins, napkins/diapers, condoms, needles, children's toys, dead pets etc.
  • Gases such as hydrogen sulphide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.
  • Emulsions such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.
  • Toxins such as pesticides, poisons, herbicides, etc.
No Info

Sodium metasilicate: is a white crystalline powder, readily soluble in water, thus forming alkaline solution. The product is commonly known as water glass. Formula: Na2O.3.75 SiO2 to 2Na2O.SiO2 with various proportions of water. Viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP. Soluble in water, pH value 12.0 - 12.8 (1% of concentration in water, 20 °C. A little water dissolves water glass more readily than much water does. Use: Both the types of sodium metasilicate, i.e. pentahydrate as well nonahydrate are used particularly in the manufacture of industrial detergents, corrosion inhibitors, washing preparations and disinfectants, adhesives, pigments, water treatment, bleaching and sizing of textiles and paper pulp, as a binder for foundry cores and molds and in waterproofing mortars and cements. Sodium silicates are very abrasive and harmful to the shaft seal faces. Double shaft seal may be required.
rdf:Description.viscosity: Varies from a few to several thousand cP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Boiler water: "Boiler water" is the term used to specifically refer to the water which is heated inside the boiler. It is that water which is provided by the boiler feedwater and withdrawn from the boiler as either heated water or steam. Aside from the BFW treatment, corrosion of boiler water systems is further controlled by proper boiler operation and in some cases by "internal" treatments with chemical additives which adjust pH and control solids precipitation and sludge formation. The chemicals are fed either to the boiler feedwater or to the boiler drum.
Boiler feedwater ("BFW") may either be the same as the makeup water, or may consist of returned steam condensate, or (as in most cases) will be a mixture of both. The relative amounts of makeup and condensate may vary. A typical figure is 5% makeup with 95% condensate, but this depends on how the steam plant is operated and how much of the steam is condensed and recovered for recirculation. In order to be non-scaling, the BFW must be a softened or demineralised water. In order to be non-corrosive to the carbon-steel or low-alloy steel components from which boilers are normally constructed, the water must be thoroughly deaerated. This is partially achieved by thermomechanical means (use of deaeration heating tanks), while the last traces of dissolved oxygen are removed by chemical agents ("oxygen scavengers").

Brackish water: Water containing too much salt (chloride) to be useful to people but less salt than ocean water. Generally, water containing dissolved minerals in amounts that exceed normally acceptable standards for municipal, domestic, and irrigation uses. Considerably less saline than sea water. Water containing between 1,000-4,000 parts per million (PPM) Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). Notes: Due to the high chloride content brackish water is corrosive.

Demineralized water (deionized (DI) water) - water from which both anions (e.g. chloride, sulfate, nitrate, phosphate, bicarbonate) and cations (e.g. calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium) have been removed by an ion exchange process. Only those substances, which ionize in water, are removed by deionization. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Today, deionized water has become an essential ingredient in hundreds of applications including: medical, laboratory, pharmaceutical, cosmetics, electronics manufacturing, food processing, plating, countless industrial processes, and even the final rinse at the local car wash. Generally, deionized water is considered of higher quality than distilled water and is more economical to produce. Water quality from deionizers varies with the type of resins used, feed water quality, flow, efficiency of regeneration, remaining capacity, etc. because of these variables, it is critical in many DI water applications to know the precise quality. Resistivity/conductivity is the most convenient method for testing DI water quality. DI high purity water is a poor electrical conductor, having a resistivity of 18.2 million ohm-cm (18.2 megaohm) and conductivity of 0.055 micro Siemens/cm. It is the amount of ionized substances (or salts) dissolved in the water which determines water's ability to conduct electricity. Therefore, resistivity and its inverse, conductivity, are good general purpose quality parameters. Notes: Deionised water is corrosive to copper and cast iron because the water is "soft" and may contain traces of dissolved oxygen or CO2. It is corrosive to cement and concrete because it is "hungry" for calcium. Various thermoplastic and thermosetting resin formulations, as well as stainless steels and aluminium, can be used. Ultra pure water - water with a specific resistance higher than 1 megaohm-cm (less than 1 micro Siemens/cm). In the laboratory, it normally refers to ASTM D1193 Type 1 reagent grade water. Anything in laboratory water that is not H2O is an impurity. Although chemically pure water is not attainable, ultrapure water systems are now capable of reducing impurities down to the limits of detection. Distilled water - water that has been purified by passing through an evaporation-condensation cycle. It contains small quantities of dissolved solids. Multiple distilling will further lower the percentage of dissolved liquids. Softened water - water that was originally hard, but from which calcium and magnesium ions have been removed.

District heating: The provision of a public heating supply, delivered form the power plant by means of hot water in a closed circuit. After supplying heat to a building's own space heating and domestic hot water heating system, the cooled district heating water is pumped back for reheating. The district heating water is often treated. The strategy is to maintain high quality water in the system through continual filtering, deaeration and demineralisation (or softening) and to maintain the pH between 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide. The procedure requires careful monitoring of the chemistry of the system water. Demineralisation is preferable to softening because it reduces the total ionic concentration. Example of water treatment method filter demineralise or soften deaerate raise pH to 9.5-10 by adding sodium hydroxide (NaOH)

Water: H2O, also further identified by such terms as soft, tap, hard, distilled, fresh, etc. Specific. Gravity.: 1.0. Viscosity: 1 cP at 20 °C. Water is the most readily available liquid and one of the most difficult to handle, primarily because of its lack of lubrication, corrosive and erosive nature. Water in nature is rarely pure in the "distilled water" sense; it contains dissolved salts, buffers, nutrients, etc., with exact concentrations dependent on local conditions. Use: Enormous quantities are required for cooling of products and equipment, for process needs, for boiler feed and for sanitary and potable water. It was estimated, in 1980, that the water requirements for industry in the USA approximated 525 billion liters per day. A substantial quantity of this water was reused. The intake of "new" water was estimated to be about 140 billion liters daily. If this water was pure and contained no contaminants, there would be little need for water conditioning or water treatment. Water possesses several unique properties, one being its ability to dissolve to some degree every substance occurring on the earth's crust and in the atmosphere. Because of this solvent property, water typically contains a variety of impurities. These impurities are a source of potential trouble through deposition of the impurities in water lines, boiler tubes and on products which are contacted by it. Notes: Water becomes corrosive in the presence of dissolved oxygen. The degree of corrosivity depends on pH, temperature and salt content. For many purposes (e.g. industrial and drinking water applications) water undergoes a further treatment (e.g. disinfection, softening etc.) which may affect the corrosivity of the water.

Mine water: Mine water consists of all water that collects in mine workings, both surface and underground, as a result of inflow from rain or surface water and groundwater seepage.
Characteristics: Corrosive and normally of low pH because of its contact with sulfur-bearing material. Mine water can have high concentrations of heavy metals, oils, and total dissolved solids as well as the temperature can be elevated. Depending on the source of the water and the regional and hydrological conditions, mine water can be a significant problem because of its enormous quantity and chemical composition. Mine water may have to be pumped continuously from the mine during operations.
Mine Water Treatment: Since mine water is often acidic, one of the most effective treatment techniques is to raise the pH by adding lime or other suitable basic chemicals. Dissovled solids can be effectively removed from the water in settling ponds, adding flocculates, or "filtering" the water with ion exchange or reverse osmosis.

Ozonation is the process of feeding ozone into a water supply for the purpose of decolorization, deodorization, disinfection and oxidation. Ozone, a form of oxygen, is the most powerful disinfectant, but it is not effective in controlling biological contaminants in the distribution pipes because it does not have a long-lasting residual. Ozonation destroys bacteria and viruses and requires a shorter time period to treat water than most other water treatment methods. Ozone, a reactive gas, is made by subjecting oxygen to high electrical voltages. Ozone's reactive nature allows it to readily react with and break up many organic compounds and kill bacteria and other organisms in the water supply. On-site production of ozone is energy-intensive. Ozone treatment is becoming more common in the United States as questions arise about disinfection byproducts. Ozone has been widely used in Europe for 100 years.
Typical values: Bottled water, drinking water, swimming pool spa water purification: less than 1 ppm. Cleaning: less than 10 ppm. Semiconductor industry, pharmaceutical industry: less than 100 ppm

Seawater: Most of the elements that can be found on earth are present in seawater, at least in trace amounts. However, eleven of the constituents alone account for 99.95% of the total solutes, chloride ions being by far the largest constituent. The concentration of dissolved materials in the sea varies greatly with location and time because seawater is diluted by rivers, rain, or melting ice, or is concentrated by evaporation. Salinity of Ocean/Sea waters The Practical Salinity Scale defines salinity in terms of the conductivity ratio of a sample to that of a solution of 32.4356 g of KCl at 15 °C in a 1 kg solution. A sample of seawater at 15 °C with a conductivity equal to this KCl solution has a salinity of exactly 35 practical salinity units (psu). Baltic Sea: about 5 to 15 psu. Black Sea: less than 20 psu. Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean: from 33 to 37 psu. Mediterranean: about 40 psu. Dead Sea: about 300-400 psu. Conversion of salinity to chloride: Chloride (ppm) = (Salinity x 1000) / 1.8 Use: Seawater systems are used by many industries such as shipping, offshore oil and gas production, power plants and coastal industrial plants. The main use of seawater is for cooling purposes but it is also used for fire fighting, oil field water injection and for desalination plants.

Softened water: Any water that is treated to reduce hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) 17.1 mg/l or less, expressed as calcium carbonate.
The negative effects of hard water can be reversed through the use of softened water. It is normal practice for commercial, industrial and public sector organisations to soften their hard water. A water softener works on the principal of "cation exchange" in which ions of the hardness minerals (magnesium and calcium) are exchanged for sodium or potassium ions, effectively reducing the concentration of hardness minerals to significant levels.
Excessive hardness combined with soaps and detergents create sticky and unpleasant scum, which reduces the effectiveness of these cleaners ultimately requiring more of the soap or detergent to do the same job. Calcium precipitates also build up and shortens useful life of laundry fabrics, appliances and fixtures. Energy efficiency in water heaters and boilers are minimized by the scaling of the heat exchange surfaces as the hardness minerals precipitate out of solution.

Swimming pool water: The common chemicals in pool and spa water can be sorted in to three distinct groups 1 Chemicals used to disinfect the water. 2 Chemicals that affect the water "balance". 3 Residual chemicals.
Group No 1 includes Chlorine, Bromine, or any other disinfecting chemical used. Group No 2 includes pH, Total Alkalinity and Calcium Hardness. Group No 3 includes Cyanuric Acid, Sulpahates, and Chlorides.
Acceptable Chemical levels: pH value about 7.4, Free Chlorine 1.5-5mg/l, Combined Chlorine max 1.0 mg/l, Chlorides max 600 ppm (mg/l).

Sodium hydroxide: chemical compound, NaOH, a white crystalline substance that readily absorbs carbon dioxide and moisture from the air. It is very soluble in water, alcohol, and glycerin. It is a caustic and a strong base. Solubility in water 1090 g/l (20 °C), pH value 14 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Commonly known as caustic soda, lye, or sodium hydrate, it is available commercially in various solid forms, e.g., pellets, sticks, or chips, and in water solutions of various concentrations; both solid and liquid forms vary in purity. The principal method for its manufacture is electrolytic dissociation of sodium chloride; chlorine gas is a coproduct. Small amounts of sodium hydroxide are produced by the soda-lime process in which a concentrated solution of sodium carbonate (soda) is reacted with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime); calcium carbonate precipitates, leaving a sodium hydroxide solution. Use: The major use of sodium hydroxide is as a chemical and in the manufacture of other chemicals; because it is inexpensive, it is widely used wherever a strong base is needed. It is also used in producing rayon and other textiles, in making paper, in etching aluminum, in making soaps and detergents. Used as corrosion inhibitor for cast iron and steel while zinc, brass and aluminium on the other hand have only limited resistance to sodium hydroxide.

Turpentine (mineral) or "white spirit": Turpentine substitutes consisting of naphtha thinners (solvent distilled from petroleum). They are colourless hydrocarbons. Boiling point: From 100 °C to 160 °C. Flash point: From 20 °C to 60 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 253 °C. Specific gravity: From 0.765 to 0.795. Viscosity: From 0.7 cPs to 1.7 cPs. Depending on which country you are in, "white spirit" can be one of several substances. In the UK it is "turpentine substitute" ie. paint thinner and is not recommended for burning. In Australia it is a cleaning solvent but it is not the same as the stuff in the UK. Following composition is typical: Solvent naphtha 45-50% , aliphatic petroleum distillates 45-50%, xylene 2%, toluene 2%. Use: as a paint thinner as well as for the cleaning of various surfaces.

Zinc sulfate chemical compound ZnSO4, a very water soluble, transparent, colorless, crystalline compound. Solubility in water 960 g/l (20 °C). pH value 4 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used to supply zinc in animal feeds, fertilizers, and agricultural sprays; in making lithopone; in coagulation baths for rayon; in electrolyte for zinc plating; as a mordant in dyeing; as a preservative for skins and leather; and in medicine as an astringent.

Xylene, C6H4(CH3)2, is a highly flammable, colorless, oily, liquid aromatic hydrocarbon obtained from coal tar, wood tar, and sometimes from petroleum. Insoluble in water. It is a mixture of three isomers that differ structurally from one another in the location of the two methyl groups that have replaced hydrogen atoms in the benzene molecule. Melting point: -48 °C to -13 °C. Boiling point: 138 °C to 144 °C. Flash point: 27 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 528 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87 kg/m3. Viscosity: from 0.6-0.8 cP at 20 °C. The separation of these three isomers from one another by fractional distillation is difficult because their boiling points are so close together. The xylenes are often used in the synthesis of other compounds, e.g., the xylidenes that are amino derivatives used in the synthesis of azo dyes (e.g. methyl orange) and other compounds. Use: Xylene is used extensively as a solvent. Notes: Harmful if swallowed or inhaled. Eye, skin and respiratory irritant. May act as a narcotic. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Xylene, C6H4(CH3)2, is a highly flammable, colorless, oily, liquid aromatic hydrocarbon obtained from coal tar, wood tar, and sometimes from petroleum. Insoluble in water. It is a mixture of three isomers that differ structurally from one another in the location of the two methyl groups that have replaced hydrogen atoms in the benzene molecule. Melting point: -48 °C to -13 °C. Boiling point: 138 °C to 144 °C. Flash point: 27 °C. Auto ignition temperature: 528 °C. Specific gravity: 0.87 kg/m3. Viscosity: from 0.6-0.8 cP at 20 °C. The separation of these three isomers from one another by fractional distillation is difficult because their boiling points are so close together. The xylenes are often used in the synthesis of other compounds, e.g., the xylidenes that are amino derivatives used in the synthesis of azo dyes (e.g. methyl orange) and other compounds. Use: Xylene is used extensively as a solvent. Notes: Harmful if swallowed or inhaled. Eye, skin and respiratory irritant. May act as a narcotic. The flash point is the lowest temperature at which a liquid produces enough vapor to ignite in the presence of a source of ignition. The lower the flash point, the greater the risk of fire. The autoignition temperature is the lowest temperature required to ignite or cause self-sustained combustion in the presence of air and in the absence of a flame or spark.

Zinc chloride: White, odourless granules. Very soluble in water. Melting Point: 293 °C. Specific Gravity: 2.9. Solubility in water 3680 g/l (20 °C). pH value 5 (100 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: Galvanizing fluxes; soldering fluxes; electroplating; batteries uses; wood preservative; dehydrating and condensing agent in organic synthesis; burnishing and polishing compounds for steels; antiseptic and deodorant preparations; textiles; adhesives; dental cements; glass etching; petroleum refining; parchment; dentifrices; embalming and taxidermists fluids; medicine; dyestuff; pigments; antistatic.

Zinc phosphate is insoluble in water, but soluble in diluted mineral acids.
The most commonly applied paint pretreatment for developing good bonding qualities between paint and metals is zinc-phosphate. In addition to the excellent effect that a zinc-phosphate coating has on paint adhesion, it also aids to decrease the tendency for paint disbondment during atmospheric exposure in a corroding environment.

Zinc sulfate chemical compound ZnSO4, a very water soluble, transparent, colorless, crystalline compound. Solubility in water 960 g/l (20 °C). pH value 4 - 6 (50 g/l, H2O, 20 °C). Use: It is used to supply zinc in animal feeds, fertilizers, and agricultural sprays; in making lithopone; in coagulation baths for rayon; in electrolyte for zinc plating; as a mordant in dyeing; as a preservative for skins and leather; and in medicine as an astringent.
